DOC.HEAD: Says Congressional Leaders Given Gulf Crisis Phones
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Dole said Monday that he and other key congressional leaders have been given special mobile telephones so the White House can keep them informed of developments in the Persian Gulf. Dole, the Kansas Republican and Senate minority leader, said he and at least four other lawmakers have had the phones for about a week. The others, he said, are Democratic Sen. George Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader; House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Washington; and House leaders Reps. Robert Michel, R-Illinois, and Richard Gephardt, D-Missouri. Dole said the phones have been specially adapted to prevent anyone from listening in. Dole mentioned the phones while making a campaign appearance for fellow Republican Dick Nichols, who is running for Congress in Tuesday's election. He said he carries the phone with him at all times, and said it allows him immediate consultation with Bush or other White House officials. The phones show Bush ``is making a sincere effort to consult Congress on the Middle East crisis,'' he said. ``The only time he would not consult Congress is if a mission or American lives are threatened,'' Dole said. ``In that case, consulting with the congressional leadership can wait.'' Dole said he hopes he doesn't get a phone call because ``that would mean an escalation of the crisis in the Middle East.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Aiming for Atlantis Launch Next Week
DOC.TEXT: NASA expects to send space shuttle Atlantis into orbit with a spy satellite next week. Forrest McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center, said Monday ``the best guess'' is Atlantis will lift off on its secret military mission around Nov. 16. Liftoff had been scheduled for Nov. 9 but was delayed because of undisclosed problems with the satellite, which reportedly will spy on Iraq. The shuttle actually was supposed to have gone up on a 10-day mission in July but was grounded all summer by hydrogen leaks. NASA still plans to launch Columbia in early December, even though the agency likes to have at least three weeks between flights, McCartney said. Work will be speeded up so Columbia's flight can be completed by Christmas, saving the agency on holiday pay and allowing it to shut down certain operations at Kennedy Space Center for maintenance, McCartney said. ``But we will not cut down on the normal inspections and data that we look at,'' he said. Columbia will carry the $150 million Astro observatory aloft during its mission. The shuttle, like Atlantis, was grounded since the summer by hydrogen leaks. Both shuttles were cleared for flight after fueling tests last month. McCartney, meanwhile, denied on Monday that employee drug use is responsible for a series of accidents this year involving shuttle equipment. A bag containing about a gram of cocaine was discovered under a desk in a shuttle hangar on Friday. NASA is investigating the incident. In analyzing the accidents, ``we have not found a common thread that would cause you to think'' drugs are to blame, McCartney said. The latest accident involved a 9-foot beam that was left to rattle around inside Atlantis last month, causing minor damage. In addition, some of Columbia's hydrogen leaks were attributed to improperly installed seals. ``I think you would like to be sure that all of the folks that are doing any work on any flight hardware are in full command of themselves, so it does concern me,'' McCartney said. But he added, ``It would be naive to think that with as many thousands of people that we have here'' no one uses drugs.

DOC.HEAD: New Community Service Requirement Lands School District in Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Along with reading, writing and `rithmetic, there's a new graduation requirement for incoming freshmen at this city's two high schools this fall: community service. The supporters of the requirement in the Bethlehem Area School District say it will teach the basic American value of helping others. Opponents, who are taking it to court, call it involuntary servitude that forces ideals on students contrary to those of their parents. ``Community service is a clear national priority that has been voiced since President Kennedy's inaugural address,'' said Andrew Faust, the school board's attorney. ``It's wrapped up in what we think of ourselves as a nation.'' Thomas Moralis, whose son David is a student, is trying to block the program. ``I don't want my son being told what to do,'' Moralis said. ``I went to school in a free America, and I want the same for my children.'' The suit, which isn't expected to go to trial before the middle of next year, contends the student service program violates the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, which bans involuntary servitude. It also says the program violates the 1st and 14th Amendments by interfering with parental rights. ``Beyond the involuntary servitude, the parents object to the philosophical underpinnings,'' said Robert Magee, attorney for the Moralis family and another family. ``It's force-feeding a certain set of values about altruism on children.'' The school board voted in April to adopt the program, a concept that has existed for years involuntary form in some schools across the country and is now being pushed by legislation approved by Congress. ``I think it's a contradiction of terms,'' said Michelle Bennett, a student at Liberty High School. ``You shouldn't have to volunteer, but it's a good idea to have it as an elective. I like volunteerism because I've done it, but it doesn't make much sense to make it a requirement because uninterested kids won't do as good a job.'' But another student, Gilberto Quinones Jr., disagreed. ``It'll give the kids more self-esteem and teach them values in the work they're doing,'' he said. ``It will teach them how to act maturely and they can learn and see if they like the work.'' The Bethlehem district based its program, which requires 60 hours of community service, on one in Atlanta. Three other Pennsylvania districts have mandatory student service programs, and 30 have voluntary programs, according to Dr. Joseph Bard of the state Education Department. Other states moving ahead with student service programs, some mandatory and some voluntary, are Maryland, Washington, California and Minnesota, said John Brisco, director of the state's Pennserve program, which encourages volunteerism and sponsors grants to school districts that promote community service to keep students from dropping out. ``I'm excited about this. It seems to work,'' Brisco said. ``It helps kids understand why school is relevant to life, and it helps some of them find an area in which they can be successful. ``For too many kids, school is a setting where they experience failure. If you put them in a setting where they tutor kids or help old folks, they become successful. Once you're successful in one phase of your life, you start doing better at other things like math and English. It's a contagion of success.'' Nationally, an early voice for bringing community service into the schools was Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. The foundation recommended in its 1983 report, High School, that service in the community or school be required by every student. ``Young people should be given opportunities to reach behond themselves and feel more responsibly engaged,'' Boyer testified in March 1989 before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. ``They should participate in the communities of which they are a part.'' Before its recess, Congress passed a $287 million national service bill to promote voluntary community service, both for youths and their elders. ``The call to service should come early, and it should be a vital part of education for citizenship in every school system in the nation,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., a sponsor of the Senate bill. The Bethlehem school board has issued a list of 95 local agencies where students can fulfill the requirement, including AIDS Outreach, the YMCA, the Special Olympics, the Girl Scouts, the Easter Seal Society, Meals on Wheels, the local public television station and a host of museums, hospitals and nursing homes. Also on the list is the school district itself, which wants volunteers to read to kindergarten children. The program applies only to the 900 members of the entering freshman classes at the city's two high schools, Liberty and Freedom. They have until June 1995 to fulfill the requirement of 60 hours, or about 15 minutes a week, on weekends or during the evenings. School officials insist they'll be flexible in deciding what constitutes community service, and say they might approve something like a student-organized carwash with the proceeds donated to a charity. Guidance counselors will oversee the program and studenss will be required to submit one-page reports on their service, how they made a contribution and what they gained from the experience. They'll receive half a credit toward their diplomas. ``The idea is to inculcate the value that there is something good about doing something of value for someone and not receiving pay for it,'' Faust said. Karen Ritter, vice president of Citizens Against Mandatory Service in Bethlehem, said her group believes in voluntary - but not mandatory - service. ``The whole thing is the mandatory issue,'' she said. ``Everyone who is involved in CAMS is a volunteer in one organization or another. My daughter worked with me in a soup kitchen. ``Bethlehem has a tradition of community service,'' Mrs. Ritter said. ``Hundreds of kids are already doing this service. They're doing it willingly because they want to do it. But once you mandate something, it's no longer volunteering.'' Supporters of mandatory service argue that an optional program would be like preaching to the choir in church. ``Schools require a lot of things that they think are important,'' Brisco said. ``They require English, math. When an individual district mandates service, it says this is something that we really value.''

DOC.HEAD: Dairy Industry Jittery as Milk Prices Head Down
DOC.TEXT: Milk prices paid to dairy farmers are going down, and the trend is sending some tremors through the industry. Strong milk prices since late last year generated substantial pressure for dairy expansion, but an Agriculture Department report says this momentum will ``collide with the effects of dramatically lower milk prices'' in the coming months. Total 1990 milk production is projected to be almost 148 billion pounds, up more than 2 percent from last year. It also would exceed the previous record output of 145.1 billion pounds in 1988. Despite the uncertainties, agency economists think 1991 milk production will rise again, perhaps by 1 percent to 2 percent to another record. Last week the USDA reported the October all-milk price average at $13.60 per 100 pounds, down from $14.20 in September and $14.80 in October 1989. The report by the department's Economic Research Service said that despite the downturn, overall milk prices in the October-December quarter ``still will be relatively favorable'' in relation to feed costs. Milk cow numbers in 1990 probably will average about the same as last year's 10.1 million head, the report said. ``Most dairy farmers probably will enter 1991 on a fairly sound financial footing,'' it said. The ratio of debt to assets has declined since the financial crunch of the mid-1980s, and economists said that will help some producers consider expanding their herds. ``On the other hand, producers generally have been conservative about taking on new debt in recent years,'' the report said. ``Although 1990 milk prices have been high, they have also been unpredictable, and the support price was much below market prices. Expansion plans may well be tempered with considerable caution.'' The 1990 farm bill sent to President Bush late last month freezes the government's basic milk price support at the current level of $10.10 per 100 pounds. But it also provides an assessment on producers if government purchases of surplus milk exceed 7 billion pounds. According to the report, the decline in milk prices will put pressure on profit margins as feed costs remain fairly constant. ``If milk prices fall as much as currently expected, returns over concentrate (feed) costs will fall about a fourth from 1990's near-record to the lowest level since 1978,'' the report said. The report added: ``This would be the largest proportional drop in returns over concentrate costs during the post-World War II years.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An Agriculture Department survey shows that most shippers of farm commodities would like more competition in setting ocean liner cargo rates. Martin F. ``Buzz'' Fitzpatrick Jr., head of the department's Office of Transportation, said most shippers want ``unrestricted ability'' to negotiate freight contracts with individual carriers. The Shipping Act of 1984 reguaates ocean carriers and grants them antitrust immunity to allow the carriers to form ``conferences,'' or cartels, to set cargo rates and apportion markets. ``Our surveys showed that many shippers would like the conference system eliminated,'' Fitzpatrick said. ``If conferences are not eliminated, most shippers advocate increased competition within the conference structure, through mandatory independent action on tariff rates and service contracts.'' A joint congressional and executive commission is preparing to review the impact of the 1984 law on maritime shipping to see if it should be retained, changed or eliminated, he said. The cost and quality of ocean liner service have a direct impact on the competitiveness of U.S. farm commodities, Fitzpatrick said. About $12 billion to $14 billion worth of products are shipped overseas on liner vessels each year, with a freight bill of $2 billion to $2.5 billion. Cooperating in the survey were the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association; National Forest Products Association; National Potato Council; Southeastern Peanut Association; and Washington State University. Copies of the survey report are available from: Office of Transportation, USDA, P.O. Box 96575, Washington, D.C. 20090. Or phone 202 245-5334. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Honey production in the top 10 countries is forecast to climb 3 percent this year to an estimated 750,500 metric tons, according to an Agriculture Department report. The Soviet Union leads the list with a 1990 estimate of 270,000 tons, up from 249,000 last year. China is second at 180,000 tons, down from 189,000 in 1989, the report showed. The United States, with 82,000 tons, compared with an output last year of 76,793 tons, is third.

DOC.HEAD: Any U.S. Attack Likely Will Start With Air Attacks in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: An American-led offensive to drive Iraq out of Kuwait probably would begin with nighttime air strikes inside Iraq to sever Saddam Hussein's links to his huge occupying army, military planners and private analysts say. Such a campaign, launched with the allied forces now arrayed against Iraq, would seek to exploit Iraq's weaknesses in air power and its apparent vulnerability in Kuwait to a seaborne assault and to naval bombardment from the Persian Gulf. President Bush has said repeatedly in recent days that he is growing impatient with Saddam's continuing occupation of Kuwait, though he has not decided to resort to military force. He has stressed, however, that force remains an active option and that he will not permit the Iraqi army to stay indefinitely in Kuwait. U.S. military officials won't discuss specific war plans, and they stress that Bush, for now at least, has not changed their mission: It remains the defense of Saudi Arabia and enforcement of United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq. ``Our training patterns have not changed in any manner'' to suggest preparations for an offensive campaign, an Army official said Friday. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Military officials' recent comments make it clear they are not enthusiastic about taking the offensive against Iraq any time soon. They would prefer to wait until more American and allied ground forces are in place in Saudi Arabia and more effort is made to find a peaceful solution. A major reason for the reluctance is Iraq's apparent success in fortifying its defensive positions in Kuwait, where at least 200,000 Iraqi troops are dug in. They are supported by an estimated 150,000 elite Republican Guard troops along key resupply lines between Kuwait's northeastern border and the Iraqi city of Basra. Iraq's defensive position in Kuwait is described by military officials as elaborate. It includes multiple layers of infantry and barriers such as mine fields, earthen mounds and anti-tank ditches. Behind these are mechanized units that can quickly reinforce the front-line infantry and cover its flanks. And behind these are mobile ``ready reserve'' units capable of counterattacking or blocking a move by Saudi-based ground forces to go around Kuwait. Iraq also has an estimated 50,000 troops along its southern border west of Kuwait. The Pentagon disclosed Friday that ``significant'' Iraqi forces also are deployed on the border with Turkey, but that no buildup has been detected on the Syrian border. If Bush ordered an attack any time soon, U.S. commanders in the field would have a wide array of firepower on which to draw, in combination with a variety of air, ground and naval forces deployed by Britain, France and about 20 other nations. About 240,000 U.S. forces are now in the Persian Gulf area, and allied forces total more than 100,000. The Pentagon said it plans to send as many as 100,000 more troops, but it would be several weeks before they get there and get ready. Joshua Epstein, a defense analyst at the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank, said there is little doubt that American forces now in Saudi Arabia could win a fight for Kuwait. The only doubt is whether the cost would be acceptable. ``You can do an offensive and you can win, but it won't be cheap,'' Epstein said, adding that estimates of probable American deaths range beyond 10,000. In the opening phase of a U.S.-led attack, the U.S. Air Force's radar-evading F-117 Stealth fighter bombers would play a key role, carrying out simultaneous attacks on important military targets inside Iraq. These targets probably would include command and communications centers that are vital to Iraq's ability to respond quickly and to coordinate a counteroffensive. In combination with air attacks, U.S. Marines would be expected to attempt a seaborne assault on Kuwait City. A contingent of about 11,000 Marines afloat in the gulf are specially trained in amphibious landings, forced entry and urban warfare. They currently are taking part in an amphibious landing exercise on a beach in Oman. About another 33,000 Marines are defending coastal routes in northeastern Saudi Arabia. Jack Merritt, a retired Army general and now president of the private Association of the U.S. Army, said a key to routing the Iraqis from Kuwait would be cutting them off from resupplies and from the Iraqi leadership in Baghdad. ``Psychology is on our side in this,'' he said, adding that ``The moment they feel they really have been cut off'' the Iraqi troops in Kuwait lose their resolve. In an actual invasion, the Marine amphibious assault force would reach the beaches at Kuwait City by landing craft, small boat or helicopter under the cover of an aerial assault from Harrier jump jet fighters and a naval barrage. Among the U.S. warships in the gulf is the USS Wisconsin armed with 16-guns and Tomahawk cruise missiles. Perhaps the costliest phase of a U.S.-led attack on Kuwait would be the Army's effort to oust the Iraqis from their hardened positions. The Pentagon estimates that Iraq has about 3,500 tanks, 2,200 infantry fighting vehicles and armored personnel carriers and 2,200 artillery pieces in Kuwait and southern Iraq. The United States has about 800 tanks in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: How the Election Will Affect Congressional Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Tuesday's elections will affect the next Congress beyond the marginal changes in the balance of power between the two parties. Within the small world of the Capitol, the nationwide balloting will be seen as a referendum on the Democratic and Republican congressional leaders. Whether he deserves it or not, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., will find his stature enhanced if the Democrats, as expected, take some seats away from the Republicans. In the Senate, where the Democrats now hold a 55-45 majority and little change is anticipated, the results will boost either Democratic leader George Mitchell of Maine or Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas, even if the lineup shifts by only a seat. The electoral glow - or pall - will in subtle ways color how the Democratic-controlled Congress deals with President Bush over the next two years. Less subtly, the changes could make it easier or harder for Congress to override the president's vetoes. Foley, Mitchell and Dole will adjust, adapt and survive the changes. There's no evidence that the outcome will shake them from their perches. That's not so in the ranks of the House Republicans. The House GOP is facing its 18th straight election without winning a majority. There's not a single House Republican remaining from when they last won the majority in 1952. Last year, their bitterness was turned toward Democratic Speaker Jim Wright of Texas, who was forced out of office following an ethics investigation. This year, they're shooting at each other. Rep. Don Sundquist, R-Tenn., is running to unseat Rep. Guy Vander Jagt, R-Mich., as chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. Vander Jagt has held the job since 1975, and Sundquist is counting on fellow Republicans to see another loss of seats as a sign that Vander Jagt should go. But is Vander Jagt is the real target? Not likely. Ambitious GOP members are setting up for 1992, when many expect House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., to retire after 12 years as leader. With the nationwide redistricting, Republicans will stand their best chance in a decade for a big gain in seats. That makes the NRCC a potentially great place to be, even if Vander Jagt has never managed to take advantage of it. The chairman of the committee gets to know all the potential new members in a very intimate and positive way - he hands them money for their campaigns. Mitchell is a former Democratic Senate campaign chairman, Dole a former Republican national chairman, and Michel a former NRCC chairman. ``It's an excellent springboard. You become the spear carrier and you also then get the spears. And they appreciate you for it,'' said former Rep. Tony Coelho of California, who vaulted from Democratic campaign chairman to House majority whip. So what is Sundquist's ultimate goal? Who is his ultimate target? He won't say. But he doesn't have to. Sundquist's quest was unveiled last week not by Sundquist, who intended to keep it quiet until after the election, not by Vander Jagt - but by the staff of House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich. Gingrich would be Michel's natural successor. But he was elected as the No. 2 Republican last year at least partly because of his long-term plans for wresting control of the House from the Democrats. A bad election result would be bad for Gingrich - unless he can blame it on someone else. The Gingrich-Vander Jagt strategy: Seed a public spectacle and then accuse Sundquist of hurting GOP election chances right before the elections. Let Sundquist take some of the blame for losses that many Republicans pin on Gingrich because he torpedoed President Bush's budget. ``Anything that distracts is doing a disservice to Republican chances this fall,'' said Vander Jagt, who went so far as to compare Sundquist with Saddam Hussein. Regardless of who eventually gets the blame, the Republican strife will make the Democrats look good in comparison, just as happened in the just-ended battle over the budget. Whether they deserve it or not. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: A State-By-State Survey of the Hottest Races
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 elections are a dream come true for political handicappers. There are 34 Senate races, 36 governor's contests and 435 U.S. House contests on Tuesday's ballot. Here is the outlook for the closest races, according to a state-by-state survey by The Associated Press: Alabama - Gov. Guy Hunt, the first Republican elected governor in the state this century, is bidding for a second term and narrowly leads Democrat Paul Hubbert. Alaska - As a Republican, Walter Hickel was Alaska's second governor. Now he's back, running as an independent and leading Republican Arliss Sturgulewski and Democrat Tony Knowles. Democratic incumbent Steve Cowper is not running. Arizona - Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard, a Democrat, leads GOP developer Fife Symington, but polls have him below the 50 percent he needs to avoid a runoff. Incumbent Rose Mofford, a Democrat, is retiring. California - The big race of 1990 is a megabuck contest for governor between Republican Sen. Pete Wilson and former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein. A lot of polling with not much agreement, but the latest surveys give a hairline edge to Wilson. The result might have to await a count of absentee ballots days after the polls close. Connecticut - Republican Lowell Weicker lost his Senate seat in 1988. Now he's running for governor as an independent and leading Republican John Rowland and Democrat Bruce Morrison. Florida - Another high-stakes contest for governor. Republican Bob Martinez was at the top of the Democrats' list of vulnerable incumbents. Democrats got another boost when former Sen. Lawton Chiles decided to challenge Martinez. Late polls said Chiles was leading, but it's close. Hawaii - This usually Democratic state gives the Republicans their best shot at picking up a Senate seat. Rep. Pat Saiki is running a strong race against Sen. Daniel Akaka, who was appointed to succeed the late Sen. Spark Matsunaga. Polls indicate the race is a tossup. Idaho - Republican Sen. James McClure is retiring and Rep. Larry Craig is favored to defeat Democrat Ron Twilegar in the Senate race. Illinois - Republican Jim Edgar and Democrat Neil Hartigan are running neck and neck to succeed GOP Gov. Jim Thompson. In the Senate race, Democrat Paul Simon holds a wide lead over Republican challenger Lynn Martin. Republicans had high hopes for this one, but Simon proved stronger than they thought. Iowa - Republican Gov. Terry Branstad is holding off Democratic challenger Don Avenson, who had strong support from abortion rights groups. Iowans don't tend to re-elect Democratic senators but Sen. Tom Harkin has a strong chance to break that tradition. GOP Rep. Tom Tauke is within reach of an upset but has been unable to catch Harkin in pre-election surveys. Kansas - GOP Gov. Mike Hayden looked like a sure loser to Democrat Joan Finney a month ago. But her hard line against abortion appears to have hurt her and Hayden had a narrow lead in the latest poll. Kentucky - Sen. Mitch McConnell has led in all pre-election polls over Democrat Harvey Sloane. But this is a strongly Democratic state and Sloane is given a chance for an upset. Maine - Former Democratic Gov. Joseph Brennan wants his old job back and is challenging his Republican successor, John McKernan. Brennan held an early lead, but the race now is a tossup. Massachusetts - Home of the voter rebellion. Outsider Democrat John Silber holds an uncertain lead over Republican William Weld in the race to succeed Gov. Michael Dukakis. Sen. John Kerry, fighting to avoid being swept away by the rage that toppled incumbents in the September primary, has opened a 20-point lead over Republican Jim Rappaport. They were tied in surveys taken right after the primary. Michigan - Gov. James Blanchard is shaking off a challenge from Republican John Engler. A new poll said Engler was leading by 14 points. Minnesota - Lake Wobegon gone berserk. Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich is viewed as potentially vulnerable to Republican Arne Carlson, who got onto the ballot only five days before Election Day. Carlson had lost the GOP gubernatorial nomination to Jon Grunseth, who was forced out of the race a week ago after allegations he swam nude with two teen-age girls and cheated on two wives. The fallout from the governor's race is considered a factor in the surprising vulnerability of incumbent GOP Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, who's in a dead heat with Democrat Paul Wellstone. A new poll said Boschwitz was pulling away. Nebraska - GOP Gov. Kay Orr once trailed Democrat Ben Nelson but is now even up. In the Senate race, Democratic incumbent James Exon appears to be pulling away from former Rep. Hal Daub. New Mexico - Former Gov. Bruce King, a Democrat, is leading Republican Frank Bond, but not by much. North Carolina - One of the most watched races in the country is the Senate battle between Helms and his Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte. Gantt has been ahead in the polls, but the contest has taken a nasty turn in the closing days. Ohio - One of the best Republican hopes for a gubernatorial pickup is this contest between Republican George Voinovich and Democrat Tony Celebrezze to succeed Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste. The race has tightened in the past two weeks. Oklahoma - Democrat David Walters leads Republican Bill Price in the race to succeed GOP Gov. Henry Bellmon. Oregon - Tight races for governor and Senate. Democrat Barbara Roberts holds a narrow lead over Republican Dave Frohnmayer in the race to succeed Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt. In the Senate race, incumbent Mark Hatfield was caught by surprise and is in a tight race with Democrat Harry Lonsdale. Rhode Island - The outlook is bleak for GOP Gov. Edward DiPrete, who trails Democrat Bruce Sundlun by 52 points. In the Senate race, Rep. Claudine Schneider's challenge to Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell appears to have fallen short. South Dakota - GOP Sen. Larry Pressler leads Democratic challenger Ted Muenster. Texas - Races don't get much nastier than this contest for governor between Republican Clayton Williams and Democrat Ann Richards. Williams once was far ahead, but the race suddenly closed to a dead heat a week ago. Now Richards is trying to exploit the disclosure that millionaire Williams paid no income taxes in 1986. Vermont - Former Gov. Richard Snelling once looked like a landslide winner in his bid to get his old job back. But Democrat Peter Welch has moved within striking distance.

DOC.HEAD: Key Redistricting Battleground States Reaping Outside Money
With PM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Political action committees financed by labor unions, teachers and other interests are pouring huge chunks of money into legislative races in about a dozen states that are battlegrounds for congressional redistricting. ``We are under siege like I have never seen,'' said Pennsylvania Senate President Robert Jubelirer. He and other Republicans are trying to fend off a Democratic offensive to take over the state's upper chamber. The stakes are high in Pennsylvania because state Democrats, should they pick up three seats and wrest the Senate from GOP control, could have absolute control in redrawing the state's congressional districts next year. Democratic Gov. Robert Casey is likely to roll to re-election and the Pennsylvania House is expected to stay Democratic. Similar shootouts are occurring in other states that stand to win or lose when 19 U.S. House seats change hands in 1991 because of population shifts detected by the 1990 Census. Eight states are expected to gain House seats and 13 to lose seats. In addition, political boundaries within every state will be redrawn, regardless of whether the states win or lose seats. The national Republican and Democratic parties have invested heavily in the states affected the most by redistricting. And each side is getting reinforcements from its allies, with labor backing the Democrats and business and conservative interests aiding the GOP. State legislative races and gubernatorial contests are crucial because those elected officials will control the highly political process of redrawing boundary lines for congressional and state legislative districts. Therefore, Tuesday's elections will determine whether Democrats or Republicans get to draw the districts or whether the two parties split the responsibility. By slicing up districts in either liberal or conservative precincts, politicians can help the election chances of either a Republican or Democrat. Legisatures draw up the lines. Governors are power brokers in the process, too, because a governor of one party affiliation, a Republican, for instance, could veto a plan drawn up by a Democratic legislature. Most of the 19 House seats expected to shift will move from the Democratic-tilting Northeast and Midwest to the more conservative South and West. California, Texas and Florida - the big prizes on everyone's list because they stand to gain as many as 14 congressional seats next year - have attracted huge contributions from out of state. Democrats in Illinois, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Ohio, which each stand to lose two congressional seats, are luring hefty contributions as well. ``Reapportionment has been on everybody's mind for a very long time in the labor movement,'' said Janice Lachance of the American Federation of Government Employees. Tom Heoffler of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said it is crucial for the GOP to hold its ground to keep the Democrats from taking total control in many states. ``We're looking at a situation here where it's vital for us to hang on to what we have just to be in a divided or split position,'' he said. Tim Dickson, executive director of the Democratic National Committee's redistricting arm, noted that efforts are just as important in states that stand to lose House seats. ``It's like musical chairs. The music's going to stop when this legislative session ends, and somebody's not going to have a seat,'' Dickson said. Democratic priorities, in addition to capturing the Pennsylvania Senate, include trying to reverse narrow GOP majorities in the senates of Michigan, Indiana, Ohio and New York. Republicans are trying to oust Democrats to gain control in the senates of Florida and Illinois. Florida is an especially important redistricting battleground because it also has a close governor's race. In California and Texas, the gubernatorial races are attracting the most attention because both have legislatures handily controlled by Democrats. Other legislative showdown states, although not necessarily key in the congressional redistricting changes, are Arizona, where Republicans hold a four-seat majority in the Senate; Colorado, where Democrats hope to make a stab at the GOP's 13-seat House margin; Idaho, where the GOP holds a four-seat edge in the Senate; Washington, where Republicans have a one-seat advantage in the Senate; and Oregon, where Democrats have just four House seats over the Republicans. In state legislatures that share redistricting powers with governors, Democrats had a big edge going into the election. They control both chambers in 29 states, while Republicans hold a lock on the statehouse in only four. Overall, there are more than 6,100 legislative seats at stake nationwide on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Voter Disenchantment Clouds House Races
With PM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Anxiety over the Persian Gulf, anger over new taxes and antipathy toward incumbents stirred up a crosswind that has Democrats and Republicans nervous about Tuesday's House elections. While Democrats are certain to maintain their lopsided majority, several candidates for re-election are in trouble because of the savings and loan debacle. And party officials have stopped talking of substantial gains. Republicans once hoped to cash in on President Bush's high popularity ratings. Now, with his poll standings in decline, they seem more resigned to mounting a rear-guard action to limit losses. Experts say there is little chance the Republicans will lose large numbers of seats. For all the volatility on the political landscape, no one expects a major power shakeup in the House, where the lineup going into this week's elections showed 258 Democrats, 175 Republicans and two vacancies. ``People are infuriated at `congressmen,' but they love theirs,'' said James David Barber, a Duke University political scientist. Former Cincinnati Mayor Kenneth Blackwell has a chance of becoming the first black Republican in the House since 1935, although he's in a tight race with Democratic Mayor Charles Luken. And in another contest of note, socialist Bernie Sanders, running as an independent, is in a tight race with Republican Rep. Peter Smith in Vermont. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri predicted Sunday the Democrats would pick up six or seven House seats. Ed Rollins, chairman of the House Republican campaign committee, said that if GOP voters shake off apathy and turn out at the polls, ``our losses will probably be held to a single digit. If Republicans are still turned off and don't vote ... the numbers will get higher.'' The House elections will for the most part hinge on 29 contests where there is no incumbent seeking re-election. Eleven of those seats were held by Democrats, 18 by Republicans. Democrats hope to pick up an open seat in Arkansas, where Rep. Tommy Robinson, who switched to the Republican Party while in the House, waged an unsuccessful campaign for governor this year. They're also hoping to pick up seats in Rhode Island, Hawaii, Iowa and Idaho, in districts vacated by Republicans seeking higher office. ``Unless there's a military action in the Middle East, the Republicans are going to be hurt because of the economy and taxes,'' said GOP consultant Tom Edmonds. ``The end result of this for Republicans is going to be poor.'' Said Democratic consultant Frank Greer: ``I don't think there's going to be big shifts, even though voter sentiments are strong out there. The real fruits of this budget debate (for Democrats) might not be felt until 1992.'' In the last full week of the campaign, Democrats charged that Bush used political appearances to launch daily broadsides against Iraq's Saddam Hussein in an attempt to divert attention from popular unrest over the tax hikes. But the president denied that, saying, ``I'll repeat it today, I'll repeat it tomorrow and I'll repeat it the next day.'' Against the backdrop of new, tougher talk on the Persian Gulf, more problems in the thrift industry and public backlash over the slowing economy and heavier taxation, about 20 incumbents will be particularly vulnerable on Election Day: -Democrat Frank Annunzio of Illinois and Republicans Denny Smith of Oregon and Charles Pashayan of California are in trouble because they have been linked to the savings and loan failures. Annunzio is chairman of the House Administration Committee. -The re-election campaign of Rep. Arlan Stangeland of Minnesota has been threatened by disclosures that the incumbent charged hundreds of long-distance calls to a woman friend on his House credit card. The woman was the office manager of a lobbying firm. -Several of the vulnerable incumbents are freshmen, including Rep. Ben Jones, D-Ga.; Peter Hoagland, D-Neb.; Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash.; George Sangmeister, D-Ill.; Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas; Greg Laughlin, D-Texas; Craig James, R-Fla.; Ron Machtley, R-R.I., and Smith in Vermont. -Two incumbents in Maryland and Virginia are in some trouble. Rep. Roy Dyson, D-Md., has run into controversy about his conscientious objector status during the Vietnam war. Dyson sits on the House Armed Services Committee and talks tough on military issues. In Virginia, Republican Stan Parris said he supported Bush's veto of a civil rights bill because ``it is worse to discriminate against majorities'' than against racial minorities.

DOC.HEAD: Senators With Eye on White House Need Strong Re-Election Showings
With PM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Senate incumbents toying with the idea of a future presidential bid will be expected to turn in a strongpperformance Tuesday - or spend the next two years wondering about the consequences. ``Any re-election of a presidential hopeful under 60 percent is a dangerous sign,'' said Larry Sabato, a political science professor at the University of Virginia. The 34 Senate races featured on Tuesday's ballot include several senators just struggling to stay in office. Those considered most vulnerable are Republicans Jesse Helms in North Carolina, Mark Hatfield in Oregon and Rudy Boschwitz in Minnesota and Democrat Daniel Akaka in Hawaii. But would-be future presidents need to do much better than just survive. They must produce a solid performance in a climate of anti-government attitudes and typical voter apathy in an off-year election. No Democrat has announced a '92 run for the White House, but those most often mentioned are Sens. Sam Nunn of Georgia, Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and New Jersey's Bill Bradley. Republicans thought to harbor presidential ambitions include Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas. All face little or no opposition in their re-election bids on Tuesday. Bradley is expected to defeat Republican Christine Todd Whitman easily, but he may not do so with 60 percent of the vote. He may feel some of the anger the state's electorate feels toward Democratic Gov. James Florio. The backlash against Florio for raising taxes after his election last year has prompted cries for impeachment in some quarters and general anger in others. A poll released over the weekend showed Bradley favored by 55 percent of likely voters and Whitman supported by 27 percent with 12 percent undecided. Nunn will have no difficulty in topping 60 percent: He's unopposed in his bid for a fourth term. In 1984, the Georgia senator manhandled his general election opponent, Jon Michael Hicks, 80 percent to 20 percent. Gore, who ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination in 1988, faces three challengers in his attempt to return to the Senate for a second term. But neither Republican William Hawkins nor two independent candidates has generated much interest. Gore is expected to win handily, but high percentages are key. ``Candidates in the Democratic Party have to have vast appeal in the South,'' said James Thurber, director of the Center for Congressional and Presidential Studies at American University. ``In the South, a higher percentage shows you're a winner,'' he said. The lone exception to the 60 percent rule - essential for Southern incumbents - is Texas. A finish in the upper 50 percent range is ``perfectly acceptable,'' Sabato said, because the state's electorate can be tough on its candidates. In 1988, Texas Democratic Sen. Lloyd Bentsen finished with 59 percent of the vote to 40 percent for his opponent, Beau Boulter. Gramm, who's expected to win easily in his re-election bid, captured 59 percent of the vote in 1984. Aside from concerns about strong showings in off-year elections, candidates sometimes have to contend with political ghosts. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., was forced out of the presidential race in 1988 when charges of plagiarism surfaced. He has seen those accusations resurrected in this year's election but is heavily favored to win a fourth term over Republican M. Jane Brady. Because no candidate has declared presidential intentions for 1992, the attention also is focused on gubernatorial incumbents. At least one analyst contends that those races - not the Senate contests - are the ones to watch. ``The (Senate) election is not going to determine electoral prowess. It's a non-starter,'' said Tom Mann of the Brookings Institution, a private research group. Although Mann says the contest in New York for governor is a non-race, he suggests keeping a close eye on how Democrat Mario Cuomo wins and then handles the state's economic problems. Cuomo was considered a presidential contender in 1988 and his name has been mentioned for '92. Mann also will be keeping an eye on Arkansas, where Democratic Gov. Bill Clinton is strongly favored for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0431, inserts Bjt designator.
The Kid Constituency: Don't Underestimate the Power of the Polls
DOC.TEXT: Youngsters in Arizona don't have to wait until they're 18 to vote. They can go to the polls in kindergarten. The ``Kids Voting'' program, designed to improve the way Americans vote, believes in starting young. ``It's thrilling because it lets kids vote on things adults do,'' says 9-year-old Stephanie Schwartz, who adds that she'll probably vote for the rest of her life. Alyssa Martin, 16, said participating in the program has made her more aware of political issues. ``Now I read the newspaper about the candidates and I want to know more,'' she said. Kids Voting began in 1988 as a pilot program taking in parts of six school districts; 30,000 children voted. Two years later, the program has grown to include about 200 school districts around the state. More than 600,000 youngsters are eligible to vote. Voting booths for children in grades kindergarten through 12 will be set up at 1,797 of the state's nearly 2,000 precincts for Tuesday's general election. Pupils vote with a special ballot in booths alongside the regular voting booths at adult polling places. The results, which will be tabulated by a private computer company, are expected to be available on Wednesday. Marilyn Hawker, Kids Voting president and executive director, said voter turnout in the 65 precincts in which children voted two years ago was 3 percent higher than state and county election turnouts. She expects the program to increase voter turnout throughout the state this year by 5 percent. Laurie Delaney, a social studies teacher in Mesa, said some of her students said their parents registered to vote for the first time after the students became involved in Kids Voting. The ballot issues that the youngsters will vote on include statewide offices, propositions and legislative races, plus some student-related issues not on the adult ballots, such as linking driving privileges with regular school attendance. In another effort to deal with civic illiteracy, millions of junior and senior high school students and their parents voted in a nationwide mock election last Thursday. They cast ballots on individual state races as well as on general issues involving drugs and defense. The idea for Arizona's Kids Voting program came during a 1987 fishing trip to Costa Rica, where the voter turnout reaches over 90 percent. Bob Evans, chairman of the Kids Voting board of directors, and several others made a forced airplane landing in a village in the small Central American country. They met a taxi driver who told them of a childhood of voting alongside his parents in simulated elections. Evans hopes the idea will overcome voter apathy. According to federal statistics, 50 percent of eligible citizens don't vote in presidential elections and 70 percent don't vote in local elections. Arizona ranked 36th in the nation in voter turnout in 1988. ``Voter apathy is the worst disease that we have within our own particular democracy and it has been a creeping disease over the last 75 years,'' Evans said. ``We're hardly a government by the people any more because there are so few people participating.'' The program already has affected the governor's race between Democrat Terry Goddard and Republican Fife Symington, both of whom participated in a televised Kids Voting program. Goddard later issued a statement to clarify his position after learning he appeared to be losing ground among the youthful voters over his comments on year-round school, one of the student-related issues on which Kids Voting participants will cast ballots. Goddard said during the broadcast that the United States might have to adopt an intensive program such as that used in Japanese schools. In his later statement, he said he didn't advocate keeping students in school year-round but would like to see the facilities have greater use. The Kids Voting program is expected to cost about $600,000, with 95 percent of the funding coming from private corporations, primarily Arizona Public Service Co., Ms. Hawker said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Go - Even Though Law Says It's Time to Quit
DOC.TEXT: Illinois law calls for mandatory retirement of judges after they turn 75, but 76-year-old William S. White has other ideas. ``I refuse to be mandatorily retired,'' says the appellate judge in Cook County. ``I view it as a violation of federal laws against discrimination on account of age.'' White wrote to the Secretary of State's office to inform them of his intentions, and the state Board of Elections certified him to run for re-election. ``I'm having my credentials reviewed by the public,'' White said. ``They're the people who hired me, and they are the people who should decide if I'm too old.'' Meanwhile, John P. Tully, a Democratic circuit judge, and Lester A. Bonaguro, a Republican circuit judge, are listed on the ballot for a seat that might not be open. Because the question of White's retirement couldn't be settled in time, officials decided all the candidates would be on the ballot and the issue would be settled later. If 60 percent of voters say White should be retained, the courts will have to decide whether he - or the winner of the Tully-Bonaguro race - will get the seat, Board of Elections attorneys say.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Weicker Holding Lead in Gubernatorial Race
DOC.TEXT: Former GOP Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who is running an independent campaign to be Connecticut's next governor, holds a solid lead over two rivals, according to a poll published Sunday. But one out of every three voters still is undecided, according to The Hartford Courant-Connecticut Poll of 729 people. The survey showed Weicker favored by 34 percent, Republican Rep. John G. Rowland favored by 23 percent, Democrat Bruce A. Morrison favored by 10 percent, and 34 percent undecided. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points. When undecided voters were pressed to choose a candidate, Weicker's support grew to 42 percent, Rowland's grew to 29 percent, and Morrison's to 15 percent, with 14 percent still undecided. The poll, taken by telephone from Oct. 29 to Nov. 2, surveyed people who said they certain to vote Tuesday. Weicker seemed happy with the poll results, but reminded reporters that he learned to distrust polls when he narrowly lost his Senate seat in 1988 to Democrat Joseph Lieberman. ``Let's face it - I couldn't ask for more,'' he said. ``But I'll be honest with you. After the last election, I don't put much stock in polls.''
DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Blasts Democratic Party Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial nominee Theo Mitchell says party leaders ``tucked their tails and ran'' from his underdog campaign to defeat Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell. ``I was criticized because I didn't ask permission to get into it from the so-called leaders of the Democratic Party, to lick their boots so I could run,'' Mitchell said. The state senator, bidding to become the nation's second elected black governor, said he told party leaders he was going to run ``since no one else had the guts.'' Mitchell told The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer in an interview published Sunday that some Democrats have tried to sabotage his campaign. Carol Khare, a Democratic National Committee member from South Carolina, says Mitchell spurned offers of help from politically experienced party members after he won the nomination. ``Party leaders who thought Theo didn't have much chance to win still wanted him to do well, both as the party's nominee and as a representative of blacks,'' Khare said. ``The Democratic leadership wanted to help more than they were allowed to help.'' Mitchell denies that he refused to ask for help or heed advice. Democratic activists say Mitchell has failed even to mobilize his prime constituency and ensure a large black turnout. ``He doesn't have an organization that can turn out people,'' said Oscar Butler, dean of students at South Carolina State College and a longtime Democratic activist.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Radicals Hope To Rain on Communists' Parade
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In years past, Kremlinologists seeking clues to Soviet politics scrutinized the lineup of leaders atop Lenin's mausoleum during the Revolution Day parade through Red Square. During this Wednesday's celebration of the Communist holiday, those wanting to know the political currents will look instead to the counterdemonstrations in Moscow's streets. For the first time in the 73-year history of the day marking the revolution that brought Bolsheviks to power in Russia, alternative demonstrations have been officially sanctioned in the capital. About 5,000 people marched in an unofficial protest on Revolution Day last year. This year's alternative demonstration has the blessing of the Moscow City Council, where radicals won seats last spring. Sunday's editions of Moskovskaya Pravda, the capital's Communist Party newspaper, stated joyfully, ``Today we may firmly declare that the celebration of the anniversary ... will go on as usual.'' The celebration will go on, but it won't be a ``usual'' Revolution Day. While the Communist Party puts on its grand show praising the 1917 uprising and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies of perestroika, protesters elsewhere in the city will be denouncing the ``coup'' engineered by Vladimir Lenin and mourning those killed during seven decades of repression. Demonstrators chose a symbolic route for their march: starting at the Communist Party's Central Committee headquarters at the Old Square, past a monument to Stalin's victims, and ending at the house where the late human rights activist Andrei Sakharov lived. ``Our main slogan is, `From a totalitarian regime, to democracy and humanism,' and we want to display this slogan to the whole world,'' said Lev Shemayev of the Moscow Voters' Association, which has organized anti-communist rallies this year. In outlining the plans at a news conference last week, he emphasized that one target of the protest would be Gorbachev. ``It is clear that everything stems from the walls of the Old Square, where the president has his study,'' he said, referring to Gorbachev's office as chief of the Communist Party. Another group of protesters, led by radical deputies of the national and Russian parliaments, plan to march through Red Square carrying signs demanding the resignation of Gorbachev, Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov and others. This march is scheduled to occur long after Communist Party supporters and military hardware have paraded over the cobblestones of Red Square. Gorbachev and the rest of the Soviet leadership will have left their reviewing stand atop the mausoleum. Radical leaders such as Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov and Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak initially urged that no festivities be held, saying the communist system has been so destructive there is nothing to celebrate. Many of the 15 republics, including the Baltics, voted to ban traditional parades. Gorbachev, however, ordered the parades to go on in major cities, and the national parliament echoed his sentiments. Moskovskaya Pravda has been printing letters from party members, war veterans and others in support of celebrating ``the glorious date.'' A group of Moscow war veterans criticized those who would cancel the festivities, saying ``the attempts to deprive the Soviet people of their national holiday are blasphemous.'' Newspapers have reported on efforts to swell the ranks of the pro-Communist Party parade, with Soviet army officers ordering soldiers to march in street clothes, and military-affiliated schools compelling students to fall in step. With the official parade still on, some radicals felt that to do nothing ``would be a political mistake because it will play into the hands of the party,'' and give the impression that all Soviet people support the Communists, Shemayev said. Not all the radicals agree. Popov said last week: ``I am not going to march in any demonstrations, although I will attend the official state ceremonies related to Nov. 7.'' The national parliament had urged that alternative demonstrations not be held, but opposition groups decided to defy the lawmakers and the City Council approved. Lev Ponomarov, a radical deputy to the Russian Republic's parliament, sounded defensive Friday in announcing protest plans. ``It is not us who initiates these demonstrations. ... We are forced to participate ... because we want to express a different viewpoint,'' he said. Shemayev stressed that the ``national reconciliation'' of Communists and non-Communists was another principal theme of the day. ``We must emphasize the main philosophy that we are all now within the confines of the barbed wire of the Soviet Union,'' he said, ``and we are all countrymen, whether we like or loathe each other.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Don't Want War, But Are Resigned to It
DOC.TEXT: King Abdel-Aziz won his desert realm by the sword, but his heirs have favored diplomacy over violence for decades. Now they are resigning themselves to the possibility of war with Iraq. ``If there's no peace, I'd rather have war than have Saddam Hussein threatening myself and my children,'' said a Saudi sheik who lived through Riyadh's transformation from backwater to glittering metropolis. Recounting the rags-to-riches story of his generation, the middle-aged sheik-businessman said ``nobody wants war'' but everyone is becoming resigned to it. Few signs of impending war are evident in this city of superhighways, but posters telling what do in an air raid can be found at traffic intersections among the modern buildings, myriad princely palaces and shiny mosques. Stay at home, they urge. Use minimum lighting. Place yourself in a corner or go underground if you have a basement. Listen carefully to radio or television. Be calm and behave wisely. Abdel-Aziz bin Abdel-Rahman al Saud, after years of exile in Kuwait, stormed out of the desert in 1902 with a few hand-picked companions and took the fort at Riyadh in a daring dawn raid. Within two decades, he controlled most of the Arabian Peninsula. His victory was so complete that war on their own soil is something only very old Saudis can remember, and only dimly. Out at Diriyah oasis, where the ultra-conservative Islamic sect known as the Wahabis joined forces with Abdel-Aziz's ancestors to plan an earlier conquest of Arabia in the 18th century, cats slink across empty streets as the sun sets over the desert. Behind a dense palm grove are the big-walled compounds where some of the wives of senior princes live. Al-Turaif Citadel, a mud-brick fort that guarded the entrance to the oasis, is being restored as a historic monument. Modern-day Saudis live in the sprawl of Riyadh, the capital, which is laid out in a grid pattern across the flat desert. They seldom visit the citadel, a relic of the warrior past. A Jordanian businessman, who like the saudi sheik spoke on condition of anonymity, told of noticing fear in many Saudis immediately after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Over the past 20 years, the people have been living in luxury,'' he said. ``All of a sudden, they were in a war mood. ``They're very afraid of Saddam. They have seen the Kuwaitis coming here, sleeping in schools, five to a room. They're worried it could happen to them.'' ``In the early days of the crisis, they packed their houses with food, water and so on,'' the Jordanian said, but now they are more relaxed and ``there's no such mood.'' Whatever the people's private fears, their ruler insists that, through diplomacy or war, Saddam be driven out of Kuwait. King Fahd bin Abdel-Aziz, the current successor of Abdel-Aziz, is one of his more than 30 sons. Fahd also is known as Custodian of the Two Holy Shrines, Mecca and Medina. In public statements, Fahd has demanded unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait and ruled out any compromise that would leave parts of the tiny emirate under Iraq control. Saudi Arabia, which has been reluctant to thrust itself onto the Arab or international scene, is assuming a greater role now and seems less willing to compromise with its neighbors. When King Hussein of Jordan refused wholehearted backing of anti-Iraqi measures, the kingdom criticized him severely and, for a time, closed the border to commercial traffic. When Yemen gave partial support to Saddam, the Saudis expelled hundreds of thousands of Yemeni workers, many of whom had been in the kingdom 30 years or more. A Western diplomat said the new policy was: ``No more Mr. Nice Guy. No more throwing of money at problems until they go away.'' Among the Saudi middle class, he said, there is a ``growing debate about, `Is it worth going to war?' Also, if you go after Saddam, does he have to be personally eliminated or could he just be defanged?'' The sheik-businessman said: ``If there is a war, the impact will last many years. The Americans, the British will stay for a while, then they'll leave, but the Iraqis will be there forever.'' He said there was only one good solution: ``We wake up tomorrow and Saddam Hussein has had a heart attack and been toppled by someone less dangerous.''

DOC.HEAD: In this Corner: Jesse `The Body' Ventura a Contender in Mayor-Mania
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: Jesse ``The Body'' Ventura was in an ugly mood. ``Politics is dirtier than pro wrestling,'' he fumed, and he ought to know. The candidate for mayor of this Minneapolis suburb is a retired pro wrestler. What ticked him off one week before the election was a political body slam -or maybe it was a headlock - from a state lawmaker. Rep. Linda Scheid wrote a letter to the community newspaper publicizing excerpts from Ventura's interview with Penthouse magazine last year and accusing the candidate of insulting women and of being a bad role model. The lean and chiseled, 6-foot-4 candidate was outraged. Politics is ``dirtier than anything,'' Ventura said. ``I mean, including wheeling and dealing in Hollywood. They're even more honest than politics is.'' Retired from the ring since 1986, Ventura, 39, is trying to unseat 18-year Mayor Jim Krautkremer in this bedroom community of 50,000. Ventura, who wore a goatee, earrings and feather boas during his wrestling days but now dresses more sedately and is cleanshaven and graying about the temples, had feared character attacks during the campaign. But he said the worse he had been called publicly before Scheid's letter was a ``bit-part actor.'' He appeared in two films with Arnold Schwarzenegger, ``Predator'' and ``The Running Man,'' appeared in other films and did a never-aired ABC pilot, ``Tag Team.'' He also is color commentator for football's Tampa Bay Buccaneers. In the interview in Penthouse's March 1989 issue, Ventura said, ``I just want to be the actor who, when a scene's done, heads back to his air-conditioned trailer, picks up a Penthouse, looks at the pictures, and maybe even reads the articles.'' On why he chose the villainous role of ``The Body'' as a wrestler: ``I identify with that role perfectly, because I am eccentric and I am a maniac.'' Scheid recommended in her letter that Ventura ``pick up some sensitivity handbooks.'' ``Sorry, Jesse Ventura, but our city doesn't need a mayor who flaunts an image of macho indifference to half of our population,'' she wrote. Ventura got involved in politics when the city proposed real estate development in a marsh near his house. He and his neighbors wanted to save the wetland. He is campaigning for slow-growth development, expanded recycling and a two-term limit for city officials. His campaign slogan? ``If you've had enough and you're mad enough ...'' The two candidates have never debated. The race for the four-year office has been waged mostly through yard signs. ``He has never been involved in our community except for that neighborhood thing,'' said Krautkremer, who advocates more aggressive development. ``He doesn't realize the commitment he's making.'' Still, he acknowledged Ventura could be a threat. ``He's been doing this for a year and a half and I don't have the ability to come up with these one-liners that he does,'' Krautkremer said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor will sell a van Gogh painting that could bring her nearly $20 million, Christie's auction house says. The painting cost about $257,000 when the actress' art dealer father bought it on her behalf in 1963. The painting, ``A View of the Asylum and Chapel at Saint-Remy,'' was done in 1889. It depicts the asylum the artist entered after cutting off part of his ear. Van Gogh killed himself the following year. When Miss Taylor was married to actor Richard Burton, the painting hung in the couple's home in Gstaad, Switzerland, and in the salon of their yacht. The painting will be sold at auction Dec. 3 in London, Christie's said Sunday. --- SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - Britain's Duchess of York toured a children's hospital today on the first official engagement of a four-day visit to Australia. The wife of Prince Andrew was invited to Australia by the Royal Flying Doctor Service, which brings medical supplies and care to the country's outback. The duchess stopped to talk with dozens of children, speaking in French at one point to a 6-year-old girl. She will travel to Melbourne on Tuesday for the Melbourne Cup horse race, Australia's biggest turf event, and leave the country Thursday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - It took six albums over 12 years, but country singer Carlene Carter is finally making it big like the rest of her famous family. ``I always thought it would work out,'' Carter, 35, said in the Nov. 12 issue of People magazine. ``But I didn't think it would work out so late in life.'' Carter is the daughter of June Carter Cash and '50s Nashville crooner Carl Smith. But not even her stepdad - Johnny Cash - or her third husband - British rocker Nick Lowe - could jumpstart a career that saw her first five albums go nowhere. Now she's back to country music and has a No. 1 hit, ``I Fell in Love,'' and a Top 20 album of the same name. ``There was a period where I was a little scared that I'd blown my chance,'' she said. ``But I think everything that I did, every step I took, every wrong turn led to this.'' Johnny Cash's daughter, Roseanne Cash, is also a popular country performer. --- NEW YORK (AP) - ngie Dickinson says she and her two sisters were never close while trying to survive life in North Dakota with an alcoholic father. But all that has changed for the 59-year-old actress now that she's taking care of her sister Mary Lou, 61, who has Alzheimer's disease. ``I'd made my own diagnosis of Alzheimer's. I'm a news junkie and I read a lot of medical stories,'' Dickinson said in the Nov. 12 issue of People magazine. ``In 1986 I told Mary Lou that I thought she might have Alzheimer's. I hope I didn't frighten her.'' The Los Angeles-based actress oversees the care required by Mary Lou, who has lost the ability to bathe, dress and feed herself. Dickinson also has persuaded her sister's three adult children to enroll in support groups for families of Alzheimer's victims. And she takes her to movies and baseball games even though ``I know she can't see the ball or the batter.'' ``But she enjoys the ambience, being there with me,'' the actress said. ``It's all very momentary, but the moments are worthwhile.''

DOC.HEAD: Paroles on the Rise as Prisons Move to Ease Crowding
DOC.TEXT: An increase in the number of convicts paroled last year reflects efforts by the criminal justice system to make room for a similar rise in individuals sent to prison, authorities say. The number of parolees increased 12.1 percent to 457,797, coupled with a 5.6 percent rise in defendants on probation to a total of 2.52 million, according to a fresh study from the Justice Department. Authorities were unanimous in saying states have used parole to reduce overcrowding, particularly when courts have set caps on the number of inmates that can be housed in particular prisons. Georgia led the nation with a 54.2 percent increase in paroles in 1989. The state's parole board releases non-violent offenders to avoid prison overcrowding and lawsuits, spokesman Mike Fleming said. The rise in paroles ``is simply a reflection of the board's attempt to maintain the level of the prison population in the state of Georgia,'' Fleming said. ``We're trying to keep it at capacity or less so that we don't get into federal lawsuits or federal control.'' In Oregon, paroles climbed 52.9 percent last year, followed by increases of 37.1 percent in Kansas, 37 percent in Oklahoma and 28.8 percent in Michigan. The Justice Department found that three-quarters of the 4.1 million adults under the authority of correctional, parole or probation officials last year were living in the community rather than behind bars. With more prison admissions, state officials have to find a way to release inmates to make more space for newly convicted inmates. The 13 percent growth in the nation's prison population last year tracks the 12.1 percent increase in parolees, said Lawrence A. Greenfeld, who supervised the study for the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. ``It's been that way for quite some time,'' Greenfeld said. ``All of these components of corrections are growing more or less at similar rates.'' Prison and jail populations since 1980 have increased 114 percent, while the number of those on parole went up 107 percent, he said. The number of individuals placed on probation increased 126 percent, he said. According to criminologist Norval Morris, the latest parole figures ``are descriptive of a system in chaos.'' Wide use of mandatory sentences for drug offenses and other crimes has strained prisons and forced parole boards to release more inmates, the University of Chicago scholar said. ``When you put a cap on facilities and fill them up with street-level drug dealers and users, you've got to do something,'' he said. ``Overcrowding doesn't produce more severity, it just produces more random severity and random leniency,'' said Morris. He recently co-authored a book, ``Between Prison and Probation,'' that urges alternatives to incarceration. Texas had the largest number of parolees last year - 91,294- followed by 57,508 in California. Pennsylvania ranked third with 47,702. New York had 36,685. Rhode Island had a 24.5 percent jump in the number of probationers, followed by increases of 16.7 percent in Oregon and a 16.3 percent increase in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, a Nation and a World Transformed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AM report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FRA7 of Oct. 31
DOC.TEXT: The opening of the Berlin Wall did far more than allow East Germans to dance across broken concrete into the dazzling world outside. It let the outside world come in. Less than a year later, two nations were wiped off the map and replaced with one. Breaching the barrier was a desperate act by a dying regime trying to placate a people massed in revolt. Although the opening of the wall Nov. 9, 1989, took the unromantic form of lifting travel restrictions, everyone recognized it as the end of the Cold War's most famous symbol. It was the dominant image in a breathtaking year of revolution in the Soviet bloc. What no one predicted was the resulting maelstrom of forces that led to German unity, an inexorable process that forced the superpowers to recognize a new world order and reach new levels of cooperation. Today, the nation that built the Berlin Wall is a territory transformed, no longer a Communist state, no longer a closed society, no longer a nation. It is a region whose destiny lies completely in the hands of people who live in what used to be another country. Uniting with mighty West Germany has given the East Germans an experienced hand to lead them and a mattress stuffed with money to rest on. But it also has forced the old nation to make Eastern Europe's fastest, most turbulent, most radical transition to a free-market democracy after four decades of sleepy, unchanging communism. Poland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and Hungary are proceeding much more gently, by comparison dipping a toe into the cold waters of capitalism as they peer through the dust and smoke of their revolutions. So swiftly has East Germany become distinct from its neighbors that ``it is inaccurate and unfair to even compare them,'' said Heinrich Vogel, an analyst at the Federal Institute for Eastern Economic and International Studies in Cologne. He said eastern Germany is in ``a distinctly privileged situation,'' sharing a language, legal system, government, currency and borders with a rich and stable region. East Germany also has thrown its fate to the West, however, while the other former Soviet satellites still have autonomy and some control of their destiny on the longer, less certain road to prosperity. What eastern Germany has in common with the other former Communist states are profound similarities in public mood. ``They are all sharing exaggerated expectations to a large extent,'' Vogel said. ``They have all inherited the structural handicaps, the mental decay, the system of mistrusting each other and society.'' In eastern Germany, Westerners have seized control swiftly, from the man in charge of selling its factories to the governor of its largest state to clever squatters who have claimed its vacant tenements. Leading eastern politicians have western campaign managers and aides. The East German women's swimming team, which dominated the world for years, has a West German coach. Children who have been drilled their entire classroom lives in the correctness of communism are using western textbooks. The food in the old nation's stores, the cars on its streets, the money in its banks and the flag flown atop its public buildings - all have changed in th single year from revolution to reunifiction. Political extremism, overt racism, crime and drug abuse have crept through the wall or simmered up from the darkest corners of a long-suppressed national psyche. Embracing the West has ruined the homegrown economy and its overstaffed, inefficient enterprises, which once were the strongest of the Soviet bloc but now are literally being killed by the competition. Since March, about one-fourth of the 8 million workers in eastern Germany have lost their jobs or are working fewer hours at lower, government-subsidized wages. A recent report by the five leading German economic institutes said nearly 4 million could be in the same situation next year, and that the pace of recovery was much slower than expected. Except for some perky areas of the service industry, virtually no sector of the eastern economy can survive without western help, said economist Heine Flassbeck of Berlin, one of the report's authors. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, facing national elections Dec. 2, has dismissed the report as too pessimistic. Hans Peter Stihl, president of the German Chamber of Commerce, said a new survey showed half of all western German businesses will have invested in the east by the end of 1991. If there is disagreement over the timetable for eastern Germany's elevation to western standards, there is little doubt about its inevitability. On a single day soon after the Germanys were joined Oct. 3, three unrelated announcements illustrated why East Germany was more fortunate than its old Warsaw Pact allies: -Mercedes-Benz said it would begin building cars at a struggling East German truck plant near Berlin, saving or creating 6,000 jobs. -The government increased pensions to help 2.7 million retired people pay higher prices and rents. -Another department announced plans to spend 10 billion marks ($6.5 billion) on fixing up 300,000 homes. Romania, Poland and the other former Communist states could use a day like that, but many of citizens have decided not to wait for it. Thousands of Eastern Europeans have poured into eastern Germany in hopes it will be the new gateway to the West, creating a German immigration crisis. Soviet soldiers, who once died by the millions fighting the Nazis and now must leave the nation they conquered, are deserting in hundreds and asking to stay. Even Jews, subjected to hideous crimes under Hitler, are arriving from the Soviet Union in search of better lives. All this in a country millions of people could not wait to leave last year, where pent-up desperation brought down the hard-line Communist leader, Erich Honecker. The uprising forced his successor, Egon Krenz, to bow even more to the masses and do the unbelievable: change history in a single autumn day by opening the Berlin Wall.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Country Split Over Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: This is Jesse Helms country, a mostly white, blue-collar town, population 23,000. In 1984, Salisbury and other small communities helped carry the Republican senator to a narrow victory over the state's popular former governor, James Hunt, in an expensive and brutal campaign. This year, Helms is counting on Salisbury again as he takes on Harvey Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte and the nation's first black Democratic Senate nominee this century. Statewide polls released over the weekend disagree on which candidate is leading, but all say the race is so close that the undecided vote will determine the victor. Eva O'Grady of Salisbury said she's concerned about Gantt's big-city connections, but she's also pro-choice and opposes Helms' stand against abortion. ``I'm totally pro-choice and that may sway me,'' she said. ``I change my mind everyday.'' This has been another nasty election, with Helms attacking his opponent's liberal record and Gantt charging the Republican with playing on racial fears. Democrats on Sunday accused Republicans of racism during the campaign, and a federal judge scheduled an election-eve hearing on whether the GOP's voter mailings are intimidating voters. Salisbury, in central North Carolina, is 79 percent white and 20 percent black. Textiles are the primary industry. ``I don't really like the way either one of them's running their campaign - all the mudslinging,'' said Donald Camp, 43, of Spencer, a town outside of Salisbury. Camp said he'll vote for Gantt because he has never liked Helms. Race is definitely not an issue among Salisbury voters, O'Grady said. If anything, Gantt's appearance gives him an advantage, she said. ``He's more charismatic, charming, upscale, yuppie,'' she said. But Jim Beck, 54, of Salisbury, said race is a factor because Gantt has made it one. ``He's definitely for the racism,'' he said, accusing Gantt of supporting blacks over whites. He said he would vote for Helms for one reason - his 18 years in office. ``He's got experience, and experience is the main thing,'' Beck said. Camp, Beck and O'Grady are white. Two students at Livingstone College, a predominantly black school in Salisbury, said they believed most voters are concerned with issues such as education and the environment rather than race. ``I don't think race has too much to do with it, but I think it's an influence,'' said Janet Ferguson, 23. Her friend, Angie Ballard, 23, described Helms as a ``flop'' on education. But she said she believed some voters would refuse to listen to Gantt because he's black. ``The racial thing seems to be coming back in 1990,'' Ms. Ballard said. Patricia Smith, who is 36 and black, said of the Democrat's chances, ``I think it's possible he might win. A lot of things he's for other people are for.''
