DOC.HEAD: In Final Push, Silber Attacks, Weld Questions His Temperament
DOC.TEXT: With polls showing the governor's race tightening, Democrat John Silber is slugging as hard as ever. Republican William Weld thinks his opponent is in danger of knocking himself out. In a string of local and national TV appearances, the hard-bitten Silber denounced one reporter, corrected another, demanded an apology from CBS and said Weld would cry if he were subjected to similar media scrutiny. On the CBS Sunday talk show ``Face the Nation,'' Silber told reporter Leslie Stahl she had misrepresented his attitudes about Jews, blacks and working women. ``The voters out there know perfectly well I'm totally in control and I just nailed you for three distortions on which somebody ought to nail you,'' he said. A stunned Stahl replied ``wow'' several times, observing: ``You're angry; you sound angry.'' When it came Weld's turn to appear, Stahl asked, ``Are you going to attack me?'' The former federal prosecutor reserved his criticism for Silber, suggesting, as he often has, the Boston University president is too unstable to govern. ``Just because someone may demonstrate a lot of ill humor, that doesn't prove they're going to have the ability to go and change the system,'' Weld said. A poll released Sunday by the Boston Globe and WBZ-TV gave Silber 44 percent to 41 percent for Weld, well within the margin of error of plus or minus three points. Independent Len Umina had 3 percent, and 12 percent were undecided. Silber has led throughout in this predominantly Democratic state. In a poll released last Tuesday, Silber had 46 percent and Weld 37 percent. That poll had a four-point margin of error. Polls show Weld gaining support with liberal Democrats for his views on abortion, the environment and day care. Silber, speaking on a local TV station, said later Sunday that CBS owed him an apology for implying he believes Jews are racist and for saying he offended women with statements about how the feminist movement has led to child abuse. ``If anything were left of the libel laws and the laws of slander, I would retire on the assets of CBS,'' he said. Silber also said, ``If you beat up on Bill Weld a little while the way I have been beat up on, I think he'll cry.'' A CBS spokeswoman, Catherine Upin, responded, ``We stand by the accuracy of our broadcast.'' Stahl had questioned Silber on comments he made several years ago that he felt unwelcome at a synagogue because his mother was not Jewish. As the campaign draws to an end, Silber has stepped up his attacks on Weld, characterizing him as an ``orange-headed WASP'' and a ``back-stabbing SOB.'' Weld countered over the weekend: ``The voters are considering whether they want to be yelled at for four years. I don't think they do.''

DOC.HEAD: Leader Of Radical PLO Unit Confirms Libya Closed His Camps
DOC.TEXT: Abul Abbas, the mastermind of the 1985 Achille Lauro ship hijacking, says Libya has expelled 145 members of his radical PLO faction and closed down four training camps. Abul Abbas said in an interview on Sunday that the move was a surprise to him and his wing of the Palestine Liberation Front, which is widely considered to be a major terrorist organization. He said the ejection was unjustified and urged Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, to reopen the camps and the group's offices. The government in Tripoli has not given an explanation for its action, he said. Reports began to surface about a week ago that Libya had expelled the Palestinians. Arab diplomats in Baghdad said the United States had asked King Hassan of Morroco and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to press Gadhafi to eject the group. Gadhafi is believed to want Libya's removal from the U.S. State Department's list of countries supporting terrorism. PLO chief Yasser Arafat has also been pressed to dissociate himself from Abul Abbas, who has one seat on the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Pressure to remove Abul Abbas increased after his group raided an Israeli beach in May, an action that led the United States to break off its dialogue with the PLO. After the raid on the Israeli beach, Abul Abbas apologized to Arafat, saying the PLO chief did not about the raid in advance. He also said that civilianswere not targets in that raid, counter to Israeli claims. Abul Abbas dismissed reports the PLO leadership had asked Libya to kick out his group. ``We rule out any possibility that the PLO leadership has asked for this, but some Palestinian circles who oppose our militant line might have done so,'' he said. He said that most of the group had moved to Lebanon, and others to places that he delined to name. Abul Abbas, whose real name is Mohammed Abbas, leads one of two wings of the Palestine front, which split from Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command in 1977. Based in Baghdad since leaving Lebanon in 1982, Abul Abbas is believed to have several hundred guerrilla fighters in his organization - in Iraq, Lebanon and, until now, Libya. The other wing of the Palestine front, based in Damascus, was led by Talaat Yacoub, who died two years ago. Abul Abbas said two of the camps were places where PLO fighters were trained for ``naval combat.'' One was a small town east of Tripoli and the other was west of Tripoli, he said. He did not provide the others' locations. The Palestinian leader said his group would continue its ``armed struggle'' against Israel but insisted that the group will not attack any targets outside of the Jewish state. Abul Abbas said that he had no plans to attack Americans or other Westerners despite the Persian Gulf crisis. But he said his group would fight alongside Iraq if it is attacked by the U.S.-led multinational forces that have massed in the region in response to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. ``In pan-Arab battles we will carry out our duties alongside our brothers in Iraq,'' he said. The Achille Lauro, a Mediterranean cruise ship, was hijacked Oct. 7, 1985 and held by terrorists for two days. A 69-year-old wheelchair-bound Jewish-American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, was killed during the hijacking and his body dumped into the sea. A Genoa court in 1986 convicted Abbas in absentia of masterminding the hijacking. Abbas maintained had merely played a role in negotiating the release of the ship in exchange for freedom for the hijackers.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Mary Martin Dies at 76
LaserPhotos NY4, NY5
With PM-Obit-Martin-List, PM-Martin-Appreciation
DOC.TEXT: Mary Martin was remembered upon her death for a tomboyish charm and vibrancy that lit up the stage whether she flew high in ``Peter Pan'' or sang to children in ``The Sound of Music.'' Martin, one of the New York theater's leading ladies for more than 30 years, died of cancer Saturday at age 76 at her home in Rancho Mirage. The actress captivated audiences with her spunk and her joyous singing in such Broadway musicals as ``South Pacific,'' ``The Sound of Music,'' ``I Do! I Do!'' and ``Leave It to Me.'' ``Vibrant, exciting and always full of life, Mary gave her millions of fans the world over some of the most memorable and thrilling moments in the history of entertainment,'' said former first lady Nancy Reagan, who appeared with her in the 1946 musical ``Lute Song.'' ``The bright light and good cheer that Mary brought to the world will not fade merely because of her absence,'' said William Hammerstein, son of Oscar Hammerstein II, who wrote the lyrics for ``South Pacific'' and ``The Sound of Music.'' Martin won a Tony Award for her 1949 portrayal of the naive Army nurse Nellie Forbush in ``South Pacific.'' Martin sang some of Rodgers and Hammerstein's most buoyant and warmhearted songs, including ``A Cockeyed Optimist,'' ``I'm in Love with a Wonderful Guy'' and ``I'm Gonna Wash That Man Right Outa My Hair'' - during which she washed her hair on stage for 1,000 performances. In ``The Sound of Music,'' which opened in 1959, Martin played the irrepressible nun-in-training Maria and won another Tony. The Rodgers and Hammerstein score included ``My Favorite Things,'' ``Do-Re-Mi'' and ``The Lonely Goatherd.'' The show ran for more than three years in New York. The role of Maria practically belongs to Julie Andrews, who got the part in the movie, while the part of Nellie Forbush in the film version of ``South Pacific'' went to Mitzi Gaynor. But the role of Peter Pan is all Martin's. She was in her 40s when she played Peter Pan, the boy who never wanted to grow up, on stage and television. ``All my life, I wanted to be Peter Pan,'' Martin once said. ``My poor mother never knew what I was going to do next. I don't think anything ever surprised my parents. I was always doing something strange - like at 5, jumping off the garage. I wanted to fly, and all I did was break my collarbone.'' ``Peter Pan'' opened on Broadway in 1954 and ran for 152 performances. It was televised live on NBC in 1955 and 1956. Martin won Tony and Emmy awards for the role. With the advent of videotape and color, NBC taped ``Peter Pan'' in 1960 and last broadcast it in 1989. A videocassette was released this year. Martin was born in Weatherford, Texas, and married Benjamin Hagman in 1930. They divorced the following year after the birth of son Larry Hagman, who plays J.R. Ewing on ``Dallas.'' Martin left Texas to pursue a singing career in California and made her debut as the Trocadero nightclub in Hollywood. It was there she was seen by producer Charles Schwab, who put her in Cole Porter's ``Leave It to Me.'' The musical, which opened on Broadway in 1938, made her a star. Each night she stopped the show by doing a coy striptease while singing the musical's best-known song, ``My Heart Belongs to Daddy.'' Martin journeyed to California for a series of less-than-memorable movie musicals and married story editor Richard Halliday in 1940. They had one daughter, Heller. Halliday died in 1973. Martin was seriously injured in a 1982 taxi accident in San Francisco that killed her manager. Her last show, ``Legends!'' opened in 1986 with Carol Channing her co-star. It didn't make it to Broadway. ``It's one show I didn't like,'' Martin said. She did it ``because Larry said to me, `Mother, you've been off long enough.''' Martin is survived by her son and daughter, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sinks, Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The governing party's victory in a parliamentary by-election helped boost the Japanese yen against the dollar and push up stock prices in Tokyo today, traders said. The dollar closed at 127.35 yen, down 1.75 yen from Friday's close of 129.10 yen. It opened at 127.20 yen and ranged between 126.75 yen and 127.55 yen in spot trading that totaled $13.56 billion. The dollar now has plunged 3.35 yen in the last two trading days, but still is above its recent low closing of 124.40, hit on Oct. 18 after a 13-day slide that totaled 13.55 yen. The governing Liberal Democratic Party won a parliamentary by-election Sunday despite widespread criticism of its proposal to send troops to the Middle East for non-combat duties. In addition, dealers said, pessimism about the U.S. economy grew after figures announced Friday showed U.S. unemployment still high and leading economic indicators declining. This fanned fears that U.S. interest rates might be lowered further, said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Lower interest rates tend to make a currency less attractive to foreign investors. The dollar's decline was softened, however, by profiting-taking on the rising yen, said Takeo Suzuki of Yasuda Trust and Banking. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,385.33 points, up 190.34, or 0.79 percent, from Friday's close. The stronger yen and a sense of political stability after Sunday's election encouraged investors, said Keiji Arai, a dealer at Sanyo Securities. ``But share prices are not shooting up because market players are cautiously waiting at the sidelines for the outcomes of two other upcoming local elections and Tuesday's U.S. midterm elections,'' he added. Yutaka Yoshino, a dealer at Nikko Securities, described the day's trading as directionless and sluggish, with volume on the first section a slim 220 million shares. The Nikkei index fell for four consecutive trading days last week. The biggest dip, 898.94 points, came on Thursday. Yoshino said buying also suffered from investors' uncertainties about both the American and Japanese government bond markets. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 85.05 points from Friday's 84.90-point finish. Their yield fell to 7.690 percent from 7.725 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sulfuric Acid Spills Into Creek
DOC.TEXT: Crews worked today to clean up about 49,000 pounds of sulfuric acid spilled from a tanker truck into a tributary of the Ouachita River, officials said. ``It could possibly kill some fish and possibly some wildlife in the area,'' said State Police Cpl. Janet Welch. State Police warned against fishing in the creek and told cattlemen to watch livestock along the water, she said. Welch said the truck crashed into a bridge over Blakely Creek while trying to pass in heavy rain Sunday evening on Interstate 30, about 15 miles from Malvern. The creek empties into the Ouachita a mile below the accident site. The driver had only minor injuries and was cited for driving too fast, Ms. Welch said.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister's Party Splits, Capital Paralyzed By Strike
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh's party broke apart today, leaving the government in disarray in a country already seriously shaken by Hindu-Moslem violence that has claimed more than 330 lives. Hindu fundamentalists vowed today to dismantle 3,000 Islamic shrines across India. They have been thwarted at least temporarily in their campaign to replace a mosque in the remote northern town of Ayodhya with a temple. The capital, meanwhile, was brought to a near standstill by a strike called by the right-wing Hindu party that provoked the political and religious crisis. Singh won the endorsement of more than half his Janata Dal Party's members in Parliament, but a large dissident faction deserted him today and named its own choice for prime minister. The dissidents elected Chandra Shekhar, a long-time Singh antagonist, to lead them and said they would request that President Ramaswamy Venkataraman ask their new leader to form a government. Whatever happens, Singh is likely to lose, since he faces a vote of confidence in Parliament on Wednesday. The defection from Singh's governing coalition last month of the Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party, inspired by the arrest of its leader for instigating unrest in the Ayodhya dispute, triggered the political crisis. In the capital today, Bharatiya Janata activists blocked traffic by deflating the tires of trucks and buses that ignored their strike call. Many shops were closed. In some areas, private cars and three-wheel motorscooter taxis were halted. Police were deployed on major streets. Most parents kept their children home from school, fearing trouble. Bharatiya Janata was protesting the killings by police of at least 22 Hindu fundamentalists who were shot last week trying to replace the Ayodhya mosque with a temple. Nationwide, more than 300 othe people have been burned, stabbed, shot or hacked to death in Hindu-Moslem riots or when police opened fire to disperse rampaging mobs. The position of the beleaguered Singh worsened today with the resignation of a sixth minister in his 38-member Cabinet. Minister of State for Communications Janeshwar Mishra submitted his resignation shortly before Singh's showdown with his Janata Dal Party, United News of India said. The string of desertions began nearly two weeks ago. The daily lurch toward disintegration leaves the entire government in question. If the Janata Dal ousts Singh, it's still questionable whether a new party leader can forge the coalition support necessary to stay in power. India could then be headed for new elections four years ahead of schedule. Ayodhya itself, the flashpoint for the sectarian dispute, was calm this morning, a day after Hindu leaders suspended their campaign to seize the mosque after claiming to have reached an accord with authorities. But the stage was set for new confrontations between the Hindu majority and the Moslem minority when a Hindu fundamentalist leader vowed to dismantle 3,000 mosques nationwide and replace them with Hindu temples. Ashok Singhal, general secretary of the World Hindu Council, told reporters in Ayodhya that his group would beef up its militant youth wing and expand efforts. ``Earlier we wanted three, but now, seeing the government operation on Hindus, we have decided that we will dismantle 3,000 mosques,'' Singhal said. The mosques are those that Singhal and others feel are on Hindu holy sites. The Hindus want a temple at Ayodhya to honor Ram, the warrior-god who is one of the most popular Hindu deities. The Bharatiya Janata Party, which had tacitly supported Singh's government since he took office as prime minister Dec. 2, 1989, had fervently supported the temple-building project. Its leader, Lal Krishna Advani, was arrested Oct. 24 while leading a caravan of supporters across India to Ayodhya. The party promptly withdrew its support, leaving Singh and his Janata Dal Party teetering. Today, Janata Dal's dissident spokesman Harmohan Dhawan told reporters that 82 of the the party's 178 members in Parliament unanimously chose Chandra Shekhar. But Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral, a Singh supporter, said 113 legislators met separately at Parliament and voted unanimously to support Singh. The figures could not immediately be reconciled. Janata Dal was created to unseat former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party, which had virtually monopolized political power in India since the country won independence from Britain in 1947. The party was united by little more than anti-Gandhi sentiments, and the crisis in Ayodhya was all it took for ex-Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, a top Singh foe in the party, and others to make their move. Hindus make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people, but in close elections the Moslem minority of 12 percent is crucial.

DOC.HEAD: Hvorostovsky Takes Carnegie by Storm
DOC.TEXT: By the time the cheering stopped at Carnegie Hall, one fact seemed indisputable: A lot of people are going to be learning how to pronounce the name Hvorostovsky. That's Dmitri Hvorostovksy (khvuh-rah-STOF-skee). Occupation: baritone. Place of birth: Siberia. Age: 28. In his Carnegie debut program of Italian songs and arias Sunday night, Hvorostovsky deepened the impression he has created in other concerts and on records. Here is a highly gifted young singer who combines a naturally beautiful voice with unusual artistic sensitivity and involvement. He devoted the first half of the program to art songs by early Italian composers, including Pergolesi and Stradella. Hvorostovsky was equal to their demands, whether the mood was light and playful, angry or, more typically, melancholy. But these songs served mainly as a warmup for the second half of the program, which featured several mainstays of the Italian operatic repertory. Here Hvorostovsky thrilled his audience with all the vocal power one could ask for and a range that carried up to the A above middle C. There was some Donizetti, Riccardo's fiery aria from Bellini's ``I Puritani,'' and finally two Verdi showpieces - Miller's aria from ``Luisa Miller'' and Rodrigo's dying ``O Carlo, ascolta'' from ``Don Carlo.'' In this last number, Hvorostovsky's purity of tone was astonishing, as was his ability to sustain a long, smooth line without, apparently, having to stop for breath like other human beings. Having roused the crowd to a fervor, he outdid himself in a couple of encores. The Prologue scene from Leoncavallo's ``I Pagliacci'' brought to mind the great Leonard Warren, who made the part one of his specialties. An aria from Tchaikovsky's ``Queen of Spades'' was heart-rending in its beauty. The excellent piano accompanist was Mikhail Arkadiev. It's no criticism of him to say one longed to hear the singer accompanied in the operatic selections by full orchestra. Hvorostovsky will be making his debut at several major opera houses around the world in the coming year - La Scala, San Francisco, Covent Garden. No plans have been announced yet to bring him to the Metropolitan Opera, but the folks over at Lincoln Center can ill afford to let this talent elude them for long.

DOC.HEAD: Man Invents Anti-Theft Device
DOC.TEXT: Necessity wasn't the mother of Gary Dimmick's invention. A thief was. After someone stole a new suede coat out from under him at a bar, a cold walk home inspired Dimmick to find a way to keep jackets, purses and other hard-to-lock objects from being stolen. What Dimmick came up with was the Lock-Man, designed to fasten objects securely to coat hooks or bar stools. Dimmick has invested more than $200,000 of his own money on the device. He said he'll have to sell 100,000 of the devices, on store shelves for a month, to break even. ``I'm over dreaming of being a millionaire,'' he said after seven years of work. ``But it was a fun fantasy.'' The Lock-Man, which is 6{ inches long and weighs 4{ ounces, uses an aluminum cylinder containing a chain to wrap around a hook or post. The chain can be looped and pulled tight and then attached to whatever needs to be secured. ``It's not Fort Knox, but it's not supposed to be,'' said Dimmick, 37. ``It's supposed to prevent casual theft - theft of opportunity.''

DOC.HEAD: Despite Government Victory, Troop Bill No Winner in Diet Election
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the governing and opposition parties both claimed an edge today in a hard-fought parliamentary election seen as a referendum on the government's fading bid to send troops to the Persian Gulf. The clearest signal, though, seemed to come from the huge majority of voters who elected to stay home. The governing Liberal Democrats breathed a little easier after the slim victory of Yoshihisa Oshima, a 50-year-old dentist, over Socialist Party member Michiko Goto in the Aichi prefectural by-election on Sunday. The party, however, backed away from calling Oshima's 45 percent to 43 percent plurality an endorsement of its troop deployment bill, which faces likely defeat in Parliament. The opposition parties were less shy. They said the upper house election was a clear repudiation of the troop deployment proposal because Goto and the Communist Party candidate, Yukiko Seko, together tallied 55 percent of the vote, or 1,003,815 votes to Oshima's 833,371. Furthermore, the opposition's strong showing came in what is normally a governing party stronghold and the home district of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, the bill's sponsor. ``This was proof that a great number of citizens oppose the Self-Defense Forces deployment bill,'' said Kanju Sato, the Socialist Party's election committee chairman. ``We will fight harder to prevent the bill from being passed.'' Kaifu, whose already weak prime ministership would have been jeopardized by an election loss, issued an unusual statement declaring, ``I'm so glad that we won as a result of the efforts by the candidate and the entire party.'' The prime minister twice visited Aichi, southwest of Tokyo, and his party's secretary general, Ichiro Ozawa, went three times. More than 100 Liberal Democrat members of Parliament were sent in to back the party's candidate, The Japan Times reported. Nonetheless, Sunday's voter turnout was just 38.7 percent of the 4.8 million eligible voters, one of the lowest figures ever in the postwar period in Aichi. ``Japanese voters are most interested in bread and butter and the bill has little to do with that,'' said Hideo Sato, international politics professor at Tsukuba University. By-elections last year, when a consumption tax was the focus, drew more than 60 percent of eligible voters. A special session of Parliament called to debate Kaifu's ``United Nations Peace Cooperation Bill'' is scheduled to end Saturday. Ozawa, however, said it could be extended. ``The public does not sufficiently understand. If the government makes a greater effort, I think we can gain support,'' said Chief Cabinent Secretary Misoji Sakamoto. The opposition, and some members of Kaifu's own party, say the proposal would violate Japan's post-World War II constitution, which bans the use of force to settle international disputes. Kaifu has said the troops would be limited to non-combat roles. He has been under pressure from the United States and other nations that want Japan to provide more than money for the Persian Gulf forces.

DOC.HEAD: Fog Equals Fear for Residents Near Chemical Processing Plants
DOC.TEXT: Fog brings fear for some residents of this central Florida mining town, where state officials have measured nine releases of dangerous ammonia or sulfur oxides from nearby chemical plants since 1987. ``We've got a bad situation here and people don't realize it,'' said Wilbert Lancaster, a 27-year phosphate industry veteran whose son was briefly overcome by ammonia fumes at Mulberry High School. ``What is it going to take to get them to do something about it? Is somebody going to have to die?'' More than two weeks after the last dense fog passed over Mulberry, Fire Chief Mitch Carmack still had blisters in his mouth - caused, he said, when he tried to take samples of the chemical while wearing standard firefighting clothes. The fumes, he said, ate holes in his shirt. The incident drew so many complaints to the city Fire Department that dispatchers stopped logging calls. Firefighters used loudspeakers for about two hours to warn hundreds of residents to stay indoors. No one required medical treatment. Twenty people were hospitalized briefly from exposure to three earlier toxic clouds, which can be created when phosphate is converted from raw ore to fertilizer. The Department of Environmental Regulation or the Fire Department has traced all but the latest cloud, on Oct. 21, to two of the three area chemical plants. DER blames a Royster Co. chemical and fertilizer plant for an Aug. 31 release and one in September 1989, when 17 high school students and the school's ROTC supervisor were hit by a bluish cloud of sulfur oxide. The supervisor, James Gandy, said he and the students coughed violently and had teary eyes and trouble breathing. DER has negotiated several improvements at the Royster plant, said Viet Ta, a DER enforcement engineer. The agency also is considering installing an additional air monitoring device near town. The company's problem is that its monitors showed nothing unusual during either of those releases, said Royster manager Gary Dahms. ``We're not denying it,'' he said, ``but we don't see how it could have happened.'' Royster has reimbursed all of those involved for their medical expenses and is starting a training program for employees on minimizing releases, he said. The company also has accepted responsibility for failing two emissions tests and making two improper releases since 1986 and has paid fines totaling $40,640 in settlements with DER. ``Even though we're legal, if we're making a smell, we're not going to get by,'' Dahms said. ``We've got to be more careful.'' The release of an ammonia cloud in February that hit a bus driver and three passengers was blamed on the now-closed New Imperial Phosphates plant. DER since has denied the plant permission to resume processing, citing a lack of proper monitoring and alarm systems.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Dinkins May Have Backdated Letter Used to Prove Stock Sale
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins' office disputed a report that federal prosecutors have evidence indicating he used a backdated letter to prove he did not evade taxes on a stock transfer. Spokesman Albert Scardino called the story in Sunday's New York Newsday ``shameful and dishonest journalism'' based on ``unfounded allegations,'' and the mayor's attorney, Charles Stillman, insisted the letter is legitimate. The letter became an issue during the mayoral campaign last year when Republican Rudolph Giuliani questioned whether Dinkins had paid appropriate federal gift taxes on the transfer of stock in a cable TV company to his son. In 1986, Dinkins said he transferred 588 shares of the stock to David Dinkins Jr. at no cost. After Giuliani's accusation, Dinkins said he had sold the stock to his son for $58,000 and thus wasn't subject to gift tax. He released copies of a handwritten, unnotarized ``Dear Dad'' letter from his son - dated Oct. 30, 1985 - as proof of the sale. The fact that Dinkins had once valued the stock at $1 million and that he failed to pay taxes for four years 20 years ago added to the controversy. A federal investigation of the stock transfer ended in July with no criminal charges, but a city probe continues. Newsday, citing an unidentified source close to the federal grand jury that investigated the matter, reported Sunday that an imprint of a phone number on the letter suggests it was written in 1988 or 1989. Investigators, though, could not prove it conclusively, the source said. The number is that of a media-related company that the younger Dinkins would have had little reason to contact in 1985, when he worked as a producer for CBS Sports, the newspaper said. Dinkins' son is now an independent TV producer and would have had reason to dial the number in 1988 or 1989, it said. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney, in a confidential report summarizing his findings for a special city investigator in July, said he found ``substantial evidence'' the letter was not written when dated, Newsday said. Maloney refused to comment on the grand jury proceedings. The mayor's son, who lives in Las Vegas, did not respond to Newsday's requests for an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Settlement Reached in Navistar Strike
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators today reached a settlement ending a strike by 8,000 Navistar International Corp. employees in six states. Navistar spokesman Bill Greenhill said the employees who walked out at midnight Friday after a contract extension ran out would begin returning today. Navistar, formerly International Harvester, makes trucks and diesel engines. The tentative agreement was reached about 3 a.m. after 19 hours of talks between the company and the United Auto Workers, union officials said. Details of the agreement were withheld pending a meeting of the union bargaining committee on Wednesday, but Bill Casstevens, UAW secretary-treasurer and chief negotiator, said the pact ``meets the membership's needs for continued job and income security while making important improvements in economic areas.'' UAW spokesman Reg McGhee said a ratification vote could begin this week. Workers in Indiana, Illinois, Ohio, Georgia, Maryland and Texas were affected by the strike. McGhee said he doubted the strike had caused any serious production problems because little work had been scheduled over the weekend. Representatives met throughout Saturday and from about 8 a.m. Sunday before reaching the accord, McGhee said. Talks had been held in Louisville since August in an attempt to reach a contract to replace the 1987-90 agreement, which had been extended since Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Orders Militias To Disband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Moldavian leader's name pronounced MEER-cha Sneh-GOOR.
DOC.TEXT: Moldavia's parliament ordered all militias to disband within 24 hours after its president urged lawmakers to reconsider laws that have encouraged ethnic unrest in the independence-minded republic. The speech Sunday by President Mircha Snegur marked the first time the ethnic Moldavian leadership had accepted blame for separatist movements in the Turkish-Christian Gagauz region in the south and the predominantly Russian and Ukrainian Dniester area in the east, lawmakers said. On Saturday, Snegur and representatives of the separatist groups met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow and agreed to a moratorium on the acts that helped precipitate the crisis. Details of the moratorium have not been worked out. Lawmakers said it probably would mean the Gagauz and Dniester regions would suspend their declarations of autonomy and planned elections. In return, the republic's government would soften a language law that made Moldavian the national language and required people in dozens of jobs, ranging from doctors to hairdressers, to pass tests in Moldavian by 1995. The language law stirred resentment among Russian speakers and the Gagauz, who speak a Turkic language and are descendants of Christians who fled to Moldavia from persecution in Bulgaria in the 19th century. Both the Gagauz and Dniester separatists claim discrimination by Moldavians, who themselves want independence from the Soviet Union. Moldavia, a republic on 4.3 million people on the Romanian border, asked for help from Soviet Interior Ministry troops after an Aug. 18 autonomy declaration by the Gagauz, who number about 150,000. After the president's speech Sunday, Moldavia's parliament passed a resolution ordering all militias - Moldavians, Russians, Ukrainians and Gagauz - to disband within 24 hours. Some units have reportedly armed themselves. In neighboring Romania on Sunday, thousands of demonstrators demanded reunification with their ethnic kin in Moldavia. About 2,000 Romanians marched to the Soviet Embassy in Bucharest, shouting ``We want Bessarabia back!'' Bessarabia is another name for Moldavia. About 4,000 Romanians in the Transylvanian city of Sibiu, some 160 miles north of Bucharest, voiced similar demands. Soviet soldiers moved into Moldavia 50 years ago under the pact by which Stalin and Hitler divided Eastern Europe into spheres of influence before the two dictators became World War II adversaries. ``We are not giving up our national rebirth, our language, alphabet, symbols, and so on,'' Snegur told lawmakers. ``Simply, we must go back and look for where, maybe, we have gone too fast for our fellow citizens.'' Snegur's speech set off heated debate. ``If we want to be taken seriously as a legislature, we cannot reconsider laws which we have already passed,'' said legislator Ion Vatamanu. Nicolae Kostin, a leader of Moldavian People's Front, said he feared the unrest could be used as a pretext by ``dark forces of conservtives'' in Moscow to crush Moldavia's autonomy. More than 1,000 students marched to the republic's Parliament on Saturday to support the Moldavian government after a clash in Dubossary, in the eastern Dniester region, left at least three people dead and nine wounded. The clash began after Russians and Ukrainians seized government buildings in Dubossary and blocked nearby roads and a bridge over the Dniester River. ``They are already martyrs,'' said Vladimir Solonar, a member of a group of Russians opposed to Moldavia's autonomy drive, speaking by telephone from Tiraspol in the Dniester region. He said black flags hung in the streets of Tiraspol, a city of just under 200,000 people, and solemn music played on the radio. A funeral rally was planned for Tuesday. About 200,000 ethnic Russians and Ukrainians live in the region, which separatists on Sept. 2 declared the ``Dniester republic.'' ``I appeal again to parents and wives to restrain all hot-headed behavior. We must be calm and soberly keep in mind what is happening and what could happen if we make one more misstep,'' he said, without elaborating. Lawmakers said they feared the introduction of Soviet troops. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov warned on Soviet TV Saturday night that Moscow would take tough measures if Moldavia's leaders failed to restore order. He did not specify what measures. Ion Hadyrka, Moldavia's first vice president, said Gorbachev and Ryzhkov urged that Moldavia's leadership be altered to reflect the percentages of ethnic groups. Hadyrka also told the legislature it should consider giving citizens seven to 10 years to learn Moldavian, which is spoken by two-thirds of the republic's people.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Training Helps Kenyan Runner
DOC.TEXT: The teachings of a Japanese coach helped Douglas Wakiihuri of Kenya win this year's hot and humid New York City Marathon. Wakiihuri went to Japan eight years ago to train under Kiyoshi Nakamura, who had worked with the outstanding Japanese marathoner Toshihiko Seko. ``He told me the way is very long,'' Wakiihuri said. ``If you are not careful, you will hit a stone. You have to have patience.'' The 27-year-old runner showed extreme patience Sunday. He stayed with the lead pack for the first 20 miles before breaking away and racing to a 40-second victory in 2 hours, 12 minutes, 39 seconds in the 26.2-mile race. With the temperature reaching 72 and the humidity 66 percent at the start of the race, it was the slowest winning time since 1984. Wanda Panfil of Poland beat Kim Jones of Spokane, Wash., by five seconds in 2:30:45 for the closest women's finish ever. The New York marathon, with a field of more than 25,000 runners, is the nation's biggest race and the second largest in the world after the London marathon. The course winds through New York's five boroughs, and parts of it are carpeted for the occasion to protect runners' feet from metal grates.

DOC.HEAD: Flurries in Montana Early Today; Heavy Snow Expected in Utah
DOC.TEXT: Flurries fell in Montana early today, and up to 10 inches of snow were expected across the northern mountains of Utah. Snow was also predicted for the higher elevations of Idaho and Colorado. Showers were forecast for the northern Plains. The storm system that piled more than a foot of snow on the Colorado Rockies this weekend and also brought the season's first snow to Texas and Oklahoma was expected to move northeast across the Mississippi Valley today. Showers were predicted for that region, but colder air was expected to turn the rain to snow by the time the system reached the Great Lakes. Up to eight inches were possible for northern Michigan. Sunny, mild weather was expected to continue in the East, with highs in the 60s and 70s. Skies were also expected to be clear on the West Coast. Highs were expected to reach the 30s in regions looking for snow, the 40s in the Pacific Northwest and northern New England, the 50s in the Great Plains, the 70s in the Deep South and California and the 80s in Florida and Texas. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 88 degrees at Tampa, Fla.
