DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were higher. Dealers said the dollar's slide came amid fears U.S. interest rates will have to drop again to breathe new life into the U.S. economy. ``The dollar will continue heading lower ... Traders are trying to see how far the dollar can go,'' said an analyst in Frankfurt. Only a military conflagration in the Middle East will turn the dollar around, traders predicted. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.75 yen to a closing 127.35 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 127.05 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.4932 German marks, down from 1.5020 -1.2590 Swiss francs, down from 1.2705 -5.0110 French francs, down from 5.0420 -1.6845 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6938 -1,123.25 Italian lire, down from 1,129.00 -1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1653 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9605, compared with $1.9515 late Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $377.05 per ounce at midmorning, from $376.25 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $376.50, up from $375.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.13 to close at a bid $376.93. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.17 a troy ounce, from Friday's $4.18.

DOC.HEAD: Baltimore, Hawaii Real Estate Mogul Harry Weinberg Dies
DOC.TEXT: Harry Weinberg, a reclusive millionaire who made a fortune in Baltimore and Hawaii, has died at age 82, leaving a $900 million charitable trust, one of the biggest in the country. Weinberg died Sunday at the Queen's Medical Center, after an eight-year battle with bone cancer. He earned millions in real estate, municipal transit companies and other ventures in a familiar American success story. Last month, Forbes magazine estimated Weinberg's worth at $950 million, ranking him 70th on its list of the 400 richest Americans. His family immigrated to Baltimore in 1912 from what was the Austro-Hungarian empire. Weinberg quit school at 12, worked in his father's auto shop, sold newspapers on the side and eventually parlayed a series of remarkably successful business deals into enormous wealth. He began acquiring land during the Depression, buying 47 properties in downtown Baltimore alone. A millionaire by the end of World War II, Weinberg began buying money-losing private transit companies in Baltimore, Scranton, Pa., Dallas, New York and Honolulu. He later sold them at enormous profit. After visiting Honolulu in the early 1950s, he recognized that jet travel would make Hawaii's tropical islands accessible to middle-class tourists. He acquired Oahu and Maui properties that form the bulk of the estate and are now worth hundreds of millions of dollars in one of the nation's hottest real estate markets. Weinberg moved from Baltimore to Honolulu in 1968, but had already set up a Baltimore-based foundation for the poor that bears his name and that of his wife, who died in 1989. The Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation - which will receive most of his estate - will be among the nation's 12 largest, worth at least $900 million and obligated to spend as much as $45 million a year, said Shale D. Stiller, attorney for the foundation. ``It really is an unbelievable task,'' said Stiller. ``It's an incredible amount of money to give away.'' Weinberg left nothing to his son, Morton, said Stiller. By all accounts, Harry Weinberg was a man with little interest in anything but business. Although he accumulated enormous wealth, he never bothered with the trappings. His offices were drab, his car was 10 or 15 years old, his clothes came off the rack and he hated publicity. ``He didn't play golf. He didn't play tennis,'' said Morton Weinberg, who lives near Los Angeles. ``His business was his life. He didn't waste his time doing other things.'' Criticized as a callous landlord who neglected his properties, Weinberg revealed a softer side after learning he had cancer. He announced he would give all his money away and developed a special concern for the elderly. On his final 1989 pilgrimage to Israel, a nation whose birth he witnessed in 1948, he asked to visit several of Tel Aviv's nursing homes. It was a humid summer day. Weinberg, surprised the nursing homes did not have air conditioning, wrote a check for $1 million to pay to cool every nursing home in Israel. Before his death, he stipulated that the foundation give at least 25 percent of its yearly donations to predominately Jewish charities. Besides his son, Weinberg is survived by three brothers, one sister and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Plans Christmas Visit to Brother Held Hostage in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose twin brother is being held hostage in Iraq said she'll overlook the dangers and spend Christmas in Baghdad. ``If this helps John's morale, so be it,'' Mary Trundy, 44, of Brockton said of her twin, John Stevenson. The U.S. government has urged families of captives in Iraq and Kuwait to ignore Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's offer to let them visit over Christmas. The White House fears the families could become hostages, too. Trundy said Stevenson called their brothers in Florida over the weekend. ``I think it is a very positive sign that they are letting hostages call home,'' she said. ``We're all planning to spend the holidays with John.'' Trundy said her twin felt forgotten and wondered what the government was doing to free the hostages. He asked his siblings to bring food and a shortwave radio, saying he had not received any of the mail they sent them, she said. Stevenson, who escaped Iran just 12 hours before the revolution 11 years ago, was working as a systems development manager for the Bank of Kuwait when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He hid until Oct. 20, when he and eight other American and British nationals were captured and taken to Baghdad, where hundreds of Americans are captives.

DOC.HEAD: Six People Arrested in Halloween Attack on Ward's Island
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with sixth arrest.
DOC.TEXT: Six young men faced arraignment today on charges of attacking homeless men with baseball bats, pipes and meat cleavers in a Halloween rampage that left one man dead and nine injured. Five of the defendants, three of them teen-agers, were arrested Sunday on murder charges in the death of Carlos Melendez, whose throat was slashed. The sixth was charged with attempted murder, police said. More arrests are expected, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann. About a dozen youths, some wearing Halloween masks, screamed, ``Trick or treat!'' as they set upon men heading to a homeless shelter on Ward's Island in the East River. Police said the gang - armed with bats, pipes, knives and meat cleavers - waited in the dark, then beat and robbed the victims as they crossed a narrow footbridge over the river. ``It was Halloween, the homeless are there, they're an easy target,'' said Capt. Daniel McKenna. Melendez, 35, died at the scene. Three other men required 30 to 55 stitches to close head cuts, and six others were less seriously hurt. Charged with murder were Robert Sherman, 23; Hector Torres, 15; Aaron Ware, 13, and his brother Raymond Fenner, 22; and John Moreno, 16, police said. An 18-year-old, Eric Williams, was charged with attempted murder in the attack on Roosevelt Jones, who was beaten in the face with a pipe, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Curfews in Gaza After 185 Wounded In Weekend Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with more Palestinians wounded today, curfews imposed. New byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Military curfews confined 150,000 Palestinians to their homes in the occupied Gaza Strip today following two days of rioting in which at least 185 Palestinians were wounded by army gunfire. An additional 350 Gaza residents were treated for lesser injuries from rubber bullets, beatings and tear-gas inhalation, according to the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, which oversees Palestinian aid programs. The weekend clashes came as Israel rejected a call by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar for international protection of the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Perez de Cuellar suggested a meeting of representatives from the 164 countries that signed the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which sets out rules for the treatment of civilians in wartime. ``Israel is disappointed at the one-sided approach exhibited in the report,'' Israel's Foreign Ministry said in a statement. ``The recommendations in the report are directed only toward Israel and do not see fit to call for a cessation of violence on the Palestinian side.'' Israel earlier rejected resolutions passed unanimously by the U.N. Security Council for a U.N. probe into the Oct. 8 rioting on Jerusalem's Temple Mount, in which 20 Palestinians were killed. The army spokesman's office said eight areas in Gaza were under curfew today, including the village of Beit Hanoun, where clashes began Saturday and spread throughout Gaza. Reporters and photographers without military escort were barred from the seaside strip, where more than 700,000 Palestinians live. Associated Press photographer Max Nash, who went into the strip with the army, said Palestinians persisted in stoning army jeeps and journalists' cars in Gaza City despite increased military patrols. Five Palestinians were shot and wounded in clashes with soldiers today in Rafah, on the Egyptian border, according to Arab hospital officials. The weekend confrontations were caused by word that a man from Beit Hanoun died in military custody. The army said the man hanged himself, but Palestinians questioned whether he was beaten while being interrogated. An AP survey of Gaza hospitals showed 185 Palestinians treated for gunshot wounds Saturday and Sunday. Officials with the U.N. Relief and Works Agency also counted at least 150 Palestinians treated at U.N. clinics for injuries from rubber-coated metal pellets, 70 for beatings and 130 for tear-gas inhalation. An army spokesman said military figures indicated 174 Palestinians were wounded over the weekend. The spokesman, who cannot be identified by name under briefing rules, said most suffered light wounds. Today, the army demolished two more homes in Gaza's Bureij refugee camp, raising the total in the past six weeks to 10, the army said. The two houses were home to 20 people, Arab reports said. The houses along with 30 shops were ordered destroyed after an Israeli soldier was stoned to death and his body burned when he accidentally drove his car into the camp on Sept. 20. The soldier apparently realized his mistake in entering the camp, and injured two youngsters when he hit a cart trying to speed out of El Bureij. At least one resident in each of the houses is suspected of involvement in the soldier's death. The army has destroyed more than 330 Palestinian houses during the nearly 35-month uprising against occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 771 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the uprising began in December 1987. An additional 294 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israeli authorities. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Boiler Explosion At Chemical Plant Kills Two
DOC.TEXT: An explosion of a boiler's steam line at the Aldrich Chemical Co. killed two men early today, officials said. The blast at about 12:45 a.m. damaged one of several buildings at the plant in the town of Wilson, about 25 miles north of Milwaukee, said Capt. Steve Dortman of the Sheboygan County Sheriff's Department. ``It didn't involve any chemicals, which were located elsewhere,'' he said. A 37-year-old man was pronounced dead after being taken to St. Nicholas Hospital at Sheboygan, Dortman said. A 25-year-old man injured in the explosion died several hours later at Memorial Medical Center in Sheboygan, the captain said. The names of the victims were not immediately released, pending notification of relatives. Dortman said the two were maintenance workers and had been investigating a problem with the boiler. There were no other injuries, Dortman said.

DOC.HEAD: More Fighting in Rwanda
DOC.TEXT: Fighting reportedly broke out in Rwanda again after the government said it had driven back rebel forces that invaded from Uganda. Meanwhile, a French Cabinet minister was scheduled to embark Tuesday on a mission to revive a peace initiative in Rwanda. French officials said Cooperation Minister Jacques Pelletier would confer with several African heads of state, including Rwanda's President Juvenal Habyarimana and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda. France has deployed 300 paratroopers in Rwanda to protect French civilians and diplomats and the airport in the event an evacuation was ordered. Several hundred French nationals already have left the central African country. State-run Rwanda radio said government troops blocked a rebel advance Sunday after the insurgents penetrated three miles into Rwanda from the Gatuna and Kaniga border posts. Uganda's official New Vision newspaper said the rebels captured the border posts after heavy fighting Saturday in which 35 government soldiers were killed and eight others were captured. New Vision also reported that the rebels had attacked in several other areas in the last five days, including the southeastern town of Rusumu on Rwanda's border with Tanzania and Burundi. The government on Thursday said it had retaken five towns in the country's northeast and driven the rebels back into Uganda. But rebel officer Lodviko Twahirwa told the newspaper other insurgents had hidden ``deep inside'' Rwanda. The rebels, many of whom deserted Uganda's army to join the invasion when it began last month, accuse Rwanda's government of corruption and say they want to replace it with a democracy in which all ethnic groups could participate. The rebel forces are drawn mainly from the hundreds of thousands of Tutsis who fled Rwanda in the late 1950s and early 1960s. At that time, the majority Hutu gained control in a bloody power struggle in which more than 10,000 Tutsi were killed. About 250,000 Rwandan refugees live in Uganda.

DOC.HEAD: Remembering The Broadway Career of Mary Martin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Martin would ...' to CORRECT tense in last sentence. Picks up 6th graf, `That's why ...' Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Obit-Martin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: No one could crow better than Mary Martin. Sure there were other Peter Pans - Sandy Duncan, for example, and even gymnast Cathy Rigby, who opens in a revival of the musical on Broadway next month. But Martin's cock-a-doodle was special. It started in the back of her throat, built slowly, almost impishly, and then roared out at the audience. Martin would crow anywhere. Tony Award shows. Banquets. High school auditoriums. Television talk shows. The middle of a busy Manhattan street. Even newspaper interviews. Just ask, and she obliged. That's why audiences liked her. She was down-to-earth. Texas friendly. Martin would dazzle them with her sweet, pure singing voice and make them laugh with her tomboyish charm and sense of fun. There are more wonderful photographic memories of Martin than any other Broadway star. Conjure up the following: Martin sitting on a trunk, innocently singing ``My Heart Belongs to Daddy'' in ``Leave It to Me'' or draped over a chair in ``One Touch of Venus,'' doing a sexy, witty rendition of ``That's Him'' or washing her hair on stage in ``South Pacific'' or flying high in ``Peter Pan'' or holding a guitar and singing to all those little children in ``The Sound of Music.'' The memories don't stop. And she never seemed to grow old. Her television taping of ``Peter Pan,'' the one preserved forever on videotape, was done in 1960 when she was 47. You'd never know it. The woman seemed eternally youthful. Theater critics loved Martin as much as theatergoers did. They would fall over their adjectives trying to find new ways to write Valentines to her. Harold Clurman, reviewing ``South Pacific,'' burbled ``When Mary Martin tells us, with radiant good nature, `I'm in love, I'm in love, I'm in love with a wonderful guy,' one doesn't murmur `Who cares?' but `Congratulations, congratulations, congratulations to you both!''' Even if the critics didn't like the show she was in, most of their notices were unabashed love letters. Wrote Walter Kerr in the New York Herald Tribune after Martin opened in ``Jennie,'' a somber, unhappy musical, ``Imagine having Mary Martin play an entire show with the corners of her mouth down! It's like using the moon not to make love by. ... Miss Martin forever, but not as Jennie.'' Martin was a Broadway star, one of the few performers whose name meant something special in the theater. She never much liked her movies or making them. Too impersonal. ``No time to think. It's shoot. Boom. If you don't get it right the first time do it again,'' she said of her Hollywood days. Ironically, it was television that cemented her theater career, making her even bigger box office on Broadway. Besides ``Peter Pan,'' she starred in a series of classy television specials - among them, a 1953 50th anniversary salute to the Ford Motor Co., that co-starred Ethel Merman; a 90-minute program with Noel Coward called ``Together with Music,'' and a television version of ``Annie Get Your Gun,'' co-starring John Raitt. These programs brought her an enormous audience that would turn into her staunchest theater supporters. ``I hope as I go out, I'm crowing,'' Martin once said. ``When that time comes, I'm ready for it.'' She may have been ready, but we weren't. Thank goodness for the RCA original cast recording of ``Peter Pan'' and the invaluable videotape just released on cassette last September. Those sounds and images won't fade.

DOC.HEAD: Shinto Shrine Set on Fire; Leftists Blamed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details, background, adds byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Shinto shrine in southern Japan was damaged by a fire early today, and police believe the attack was part of a terrorist campaign by leftist radicals who hope to disrupt next week's coronation. Officials on the island of Okinawa said no one was in the shrine at the time of the fire, which was quickly extinguished. There were no injuries. The attack came four days after two explosions rocked a police dormitory in Tokyo, killing one policeman and injuring six other people. If radicals were involved, police say, the shrine blaze would be the 62nd guerrilla incident this year and the 10th since Oct. 1, compared with only 27 incidents in all of 1989. Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion, is closely associated with the monarchy, and leftists view the emperor as a symbol of Japan's militarist past. Many critics contend that the Nov. 12 government-sponsored coronation ceremony, which has strong religious underpinnings, is a violation of the constitutional separation of church and state. The attacks by radicals have heightened fears that police efforts to guard the coronation may not be enough to keep radicals from causing trouble, a possibility officials grudgingly acknowledge. Police in Tokyo are mounting their largest security operation ever, with 26,000 officers - more than half the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department - already deployed on coronation-related assignments. At least another 6,000 reinforcements will be brought in from other police forces over the next week, bringing the total to 32,000 by coronation day. ``If they were to attempt an attack on the palace, we could stop them,'' a high-ranking police official recently told reporters. ``But when they disguise themselves as regular citizens, they are very hard to uncover.'' Police today raided several buildings used by Japan's two largest radical groups, the 5,000-member Chukakuha, or Middle Core Faction, and the Kakurokyo, or Revolutionary Worker's Association. No arrests were reported. About 70 officers, many clad in full riot gear, forced their way into the Kakurokyo's Tokyo headquarters. A radical who was in the building said the raid lasted about two hours. News reports said police believe a faction within the Kakurokyo, which has about 800 members, is responsible for Thursday's dormitory blasts. Police would make no official comment on those reports. They said today's raid was part of an investigation into a separate incident last month.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon to Call Up Reserve Combat Troops For Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs next-to-last graf, ``More than ...,'' to delete redundant language.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of combat troops from the reserves will be called up to join U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, The New York Times said today. More than 34,000 reservists have already been mobilized to perform support roles. The reservists, who could be in the Gulf early next year, will be among as many as 100,000 additional troops the Pentagon says it will send to the region in coming weeks, the newspaper said, citing unidentified Pentagon officials. The decision will be a major test of the use of active-duty soldiers alongside part-time combat forces. The Pentagon had earlier opposed calling up combat reservists on grounds the time needed to train them would cut into the 180-day limit they can now serve. Congress, in its waning hours last week, opened the way for a wider call-up when it doubled the limit on active-duty service for combat reservists to 360 days. The reservists serving in the Gulf include doctors, cargo plane pilots and water purification specialists. Army officials said combat reservists will train at Fort Irwin, Calif., where they will practice desert warfare techniques, according to the Times.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Cemetery Desecrated in Slovakia
DOC.TEXT: A Jewish cemetery in Slovakia was desecrated and tombstones painted with swastikas, a Prague newspaper reported today. The cemetery in Nitra - about 40 miles northeast of the Slovak capital, Bratislava - was vandalized on Friday, the independent daily newspaper Lidove Noviny said. It said police had not made any arrests. About 12,000 Jews live in Czechoslovakia, mostly in the Czech lands, but exact statistics are not available. Before the World War II, there were about 315,000 Jews living on Czechoslovak territory. Prague traditionally was one of Central Europe's most important cultural centers of Jewry. Following the collapse of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe, there has been an upsurge in anti-Semitism and racism directed at other groups. In Czechoslovakia, the main targets have been gypsies and guest workers from Cuba and Vietnam who were brought to the country by the former Communist government. Skinhead youths have fought with gypsies in several cities and towns. Vietnamese workers have been sent home en masse after violent clashes with workers at factories in Slovakia. Slovak nationalists are pushing for more autonomy, or even full independence for Slovakia, the country's smaller, more rural republic. It is home to about one third of the country's 15.5 million people. A commemorative plaque to former Slovak President Jozef Tiso, unveiled July in the central Slovak town of Banovce nad Bebravou, was removed after a series of protests in Czechoslovak media. Tiso served as the president of a Nazi puppet government from 1939 to 1945 in Slovakia. About 58,000 Jews from Slovakia were deported to the Auschwitz concentration camp under Tiso's rule.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Show Colorado, California Ready to Limit Politicians' Terms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to CORRECT that Missouri voters NOT voting on term limits; INSERTS graf after 4th graf, `Oklahoma voters...' to CLARIFY that Missouri court ruled similar measure off the ballot. Picks up 5th graf pvs: ``The rush...'' ^By CARL HILLIARD
DOC.TEXT: Illustrating the ill will against incumbents nationwide, voters in Colorado and California appear ready to limit how long politicians can hold office. ``The mood is real simple: Folks are really ticked or fed up with how legislative bodies are conducting themselves,'' said Los Angeles County Supervisor Pete Schabarum, a chief proponent of one of two term-limiting ballot measures in California. Recent polls predict approval for both. Elsewhere, voters in Kansas City, Mo., decide on Election Day whether to limit City Council members to two four-year terms. If approved, nine of 13 members would be forced out in April. Recent polls indicate voters favor the measure 3-to-1. Oklahoma voters recently approved a first-in-the-nation constitutional amendment limiting state lawmakers to 12 years in office. The amendment takes effect Jan. 1. A measure that proposed a state ethics commission to regulate lobbyists was ruled off Missouri's ballot by the state Supreme Court on Oct. 22. The rush by disgruntled voters this Election Day to limit terms is unprecedented, said Karl Kurtz, director of state services for National Conference of State Legislatures. Colorado's proposed amendment would impose eight-year limits on the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, treasurer, attorney general and state legislators. It would also hold each U.S. senator and representative from Colorado to 12 years in office, although some question the constitutionality of state-imposed limits on federal office. The U.S. Constitution imposes no limits on how long lawmakers may serve. A survey conducted Nov. 3 for The Denver Post and KCNC-TV showed 65 percent of those polled favored the proposal, 26 percent were opposed and 9 percent were undecided. In California, a survey Oct. 21-27 found 69 percent of those polled favored Proposition 140, the stricter of two similar measures in the state. That proposition would limit members of the Assembly to six years, or three terms. State senators and other politicians holding statewide office would be held to a total of two terms, or eight years. The measure would also cut the Legislature's staff by about 40 percent and eliminate legislators' retirement benefits. Proposition 131 would limit members of the Senate and Assembly to 12 consecutive years, or three terms in the Senate and six in the Assembly. Other statewide offices would be held to eight consecutive years or two terms. However, Proposition 131 would allow a legislator to serve 12 years, sit out a term and return for another dozen years. Proposition 131 is backed by consumer advocate Ralph Nader and the citizen lobby Common Cause. Most California legislators bitterly oppose both measures. If both are approved, the one with the most votes will prevail, according to a California Supreme Court ruling last week on a similar matter. The trend toward limiting terms illustrates voters' frustration with inaction on the budget, increasing taxes, dwindling government services and dishonest politicans, said Jim Monaghan, a Denver political consultant. ``One of the most disturbing things in politics is that it is one of a few professions where people aren't expected to tell the truth and get away with it,'' he said. Herrick Roth, a former Colorado state senator, said the argument for reform is simple: ``Incumbency in state legislative and executive offices is wrapped in its own security blanket, and for the Congress it is ditto in spades.'' However, Steve Bieringer, director of the AFL-CIO's Region XI, based in Denver, said prolonged incumbency is not a problem in Colorado. The state's congressional delegation has spent an average of eight years in office, he said. One senator is retiring and a representative resigned his seat to seek the Senate post, so the average will fall to five years after the election, ``hardly long enough that such a drastic measure is required,'' Bieringer said.

DOC.HEAD: Bachelor Offers $1,000 Reward to Person Who Finds Him a Mate
DOC.TEXT: Furniture maker Vernon L. Mefford is offering a real deal, and he's talking about more than just 10 percent off on a rocking chair. He's offering a $1,000 reward to anyone who helps him meet and marry his ideal woman. ``I'm trying a different way to meet the right person of my dreams,'' Mefford says. ``The standard way of dating just hasn't been very successful for me. I've just found it to be a painful and empty experience.'' Mefford, 44, has been wed twice before and has two grown sons from his first marriage. He said personal problems ended those marriages, but they didn't sour him to the idea of trying again. He has printed fliers describing the kind of woman he's looking for: a slender woman in her late 20s to early 40s with a beautiful smile and Christian values who is intelligent, honest and willing to reciprocate his love. On the other side of the flier is a price sheet for his handcrafted swings, rockers and end tables. ``I just hand it out to my customers, and when I go to trade shows I distribute the letter to everyone who comes by my booth,'' he said. Mefford figures he has made contact with about ``25 to 30 women so far.'' One of those is Robin Beck of Nashville, Ind. She called nnd they had a dinner date. ``I don't think we will get married, but I think I have made a good friend with him,'' Beck says.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Hour Warning Strike Hits Coal Mines
DOC.TEXT: Miners staged a two-hour warning strike at virtually all Poland's deep coal mines today to demand pay increases and protest the effects of economic reform on the crucial industry. The strike, called by the Solidarity miners union, affected some 70 hard coal mines. Only four of the country's mines were not involved but workers at those expressed sympathy for the job action, the official PAP news agency said. The protest was called after months of negotiations between the Solidarity-led government and the miners' unions produced no agreement on pay raises, Industry Ministry spokesman Jan Golab said. The Council of Ministers, led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, was to discuss the protest in the state-owned mining industry today, Golab said. But he said the demand for pay twice the national average ``cannot be met for economic reasons'' by the impoverished government treasury. Workers nationwide earn an average $126 monthly, but miners earn $179, Golab said. The miners say their economic situation is worsening and that they were promised higher salaries during the 1989 negotiations between the then-Communist authorities and Solidarity-led opposition. The growing unrest in the traditionally volatile industry comes three weeks before Poland's first popular presidential election. Mazowiecki faces Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa in a contest focused on the government's economic reforms. Coal is a crucial export for Poland and the main domestic energy source. The mines, mostly in the Silesia region of southwestern Poland, were heavily subsidized by the government under the socialized system and miners received many fringe benefits, including shops for goods in short supply. Post-Communist Poland is stripping away subsidies, forcing state industries to become self-sufficient as the country switches to a market-driven capitalist economy. But the mining industry is so economically unsound because of inefficiency, decades of artificially low, government-set prices for coal and other factors that high levels of support from the national treasury continue to be required.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix overline
KGB Major Arrested as Suspected Spy
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they had arrested a Soviet KGB major as part of an ongoing drive to round up Soviet spies in what was once East Germany. The now-dissolved East German state served as a major base for Soviet espionage efforts. The two Germanys merged on Oct. 3. Berlin police, in a statement, identified the arrested Soviet man only as Sergei P., and said he was 34. He was arrested over the weekend while meeting with a German contact in Potsdam, just outside Berlin, they said. Many Soviet soldiers are stationed in Potsdam. The German contact, identified only as Rainer K., had tipped off police, they said. Police have been urging German citizens to confess entanglements in intelligence activities and turn in their contacts. Police and Germany's federal intelligence service are trying to shut down old spy networks and prevent spies who once worked for East Germany's formidable Stasi secret police from going over to the Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Churches Seek to Unite in Opposing Apartheid
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Christian churches opposed to apartheid and those that long supported segregation met today in an effort to reach consensus on ending discrimination and building a new South Africa. ``For the first time there is the distinct possibility that the Christian churches can speak with one voice on apartheid and the country's future,'' the Rev. Frank Chikane, co-chairman of the conference, told the Sunday Times. He said Christian churches represent 78 percent of the population. The National Conference of Churches, billed as the largest such gathering ever in South Africa, has attracted about 300 delegates from 90 churches to Rustenburg, 60 miles northwest of Johannesburg. Virtually all the country's leading Christian clergymen were to attend the conference, which began today, including Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his anti-apartheid activism. The delegates will seek to reach agreement by the end of the conference Friday on what churches should do to help South Africa make a peaceful transition from apartheid to a non-discriminatory democracy. Many of the churches represented belong to the South African Council of Churches, often at the forefront of the anti-apartheid movement. Chikane is general secretary of the council. The white branch of the Dutch Reformed Church, which argued for decades apartheid was supported by the Bible, also was present. It is the main church of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who dominate the government. The Dutch Reformed Church now says that apartheid is wrong and has no biblical foundation. But virtually all Dutch Reformed Churches remain segregated. The church says it wants to merge with its black and mixed-race sister churches but no action is expected for several years. The black and mixed-race branches have staunchly opposed apartheid. Two relatively small white churches that still support apartheid declined to attend the conference. They were the Reformed Church and the Afrikaans Protestant Church, which broke from the Dutch Reformed Church in 1988 to protest moves away from apartheid. South Africa is predominantly Christian, with large numbers of Catholics, Anglicans, Methodists, Zionists and Pentecostalists. There are also many Jews and Moslems in South Africa. Last Christmas, President F.W. de Klerk called on the country's churches to develop a joint position on the role they envisioned playing in the country's future. De Klerk has promised to dismantle the apartheid system and negotiate a new constitution that would allow the country's 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Dissident Leader Awarded Human Rights Prize
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been under house arrest since July 1989, has won a Norwegian award for defending human rights in Burma. Ms. Suu Kyi was named winner of the annual Thorolf Rafto Memorial Prize for Human Rights, said a statement on Sunday from the Rafto Foundation based in Bergen, Norway. ``Aung San Suu Kyi personifies Burma's mass movement for democracy,'' the statement said. ``Through her courageous and devoted work for human rights and democracy, Aung San Suu Kyi has become the focal point of the Burmese opposition demanding an end to the iron-fisted military rule in the country.'' Ms. Suu Kyi, 45, is the daughter of the late Burmese independence leader Aung San. She is a leader of the National League for Democracy, which easily won elections in May. The military government has refused to yield power. The award statement said that under Burma's military rulers, ``massacres, extrajudicial executions, detention, torture and harassment has befallen thousands and thousands of peaceful civilians.'' Amnesty International and several Western governments and groups have made similar charges against the government, which came to power in September 1988 in a crackdown on the pro-democracy movement that left thousands dead. An independent expert sent by the U.N. Commission On Human Rights, Sadako Ogata of Japan, arrived in Rangoon on Saturday and is expected to seek a meeting with Ms. Suu Kyi. Political sources reached in Rangoon by telephone from Bangkok said the authorities were unlikely to allow the meeting. The military leader, Gen. Saw Maung, said on state radio Friday: ``What type of rights do they want? I am not the one to be investigated ... I tell you, if anyone wants to enjoy the human rights they have in the U.S., in England and India, provided that country accepts, I will permit them to leave.'' Saw Maung's latest crackdown has been against the Buddhist clergy who had protested alleged killings by soldiers in early August. On Wednesday, he banned unauthorized monks' groups and threatened dissident offenders with up to three years in prison. On Oct. 22, soldiers began raiding monasteries in the central city of Mandalay and arrested dozens of monks. Thorolf Rafto was a Norwegian professor and human rights advocate who died in 1986. Last year the Rafto prize was awarded jointly to the Hungarian youth opposition movement, FIDESZ, and to Romanian dissident Doina Cornea, who was kept under house arrest by President Nicolae Ceausescu for several years. The Rafto award carries a $4,200 prize.

DOC.HEAD: W. Virginia Red Cross Workers On Strike Today
DOC.TEXT: About 90 American Red Cross workers in West Virginia went on strike today in a contract dispute, but the agency said its services wouldn't be affected. Members of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Workers District 1199 went on strike at Red Cross officers in Beckley, Charleston, Huntington and Parkersburg, union spokesman David Mott said. Red Cross spokeswoman Evelyn Spencer said the Red Cross had a 7-to 10-day blood supply and would conduct normal business. ``We will have to depend on volunteers and professionals, but I have every hope that things will be resolved,'' Spencer said. ``I hope it will be a normal Monday.'' Mott said Red Cross workers average less than $5 per hour and ``are consistently paid $2 less per hour than comparable health care employees in this area.'' He said the company wants to take away some holidays, personal days and vacations. ``This is a multimillion-dollar corporation. They have people like Elizabeth Dole making $185,000 a year. Yet they are demanding concessions from workers,'' Mott said. Mrs. Dole resigned as secretary of labor last month to become president of the American Red Cross. Spencer said management is not asking for concessions but wants more control over sick days. ``Workers earn 12 sick days a year. By contro, we mean we need to have six of those days verified,'' she said. ``You call in sick. I say, `fine, you've had your six free days, now you have to have them verified by a doctor.'''

DOC.HEAD: New Powers for Sharon Draw Protest
DOC.TEXT: The government faced angry protests today over its decision to grant sweeping powers to Israeli immigration chief Ariel Sharon, who must provide housing for at least 1 million Soviets in the next two years. The government, meanwhile, said the pace of immigration was increasing, with 75,000 Soviets expected in the next two months. About 120,000 Soviets have arrived so far this year. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Cabinet voted Sunday to give Sharon a free hand in earmarking state lands as construction sites and awarding jobs to contractors. The center-left Labor Party and six other opposition factions responded by announcing motions of no confidence in the Cabinet to be submitted today in Parliament, said Sarah Yitzhaki, the parliamentary spokeswoman. Much of the anger results from Sharon's reputation as a maverick who ignores the rules to get things done. As defense minister in 1982, he failed to inform the Cabinet of his plans for an invasion deep into Lebanon, involving Israel in its most divisive war. Now he heads a special ministerial committee with responsibility for housing the wave of Soviet immigration, which is expected to total 1 million new arrivals before the end of 1992. Today, Sharon defended the Cabinet decision, which came by an 11-4 vote. He said he needed the new powers to speed up construction. ``We are in a true emergency, and we need to shorten the bureaucratic process,'' he said on Israel radio. He also accused his opponents of being unpatriotic. ``Those, who act out of narrow partisan motives at a time when the Israeli people have to deal with a great mission, do exactly the opposite of what we have to do,'' said Sharon. But some government officials and opposition leaders said the Cabinet decision could lead to widespread corruption. Among the opponents were Justice Minister Dan Meridor, a Shamir confidant, and Attorney General Yosef Harish. Some government lawyers argued Sharon's widespread powers could hold up building because contractors who felt wronged would appeal to the courts. Opposition leaders said they feared the decision would enrich contractors with Likud ties. ``With our own hands, we are opening the door to corruption,'' Shimon Shetreet, a Labor legislator, said on Israel radio. ``Even in a time of emergency, let us not develop a feeling that everything is permissible.'' The government was expected to survive today's confidence vote. But its fate could depended on the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel Party, which has five members in the 120-seat Parliament. The party has been negotiating for several months to join the government, but also told Labor leader Shimon Peres earlier this week it would consider voting to topple the Likud-led government.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Charged in Bribery Scandal Dies
DOC.TEXT: A judge charged last week with accepting bribes in an alleged immigration scam, has died, police said today. Eric Noseworthy, 41, died suddenly at his St. John's home on Saturday. The cause of death was not immediately announced. He had been awaiting trial after being charged on Tuesday with breach of trust, conspiracy, possession of property obtained by crime, and accepting commissions and rewards. Noseworthy was one of five people charged following a nine-month police investigation into an alleged scam involving Hong Kong residents obtaining Canadian citizenship. Lieut. Alex Kielly of the Royal Newfoundland Constabulary said police did not suspect foul play in Noseworthy's death. He refused comment when asked if the judge had killed himself.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Hear Appeal of Texas Woman in Parental Rights Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear the appeal of a Texas woman who says she lost parental rights over her young daughter because the free legal help she got was inadequate. The justices, over one dissenting vote, turned down a request to use the case to decide whether poor people may challenge the competency of their court-appointed lawyers when states seek to take away their children. Justice Harry A. Blackmun voted to hear arguments in the case, but four votes are needed to grant such review. In a series of decisions, the high court has ruled that poor criminal defendants facing serious charges have a constitutional right to free and effective legal help. And in a key 1984 ruling, the court said a defendant's conviction may be overturned if he or she can prove a court-appointed lawyer's deficiency calls into question the result's reliability. The justices in 1981 said poor people facing termination of parental rights may have a due-process right to free legal help, but the court never has said that such help must meet any specific standard of effectiveness. Nicolosa Barnes was stripped of parental rights to her daughter, Christina, in 1987 by the Dallas County Child Welfare Unit of the Texas Department of Human Resources. Court records indicate that Christina, then 5 years old, was suffering from malnutrition. Doctors said the child was frail and listless, and had bleeding sores in her mouth. One doctor said it appeared the child had been ``starved'' for two weeks. Mrs. Barnes' husband, Harold, also was stripped of parental rights to Christina. He did not appeal. The Barneses also have three sons, according to court documents. In the appeal acted on today, Mrs. Barnes said her court-appointed lawyer called no witnesses in the parental-rights termination hearing, made no prehearing investigation and failed to object to harmful and inadmissible evidence. ``When an indigent is entitled to appointment of counsel when the permanent deprivation of one's child is at stake, that counsel must be competent or the judgment should be set aside,'' the appeal contended. The Texas Supreme Court rejected Mrs. Barnes' appeal last March. The case is Barnes vs. Dallas County Child Welfare Unit, 90-5156.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling on Disabled Workers in Ohio Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that barred employee benefit plans from discriminating against workers who are disabled later in their careers. The court, without comment, rejected arguments by Ohio officials that younger workers forced to retire because of disabilities are entitled to greater benefits. The dispute between the Ohio Public Employees Retirement System and retired speech pathologist June Betts led to a ruling by the justices last year in favor of the state officials. The high court in 1989 said a state law permitting reduced benefits for Ms. Betts did not violate a federal law banning age bias in employment - unless she can prove intentional discrimination ``in some non-fringe benefit aspect of the employment relation.'' The ruling appeared to say workers charging age bias must prove that reduced fringe benefits were aimed, for example, at discouraging older workers from applying for jobs or were intended to force them to quit. But the 1989 decision was not the end of Ms. Betts' case. The high court sent it back to the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to determine whether she was forced to retire, and therefore may not be penalized with reduced benefits. The appeals court ruled her retirement was involuntary. Ms. Betts was a speech pathologist for the Hamilton County Mental Retardation Department. When her ability to work deteriorated because of health problems, she was given a choice by the state in 1985 of taking unpaid medical leave or retirement with a standard pension. She was barred from receiving more generous disability retirement benefits because she was 61. A provision of the state pension plan allows disability benefits only for those who worked for the state for at least five years and were under 60 when forced to quit. Ms. Betts' pension was $158.50 a month under the standard plan, compared to $355 a month she would have received in disability retirement benefits. The 6th Circuit court, re-examining the case after the 1989 high court ruling, said Ms. Betts was the victim of illegal age discrimination. ``She was denied the choice of disability benefits which would have been available to her had she been one year younger,'' the appeals court said. ``Employers may not force older workers involuntarily into less desirable retirement programs on the basis of age. Such coercive conduct constitutes involuntary retirement.'' The case is Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio vs. Betts, 90-451.

DOC.HEAD: Police Link Arrested Rebel Suspect to Killing of U.S. Officer
DOC.TEXT: The army said today it has arrested a suspected Communist rebel leader believed to have been involved in planning the 1989 killing of a U.S. Army colonel. In another development, the government has agreed to drop civil suits against one of the closest associates of the late President Ferdinand Marcos in exchange for his holdings in various Philippine companies, an official said. Maj. Gen. Guillermo Flores, chief of the Philippine army, identified the arrested rebel suspect as Reynaldo Bernardo. He said Bernardo is believed to be the intelligence chief and vice commander of the Manila wing of the Communist New People's Army, known as the Alex Boncayao Brigade. Flores said Bernardo helped plan the April 21, 1989 killing of Col. James Rowe near his office at the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group in suburban Quezon City. He said as the brigade's intelligence chief, Bernardo was ``deeply involved'' in the selection of ssassination targets. A team of soldiers and policemen arrested Bernardo on Sunday in Quezon City, Flores said. He said Bernardo was carrying ``very sensitive documents'' and had a pistol but did not resist arrest. The army commander said Bernardo would be charged with illegal possession of a firearm, and other charges would depend on results of interrogation. Word that civil suits were dropped against the former Marcos associate came today from Arthur Defensor, a member of the Presidential Commission on Good Government. He said the agreement with Roberto Benedicto was signed Saturday in Singapore. Benedicto, 73, was a classmate of Marcos and among the late ruler's closest associates. Under the agreement, Benedicto gave up assets and funds totaling about $43 million. He had previously turned over about $28 million in deposits in foreign bank accounts. Under the agreement, the government will release control over Benedicto's other assets and drop three civil suits against him. It was not certain whether Benedicto, who now has immunity under the settlement, will be called as a witness in 33 civil suits against the Marcos family. The government says Marcos stole billions of dollars from the national treasury during his administration.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Prosecution Of Cable Systems Carrying Playboy Channel
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let Puerto Rico prosecute some cable TV systems for carrying The Playboy Channel, rebuffing arguments that a lower court ruling unduly hampered states' anti-obscenity efforts. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that such prosecutions are pre-empted by federal law. In another obscenity case today, the court upheld an Illinois law that lets authorities seize the property of businesses convicted at least twice of obscenity violations. The court rejected the argument of Sequoia Books, Inc. that the law operates as a prior restraint on free expression. At issue in the Puerto Rico case was the effect of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, which imposes mandatory access obligations on cable operators whose systems have at least 36 active channels. The law says such operators must make available, on a first-come, first-served basis, a certain number of channels for commercial use by programmers not affiliated with the cable system. Once an unaffiliated programmer obtains access, the cable operator is prohibited from exercising any editorial control over the programming transmitted on that channel. But the federal law also states that cable operators cannot be held accountable for any libel, obscenity or false advertising carried on a channel it surrendered under the mandatory access provisions. In the spring of 1987, a prosecutor in Puerto Rico's Department of Justice notified cable operators that criminal obscenity charges would be filed against all systems transmitting The Playboy Channel. Within a few months, all cable systems but one - Teleponce Inc. - had dropped The Playboy Channel, which features so-called adult entertainment. Playboy Enterprises Inc., which through a wholly owned subsidiary distributed The Playboy Channel, and the Puerto Rico Cable Television Association, a trade group, then sued the island commonwealth's Department of Justice. The suit, invoking a federal civil rights law, accused Puerto Rico officials of unlawfully interfering with free-speech rights. U.S. District Judge Jaime Pieras Jr. barred authorities from taking any action against any cable operator carrying The Playboy Channel under the federal Cable Act's mandatory access provisions. The judge said local obscenity prosecutions of such cable operators were precluded by the federal law. The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that ruling last June. In the appeal acted on today, Puerto Rico Secretary of Justice Hector Rivera Cruz argued that the federal civil rights law invoked against his department should not be used to pre-empt obscenity law enforcement. He criticized the appeals court's ``omission of any reference to (the federal law's attempt) to preserve to the states the traditional police power in the enforcement of laws concerning any matter that is obscene or otherwise unprotected by the Constitution.'' Lawyers for Playboy Enterprises urged the justices to reject the appeal. They said the lower court rulings halted ``a concerted censorship campaign ... designed to intimidate cable systems,'' and that the civil rights law invoked in the lawsuit ``imposes no limitation on the enforcement authority of Puerto Rico beyond that imposed by the Cable Act itself.'' The case is Cruz vs. Playboy Enterprises, 90-491.

DOC.HEAD: Police Report 29 Blacks Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with death toll, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-nine blacks were fatally shot or stabbed, including several whose deaths may be linked to a feud between high school students in a township, police said today. Another eight of the deaths were believed to be the result of clashes between rival taxi companies, police said. Those deaths occurred when men traveling in vans randomly stabbed and shot people Sunday in the Kutloanong township, 140 miles southwest of Johannesburg, police said. Rival taxi groups began fighting one another last week in Kutloanong, resulting in the three deaths before Sunday's violence. Police said they were trying to determine whether Sunday's attack was linked to the earlier killings. There are about 100,000 privately owned taxi-vans operating in black areas nationwide, and violent disputes over routes and passengers occur regularly. Also, the daily police unrest report said 19 people were killed in Bekkersdal and one died in Alexandra. Both townships are outside Johannesburg. Also, a man was stabbed to death in Mganga Baboyi, a township in the eastern province of Natal, the unrest report added. Police Capt. Eugene Opperman said most of the deaths in Bekkersdal were the result of a fued between students who wanted to take final examinations and those demanding a boycott. Some students in townships have long demanded boycotts of the year-end exams to protest school conditions in the black townships. Opperman said the 19 deaths had occurred since Thursday, but he did not have a breakdown for each day. He also said it was not known how many were the result of the school feud, but he believed it was most of them. Another police official, Capt. Henriette Bester, said there were some incidents of arson and stone-throwing Monday in Bekkersdal. Thousands of blacks have died in township violence since 1986, most of it involving factional fighting between supporters of the African National Congress and the rival Inkatha Freedom Party. They are the country's two largest anti-apartheid groups but differ on tactics for fighting apartheid and on their idea for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Nursing Home Couple Lassoed By Love
DOC.TEXT: Two nursing home residents who sneaked off to South Carolina to be married have decided to leave the home and live together. Arnold Beck, 82, and Isabelle Summit Beck, 73, were married Aug. 31 in York, S.C. It was her second marriage and his fourth. They honeymooned in a borrowed cottage in Bessemer City but returned to their separate rooms at the nursing home. ``We don't feel too much like husband and wife because we're not together except during the day,'' Mrs. Beck said. Beck moved into a single room i South Haven nursing home in 1987 with his ailing third wife. She died shortly afterward. Mrs. Summit, who had been married 45 years to preacher Max Summit, was a widow when she moved to South Haven in 1988. ``I thought she'd be the last woman I ever hooked up with,'' Beck said. ``But she threw a lasso of love around me. I didn't love her at first. It just fell over me.'' A lifelong gospel singer, Mrs. Summit joined with Beck one night as he sang, ``No, Never Alone.'' Without even silverware, they're readying to move into an apartment by the end of November. Family members are scrambling to help. ``I think it's wonderful,'' said daughter-in-law Linda Summit. ``At (their age) they know what's best for them, I suppose.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev To Visit Germany Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will visit Germany Friday and Saturday and sign a 20-year friendship treaty between the two nations, the government said today. Dieter Vogel, spokesman for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said details of the visit were still being worked out. But he said Gorbachev was likely to visit Bonn and then Kohl's home in Oggersheim, 55 miles southwest of Frankfurt. The agreement Gorbachev and Kohl plan to sign is one of the most important bilateral agreements ever worked out between the two nations. The 20-year treaty reflects the two countries' hopes of laying to rest past enmity. Many Soviet citizens remain bitter over the carnage and death brought to their land by Adolf Hitler's armies. In the treaty, the two nations will pledge not to use force against each other and to respect the boundaries of all countries in Europe. The pact also creates the framework for German financial and technological help for the Soviet Union, and for intensified political and cultural ties. The document was initialed in Moscow on Sept. 13. The two leaders are also expected to talk about the Persian Gulf crisis and developments in Europe, said Vogel.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling That Property Of Obscenity Dealers Can Be Seized
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling allowing prosecutors to punish businesses convicted of dealing in obscenity by seizing their property. The court, without comment, rejected an adult bookstore's challenge to an Illinois anti-pornography law. The justices recently boosted efforts to crack down on obscenity. The court last year ruled in a case from Indiana that states may use anti-racketeering laws in the drive against adult bookstores and other businesses that sell or display sexually explicit material. But the court said in that ruling that prosecutors may not use such tough crime-fighting measures to shut down the businesses before trials are held to determine whether any of the material sold is obscene. Last month, the court left intact the forced closing by federal officials of three adult bookstores and nine video rental shops in Virginia. A lower court ruled that seizing their property after they were convicted of racketeering and selling obscene material did not violate the bookstore owners' free-speech rights. In the case acted on today, the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld an Illinois law challenged by Sequoia Books Inc., owner of the Denmark II bookstore in Kendall County. Sequoia Books was convicted of selling obscene materials 12 times between January 1985 and September 1987. An Illinois law that took effect Jan. 1, 1989, lets authorities seize property ``derived from or used to commit obscenity offenses.'' Any business convicted at least twice of obscenity violations is subject to forfeiting its property. The 7th Circuit court said the law may not be applied retroactively but said Sequoia's property may be seized for any obscenity violation from 1989 onward. The bookstore's owners said the law operates as a prior restraint on free expression. Fearing an obscenity conviction that could be economically devastating, the owners said they are forced to engage in self-censorship and stop selling adult-oriented material that may not be obscene. The 7th Circuit court rejected the argument, noting that the Illinois law is less sweeping than the seizure provisions of the federal anti-racketeering law that has survived similar challenges. A previous attempt by Illinois officials to use a public nuisance law to shut down the Denmark II bookstore was declared unconstitutional by the Illinois Supreme Court. The state court said officials may not use public nuisance laws to shut down establishments that sell non-obscene works merely because some obscene material was sold there. Sexually explicit material, often characterized as pornography, is not necessarily obscene. Obscenity, a legal term, must be determined in a judicial proceeding. Sexually explicit material judged obscene enjoys no free-speech protection. If the material is not found to be obscene, it is protected by constitutional free-speech guarantees. The case is Sequoia Books vs. Ingemunson, 90-454.

DOC.HEAD: Tuesday's Election Could Be Canceled, Election Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to update with secretary of state not attending hearing, additional argument against suit, picking up at the 7th graf previous, ``Twenty-two.''
DOC.TEXT: Tuesday's general election in Wyoming could be canceled if a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the ballot is successful, the state's top election official said. ``Wouldn't that be interesting if there was no election on Tuesday?'' asked Secretary of State Kathy Karpan, who is running for re-election. ``We might have a problem.'' Karpan initially planned to fly to Sweetwater County to attend a court hearing on the lawsuit today, but decided instead to remain in Cheyenne and try to arrange a telephone conference call with the judge. The lawsuit was filed Friday by Elaine Watkins, chairwoman of the Sweetwater County Democratic Party. She claims new electronic ballots are unconstitutional because the names of Republican candidates appear above Democratic candidates. The old ballots had the Republicans alongside the Democrats. ``What happens if the judge rules the ballot invalid?'' Karpan wondered. ``I hope we can still go forward with an election.'' She said today that if she got to talk to the judge she would argue that it's too late to challenge the ballot format. The code calls for any challenges to be made in the three days following publication of the ballot, which occurred two weeks ago, she said. Twenty-two of Wyoming's 23 counties have similar new ballots with the Republican candidates listed atop the Democratic candidates. Crook County still uses paper ballots that list the candidates horizontally. Karpan said she is confident the new ballots are constitutional. She argued that Wyoming law allows county clerks to modify the format of the ballot - from horizontal to vertical in this case - to adjust to new technology. In addition, she explained that Republicans are listed first because, under state law, the party of the U.S. House representative that won the majority of votes in that county in the previous general election comes first. Republican Dick Cheney beat Democrat Bryan Sharratt in every county in the state in 1988. The lawsuit asked the court for a declaratory judgment ruling the ballot and a section of the state election code unconstitutional. The lawsuit also sought preliminary and permanent injunctions ordering the Sweetwater County clerk to refrain from using the ballot format Tuesday. State Democratic Party Chairman Chuck Graves said the party is not trying to interfere with the election or set it aside, but will push the issue if it appears a candidate has been harmed by the contested ballot.

DOC.HEAD: `Buddy,' A Musical Biography of Buddy Holly, Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs at end with reviews from other critics. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Buddy Holly and Broadway don't mix. At least not in ``Buddy,'' a comic-strip cannibalization of the life of the rock 'n' roll legend, which opened Sunday at the Shubert Theater. There are basically two different shows on stage at the Shubert - one a dumb, dramatic biography with dialogue that would put Archie and Jughead to shame and the other an elaborate musical concert that makes some attempt to show why Holly was so important to pop music in the late 1950s. But the man behind such classics as ``Peggy Sue,'' ``That'll Be the Day'' and others deserves a better showcase for his material than a glorified sound-and-light show gussied up with elaborate posters and billboards featuring advertisements from 30 years ago. Perhaps the producers were afraid to let the songs stand by themselves, although Holly's life is not the stuff of great conflict. Writer Alan Janes is hard pressed to come up with anything beyond a straightforward recitation of the man's short musical career, which lasted only 18 months. ``Buddy'' chronicles Holly's rise from reluctant country and western singer in Lubbock, Texas, to rock 'n' roll star to his death at age 22. He never wanted to sing just country, a fact lost on myopic record producers in Nashville. Only when Holly and his band, The Crickets, hook up with manager Norman Petty, does their career take off. It would be nice if the show did, too, but Act 2 opens with a tedious episode about how Holly meets his future wife, Maria Elena, in a recording company office. The acting is primitive - broad, loud and embarrassing. The jokes are sledgehammered home with the confidence that they are funny. They're not. If the performers can't act, at least most of them can sing. That leads to the evening's one flicker of creativity - the recreation of Holly's last concert, the one he did with the Big Bopper and Ritchie Valens the night they were killed in a light plane crash. The horn-rimmed Paul Hipp, dressed for much of the evening in blue jeans, white socks and black penny loafers, sings well as Holly. He even sounds a little like the man. And there are acceptable impersonations of the Big Bopper by David Mucci and Ritchie Valens by Philip Anthony. The songs do have a nostalgic appeal, pop anthems that harken back to a simpler time when ``American Bandstand,'' not MTV, ruled the airwaves. To its credit, the music for ``Buddy'' is performed live and is not canned. There's no lip-synching and that sense of live music can get the audience going. At one of the final preview performances, a crowd of aging and out-of-shape baby boomers worked themselves into hand-clapping exhaustion during the final concert sequence. It would be wise for the Shubert to have its house physician in the theater during all performances. What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: ``It's too bad that the beginning of `Buddy' is not nearly so happy as the ending. ... Not content to give its customers the 1950s equivalent to `Beatlemania' that they came for, the creators of `Buddy' pad the evening with a superficial, extremely talky biographical drama that makes the puffy 1940s Hollywood biographies of Tin Pan Alley composers look like `Citizen Kane.''' Howard Kissel, the Daily News: ``If `Buddy, The Buddy Holly Story' were an audio-animatronics exhibit at Disney World, you could praise it for being uncannily lifelike. But considering that it appears to be written and performed by humans, I'm afraid it's not lifelike enough. ... The depressing thing is that the audience responds as if they were watching an actual concert, rather than an imitation. Real, fake - it seems like an event and the crowd is so hungry to be associated with one they go along with it.'' Clive Barnes, New York Post: ``The premise is flimsy but, oh, boy! the premises are jumpin' ... `Buddy' ... is little more than a rock concert set to Broadway. But what a rock concert! ... I like it.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees to Use California Murder Case to Set New Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to use a California murder case to set new guidelines for federal court appeals by convicted defendants who say their rights were violated. The justices said they will hear an appeal by state officials in the case of Owen Duane Nunnemaker, sentenced to life in prison for murdering his estranged wife in 1975. The court is expected to announce a ruling by July. Nunnemaker shot his wife, Alice, in her home in Sebastopol. He testified that he did not recall the shooting and did not intend to kill her. At his trial, Nunnemaker's lawyer objected to statements made by a state psychiatrist but did not claim the psychiatrist violated the defendant's rights by questioning him without warning him of his right to remain silent and to have an attorney present. Some 10 years later, Nunnemaker began a new round of state court appeals, arguing the psychiatrist violated his rights. The appeals were unsuccessful, culminating with the California Supreme Court denying him a hearing without comment. Nunnemaker then turned to the federal courts for help. A federal judge ruled that the defendant was barred now from arguing the psychiatrist violated his rights because no such claim was made at his trial. But the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the judge's ruling in May and ordered the judge to conduct further hearings. The appeals court said the state Supreme Court's failure to explain why it denied Nunnemaker's appeal opens the way for further federal court review. Such federal court appeals are called habeas corpus petitions - post-conviction challenges by defendants who say their rights were violated. Relying on a U.S. Supreme Court ruling last year, the 9th Circuit court said, ``Where a state supreme court does not plainly state in its summary denial of an original habeas petition that its ruling rests on a state procedural bar, federal review is not precluded.'' The U.S. Supreme Court in 1989 revived a Chicago murderer's challenge to his conviction. The justices in that case said the defendant had lost a state court appeal on ambiguous grounds because the state court did not say clearly that it was relying on procedural grounds to foreclose any new federal court appeal. The California attorney general's office said the 9th Circuit court ruling will permit ``cynical manipulation of the post-conviction remedies provided by the state and federal systems.'' The state lawyers said hundreds of cases each year in California will be affected. The case acted on today is Ylst vs. Nunnemaker, 90-68.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Investigates Klan Posters Found at Post
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army is investigating the appearance of racist posters at a military post in Frankfurt, a spokeswoman said today. Frankfurt military community spokeswoman Brigitte Schmitz said the posters appeared last month in the military's Ambassador Arms hotel. She commented after a report on the incident appeared in the Stars and Stripes newspaper. ``The investigation is still ongoing, but has not advanced very far yet,'' Ms. Schmitz said. The spokeswoman said a $1,000 reward had been offered for information leading to the arrest of those who put up the posters. The posters invited people who are ``tired of rap music, AIDS and being intimidated because you're white, to be a part of a group fighting to stop such things for 120 years,'' the newspaper said. The posters had the Ku Klux Klan insignia and a telephone number to call in the United States for more information. The number is no longer in service. Military regulations forbid membership in extremist organizations. The Klan is on a list of organizations off limits to service members and dependents and U.S. civilian employees of the military. Maximum sentence for violation of the regulation is a dishonorable discharge and up to two years imprisonment, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Crain's: Advertisers of Strike-Bound News Heading for Radio
DOC.TEXT:
Advertisers in the strike-bound Daily News are turning to radio rather than other newspapers in the city, but many of the stations are already heavily booked, a business publication reported today. Crain's New York Business reported radio is drawing advertisers who are concerned that the New York Post and New York Newsday, the city's other two tabloids, don't provide the right mix of readers.
Many radio stations, however, can't handle the extra advertisers because their ad load has increased for the holiday season, Crain's said. ``I have problems with the Post because of the editorial content,'' said Harvey Berman, president of the Harvey Berman ad agency. ``We would consider radio; however, last weekend I tried to get a news radio package for a client, but couldn't get the time.'' The 71-year-old News trudged ahead Sunday, handing out free samples and using ``hawkers'' to sell newspapers on the street where vendors feared union intimidation. The press run was about 600,000. News' spokeswoman Lisa Robinson said 50,000 copies were given away. ``We're still seeing gaps in distribution,'' she said. ``Many, many people support us. Some people don't.'' The News, the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily, had a Sunday circulation of about 1.2 million before the strike began Oct. 25. Nine of the newspaper's 10 unions went on strike. Some union members have returned to work, but about 2,000 remain off the job. Negotiations that began in January over contracts that expired in March have been fruitless. The unions charge unfair labor practices.

DOC.HEAD: Eat Less Fat, More Fruit and Vegetables, Government Advises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 3-5, Health and Human Services, with Sullivan quote.
DOC.TEXT: Americans should eat less fat and cholesterol and more vegetables, fruits and grains, according to new federal dietary guidelines issued today. The guidelines differ little from the last set, issued in 1985, although the new ones offer more information, including recommended limits on the amount of fat in a healthy diet. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan acknowledged that the guidelines were ``no earth-shattering thing,'' but he said their specificity would make them easier for Americans to understand and follow. The guidelines ``can make all the difference between good health and illness, between long life and premature death,'' he said. ``Americans who ignore them do so at their own peril,'' said Sullivan, who released the guidelines with Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. Both secretaries rejected criticism from a consumer group that the new guidelines are weaker than the 1985 set. The guidelines, which apply to people 2 years and older, make seven different points: -Eat a variety of foods. -Maintain healthy weight. -Choose a diet low in fat, saturated fat and cholesterol. -Choose a diet with plenty of vegetables, fruits and grain products. -Use sugars only in moderation. -Use salt and sodium only in moderation. -If you drink alcoholic beverages, do so in moderation. The guidelines suggest that depending on body size and activity level, a healthy diet consists of 3-5 servings daily of vegetables; 2-4 servings of fruit; 6-11 servings from the food group that includes breads, cereals, rice and pasta; 2-3 servings of milk, yogurt and cheese; and 2-3 servings of meats, poultry, fish, dry beans and peas, eggs and nuts. The amount of food in a serving depends on the food. For example, for vegetables, one cup of raw leafy greens or a half cup of other kinds constitute a serving. Other one-serving amounts include one slice of bread; half a bun, bagle or english muffin; one ounce of ready-to-eat cereal; a half cup of cooked cereal, rice or pasta; one medium apple, orange or banana; one cup of milk; and 1.5 ounces of cheese. They also recommend that total fat provide 30 percent or less of calories daily, and that saturated fat, which is mainly from animal products and tropical oils, be limited to less than 10 percent of total calories. The guidelines define moderation in drinking alcoholic beverages: for women, one drink per day, and for men, no more than two drinks a day. One drink means 12 ounces of regular beer, five ounces of wine or 1.5 ounces of distilled spirits, 80 proof, according to the federal document. In several places, they make special recommendations for pregnant women, saying they may need additional nutrients and should not drink alcoholic beverages. John R. Cady, president of the National Food Processors Association, said the new guidelines recognize that there are no bad foods, but rather bad diets. Cady said his group would use the guidelines as a basis for a national food label education program to help consumers when new food labels are introduced. Cady's group, which represents the makers of most of the nation's processed and packaged food products, is leading that effort. But the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a nonprofit consumer advocacy group, contended that the new guidelines are weaker than the 1985 ones. Also, they do not heed the advice of the National Academy of Sciences and the surgeon general, the center said. ``This document is clearly designed not to offend the meat, egg and dairy industries,'' said Jayne Hurley, associate nutritionist at the center. ``It represents the least common denominator of nutrition advice,'' she said. ``This is a Band-Aid and the American diet needs surgery.'' She criticized the guidelines for advising people to use salt and sugar ``in moderation.'' The 1985 dietary suggestions said people should ``avoid too much'' salt or sugar. She also noted that the National Academy of Sciences advises that an ideal diet should contain no more than 7 percent or 8 percent of calories from saturated fat, compared with 10 percent in the new guidelines. She criticized the guidelines for recommending no specific limits on cholesterol or sodium. The National Academy of Sciences recommends no more than 200-250 milligrams of cholesterol and 1,800 milligrams of sodium per day, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Mississippi Case on Filing Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that someone suing more than one defendant generally does not have to include all of them in the same lawsuit. In a unanimous unsigned opinion, the court revived a suit by a Mississippi man stemming from his back surgery in 1986. The patient, Billy J. Temple, had a plate and screw device implanted in his lower spine. The screws broke off inside his back. The operation was performed by Dr. S. Henry LaRocca at St. Charles General Hospital in New Orleans. The device was made by Synthes Ltd. Temple sued the manufacturer in federal court in Louisiana. He filed a separate negligence and malpractice suit against the doctor and hospital in Louisiana state court. A federal judge threw out the suit against Synthes and the decision was upheld by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The federal courts said Temple should have sued all three defendants together. The Supeme Court today reversed those rulings. The high court said, ``It has long been the rule that it is not necessary for all joint tortfeasors (defendants in personal injury cases) to be named as defendants in a single lawsuit.'' The court rejected arguments by Synthes that a 1966 revised court rule changed that principle. The justices said that while they encourage ``judicial economy'' and efficiency by suing all defendants together, there is no evidence LaRocca and the hospital are indispensable to the case against Synthes. Temple's hometown was not available in court papers here. The case is Temple vs. Synthes, 90-295.

Homosexual Soldier Wins Court Battle to Re-Enlist
DOC.TEXT: A homosexual soldier today won a Supreme Court battle to re-enlist in the Army despite the military's ban on homosexuals.
