The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court decision requiring the Army to allow Perry Watkins of Seattle to re-enlist. Watkins is a 16-year veteran with an excellent service record. Today's action does not affect in any sweeping way the military's ban on homosexuals. The case nevertheless has been closely watched by gay rights advocates. The appeals court ruling in Watkins' case did not address the validity of the ban, but noted that the Army repeatedly had re-enlisted Watkins while knowing he is gay. ``Sgt. Watkins has greatly benefited the Army, and therefore the country, by his military service,'' an 11-judge panel of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said last year. ``In addition, Watkins' homosexuality clearly has not hurt the Army in any way ... Equity cries out and demands that the Army be estopped (prohibited) from refusing to re-enlist Watkins on the basis of his homosexuality.'' In other action, the court: - Agreed to use a California murder case to set new guidelilnes for federal court appeals by convicted defendants who say their rights were violated. The justices said they will hear an appeal by state officials in the case of Owen Duane Nunnemaker, sentenced to life in prison for murdering his estranged wife in 1975. - Let stand a ruling that lets prosecutors punish businesses convicted of dealing in obscenity by seizing their property. The court, without comment, rejected an adult bookstore's challenge to an Illinois anti-pornography law. - Refused to let some Puerto Rico cable TV systems be prosecuted for carrying The Playboy Channel, rebuffing arguments that states' anti-obscenity efforts may be hampered unduly. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that such prosecutions are pre-empted by federal law. - Left intact a ruling by Ohio's highest court in a nationally publicized child-custody case that said the public has no right to attend juvenile court proceedings. The justices, without comment, rejected a Columbus, Ohio, newspaper's arguments that the Constitution requires most juvenile court hearings to be public. - Let stand a ruling that barred employee benefit plans from discriminating against workers who are disabled later in their careers. The court, without comment, rejected arguments by Ohio officials that younger workers forced to retire because of disabilities are entitled to greater benefits. The appeals court vote in the homosexual soldier case was 7-4. In the appeal rejected today, Bush administration lawyers had argued that the federal government never should be barred from applying a valid regulation such as the Army's ban on homosexuals. Watkins was drafted during the Vietnam war, in 1967. He was 19. In filling out a pre-induction medical form, he marked ``yes'' in answering a question that asked whether he had homosexual tendencies. He was inducted anyway, and subsequently was allowed to re-enlist three times. After two tours of duty in Korea, Watkins was stationed at Fort Lewis, near Tacoma. From 1967 through 1980. he was the subject of three Army investigations. Each one was sparked by Watkins' telling some superior about his homosexuality, but after each investigation he was allowed to re-enlist. In 1981, the Army adopted a new regulation requiring the discharge of all homosexuals. A review board in 1982 voted to discharge Watkins, but before the discharge orders were issued a federal judge barred the Army from taking such action. Seven years of court maneuvering and conflicting rulings followed before the 11-judge panel's ruling last year. But Watkins was forced to accept an honorable discharge in 1984 after a three-judge appeals court panel voted against him. His lawsuit against the Army sought reinstatement with back pay. He would be eligible for a full Army pension with four more years of service. The 1989 ruling in favor of Watkins did not say he was entitled to back pay, and implied the Army could try to discharge him for any future homosexual acts. But the ruling said the Army ``may not attempt to discharge Watkins for any alleged homosexual acts that were the subject of past discharge proceedings or for any past or future statements by Watkins acknowledging his homosexuality.'' The case is U.S. vs. Watkins, 89-1806.

DOC.HEAD: Bill of Rights Tour Draws Anti-Helms Protesters
DOC.TEXT: At least 200 people, mostly schoolchildren, walked a gauntlet of protesters to look at an original copy of the Bill of Rights that went on display today in Maine's capital. ``Ask your teacher who Jesse Helms is,'' about a dozen demonstrators from an AIDS coalition group chanted, referring to North Carolina's conservative, Republican U.S. senator. The demonstrators from the Maine chapter of AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, claims Philip Morris is the largest corporate donor to Helms' re-election campaign. Helms has drawn the wrath of the group and other people for consistently voting against gay rights and bills to help people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The Bill of Rights copy is on a national tour to mark the document's 200th anniversary. The tour is sponsored by Philip Morris Companies Inc., a tobacco, food and beverage giant. Demonstrators held up signs that read: ``Philip Morris Bill of Rights tour is a politlcal sham.'' They urged consumers to boycott the company's products. With lyrics from the rap group 2 Live Crew blasting from an amplifier, a half-dozen people demonstrated against attempts to ban rock lyrics under attack as sexually explicit or otherwise offensive. ``If it's 2 Live Crew this week, who will it be next week?'' said Chris Kenoyer, leader of a group called Rock the Vote. Three members of the rap group were acquitted last month of obscenity charges after their ``Nasty As They Wanna Be'' was banned in a Florida county. A multi-media display accompanies the Bill of Rights. The display will be at the Augusta Civic Center for four days. Visitors passed through metal detectors to get to the elaborate display. Augusta was the fifth stop on a 26,000-mile tour that will take the document to all 50 states. The tour began Oct. 10 in Vermont and also has been to New Hampshire, Rhode Island and New York. The tour will end in Virginia in February 1992. There have been similar demonstrations in other states. The Bill of Rights copy on display includes 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution and two that were proposed but not approved by the states.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Consider Reinstating Age-Bias Lawsuit Against IRS in Texas Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider reinstating an age-bias lawsuit against the Internal Revenue Service by an employee working in Austin, Texas. The justices said they will review rulings that Charles Stevens III waited too long to sue the IRS. At issue is an interpretation of the federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA). Depending on how the high court rules, in a decision expected by July, suing under the act could become a bit easier or a bit more difficult. Stevens was employed at the IRS Austin Service Center for 19 months before being promoted for a probationary period to a better-paying job in 1986. But in the spring of 1987, during the probationary period, he was returned to his old job. Stevens, 63, said age discrimination was the reason. The merits of his allegation, however, have never been ruled on. A federal judge, and then the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, ruled that Stevens' suit was barred because he had waited too long before filing it. Under the ADEA, federal employees who believe they have been discriminated against because of their age have two avenues of relief. They may sue in federal court as long as they give notice of their intent to sue within 180 days of the allegedly unlawful action. Or they may file a complaint within 30 days with the employing agency, and appeal any adverse ruling to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Stevens waited beyond 30 days before filing a complaint with the IRS, and the complaint was dismissed as untimely. Stevens gave notice of his intent to file his federal lawsuit 176 days from the date of the alleged discrimination - within the legal deadline. But the lower courts ruled that Stevens' failure to comply with the complaint-filing deadline also required the dismissal of his separate lawsuit. The case is Stevens vs. Department of Treasury, 89-1821.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Rock Mobil Refinery, Fires Put Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS overline and 4th graf `Mobile employee ...' to CORRECT spelling of Mobil, sted Mobile.
DOC.TEXT: A series of explosions shook a Mobil Oil Corp. refinery and set off a fire that severly burned an employee, authorities said. The first explosion occurred about 11:30 p.m. Sunday. The fire was put out by early today, officials said. The fire erupted in a unit used for gasoline refining, said plant safety manager Jack Cohn. The cause was not immediately known, he said. Mobil employee John Oler, 38, of Chalmette was taken to Chalmette Medical Center and transferred to West Jefferson Hospital with burns over 70 percent of his body, said Donna Shields, a spokeswoman for the medical center. The plant was not evacuated and all employees were accounted for, officials said. Richelle Lewis, who lives about five miles away in Miro, said she heard a ``loud whoom followed by three explosions. I turned around and the sky was all red.'' The refinery is about six miles east of New Orleans.

DOC.HEAD: High Court In Stuart Case: Attorney's Mouth `Forever Sealed'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15 graf, `Charles Stuart ...' with three grafs to ADD background on killing and police search. Pick up 16th graf, `But Stuart ...'
DOC.TEXT: Charles Stuart's lawyer does not have to testify to a grand jury about a conversation he had with his client the day before Stuart leaped to his death from a bridge, the state Supreme Court ruled today. The court in a 4-1 ruling said John T. Dawley's attorney-client privilege was not undone with his client's suicide on Jan. 4 that threw a final twist in the deeply mysterious plot to kill Stuart's wife, Carol. ``The mouth of the attorney shall be forever sealed,'' the court wrote. ``The privilege of insisting that the attorney keep confidential the client's disclosures made to the attorney in his or her professional capacity belongs only to the client, and therefore can be waived only by the client,'' the court said in a decision written by Justice Francis P. O'Connor. The Suffolk County District Attorney's office had wanted Dawley to testify before a grand jury gathering evidence in the death of Carol Stuart, a tax attorney who was shot and killed Oct. 23, 1989. Dawley met with Stuart for about two hours on Jan. 3, and investigators contend that the 30-year-old fur store manager admitted to his lawyer that he killed his wife. The next day, Stuart jumped to his death off the Tobin Bridge into Boston Harbor. Officials at the district attorney's office were in conference this morning and could not immediately be reached for comment. Dawley declined to comment on the court's ruling until he received a copy. ``I'd like to read it before I comment on that,'' he said. A grand jury has met periodically since, attempting to piece together details of the crime. No charges have been filed. Suffolk County Assistant District Attorney Thomas Mundy argued that the grand jury would be deprived of ``potentially relevant information'' if Dawley did not testify. Paul Leary, first assistant district attorney, said the grand jury, which has made little progress in recent weeks, has been waiting for the decision on Dawley. But attorneys representing the Stuart family argued that the court would be setting a dangerous precedent by tampering with the attorney-client privilege. Charles Stuart originally told police he and his pregnant wife were attacked by a lone, black gunman in their car after they left a birthing class. The couple's baby, delivered prematurely after the shooting, died 17 days later. Stuart, shot in the stomach, called police on his cellular phone and when he lost consciousness emergenc operators located him by listening for police car sirens heard over the phone. The case intensified racial friction in Boston after police stormed homes in a black neighborhood in search of Mrs. Stuart's killer. But Stuart became the prime suspect after his brother, Matthew, implicated him in the crime. Matthew Stuart told authorities that under his brother's instructions, he drove to the crime scene and retrieved several personal belongings of Carol Stuart, plus a gun believed to be the murder weapon. Dorothy Stuart, Stuart's mother and the executor of his estate, has told the grand jury she couldn't waive her son attorney-client privilege, and she would not have done so if the law had allowed her. The state had argued that Stuart, having died, ``no longer can be harmed by the disclosure of his communications to his attorney'' and that the privilege should be overridden because of ``society's interest'' in finding who killed Carol Stuart and her son. But the court disagreed with that contention, saying that ``the client's and the public's interests are best served by a rule of confidentiality that applies both before and after the death of the client.'' In his dissent, Justice Joseph R. Nolan said that despite the court's ruling, attorney-client privilege is not absolute, and the possibility that Charles Stuart did not kill his wife meant the killer could still be on the loose. ``Under the court's analysis, there is no `safety valve,' no mechanism by which the attorney-client privilege may ever be overridden by the court in the interests of justice,'' Nolan wrote. ``I would argue the court to adopt this very narrow `interests of justice' exception.'' Leo V. Boyle, president of the Massachusetts Bar Association, said the attorney client privilege ``is of ancient origin, and is at the heart of the delivery of justice. Once you bend the law for a single case, no matter how tragic, the legal framework of our society starts to crumble. The court did the unpopular thing, but undoubtedly the right thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Because of Redistricting, Legislative Races Are High Stakes
DOC.TEXT: Allyson Schwartz kicked off her state Senate campaign with a 15-mile bike ride and has spent endless hours doing what's expected of legislative candidates: knocking on doors, staking out supermarkets and greeting commuters at train stops. She's also spent more than $500,000 just to keep pace with her opponent, Republican Sen. Joe Rocks. ``There's a lot at stake in this race,'' Schwartz says. The nation's political map will be redrawn next year to reflect population shifts of the last decade. Most of the work will be done in state legislatures. And the finished product will go a long way in determining which party will make gains in 1992 House races - and whether Republicans have any hope of climbing out of the minority beforethe close of the century. The Schwartz-Rocks contest is just one of more than 6,100 legislative races to be decided across the country Tuesday. In the high-stakes battle for redistricting leverage, about 50 of those races in a dozen states will make the difference, deciding which party controls legislative chambers that are held by slim majorities. National political party organizations have paid close attention to oft-ignored state races this year, offering candidates lots of advice and, more important, money. ``Control of redistricting is control of your future,'' said Tim Dickson, director of the Democratic Party's major redistricting arm, Project 500. In Pennsylvania, Democrats control the state House and Democratic Gov. Robert Casey appears headed for re-election. Republicans need to keep their majority in the state Senate for leverage in redistricting, which likely will cost Pennsylvania two seats in Congress. If Democrats pick up three state Senate seats, the party would have a coveted redistricting monopoly and could squeeze out two Republicans. Pennsylvania Democrats think their chances may rest on the Schwartz-Rocks contest. ``I'm in the toughest fight in Pennsylvania,'' Rocks says. There are similar struggles in several other major redistricting battlegrounds. Democrats are trying to steal control of the state Senates in New York, Ohio, Michigan, Arizona and Indiana. The lower houses in Arizona and Indiana also are within reach for Democrats. Republicans are defending their control of those chambers and trying to erase slim Democratic majorities in the Florida and Illinois senates and the lower chambers in Pennsylvania and Oregon. Gubernatorial races in several states, including the three biggest redistricting prizes - Florida, Texas and California - also will have a huge role in determining who draws the all-important new district lines. Democrats have a decided edge entering Tuesday's vote. They already control 69 of the nation's 99 legislative chambers, including total control in Florida, Texas and California, three states that are likely to gobble up 14 of the 19 shifting seats. ``We're looking at a situation here where it's vital for us to hang on to what we have just to be in a divided or split position,'' said Tom Hoeffler of the National Republican Congressional Committee. Such high stakes translates into hefty spending: The Rocks-Schwartz matchup is one of a handful of state legislative races that will cost $1 million or more. The extra money has allowed candidates in targeted races to hire big-name consultants for flashy mailers and radio ads, polling and to build phone banks to get out the vote. Most - but not all - of the candidates welcome the attention. ``I regret all of this in a way,'' said Jerry Denbo, an insurance salesman in French Lick, Ind., who may be the Democrats' best hope for erasing the GOP's razor-thin majority in the Indiana House. ``I'd really rather it be decided by the people in these counties,'' he said. South Bend lawyer Joe Donnelly seemed surprised when told the people at Democratic Party headquarters in Washington figured their chances of capturing the Indiana Senate might come down to his effort to oust an incumbent Republican. ``I didn't realize that,'' Donnelly said. ``I better win.'' It's not just in states that are losing or gaining congressional seats that legislative races are getting extra attention. All congressional districts have to be redrawn, even if a state's delegation is unchanged. In most states, the legislature is charged with redrawing its own districts as well. Because of that, even getting enough seats to be a viable minority - or to prevail in veto battles - is important. In the 75-member Utah House, Democrats are scrambling just to remain a one-third minority, figuring if they can keep their 27 seats they'll be able to scream loudly enough to have some input when the state districts are redrawn. ``The Republicans have promised to reapportion us out of existence,'' said Democratic state Rep. Frank Pignanelli, the minority whip. ``They accomplished it in 1980 ,and if they do it again this really will be a one-party state.''

DOC.HEAD: Rape Trial Beginning Involving Victim Who Claims 21 Identities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with jury selection beginning; INSERTS one graf after 6th graf, `The defense ...' to UPDATE with judge saying jury will be sequestered. Pick up 7th graf, `Defense attorney ...'
DOC.TEXT: A young woman who claims to have 21 personalities may herself be on trial this week as much as the man accused of raping her. The trial, which has raised new questions about sexual consent and mental illness, began today with jury selection in state court, where the prosecution is expected to call to the stand six of the personalities documented by psychiatrists. Mark A. Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh, is charged with second-degree sexual assault, which carries up to 10 years in prison. Prosecutors claim he had sex with one of the woman's personalities after learning she was mentally ill. Under Wisconsin law, a person with a mental illness or deficiency so severe that he cannot understand the consequences of his behavior is incapable of consenting to sex. It will be up to the jury to decide whether the woman in the case is ill to that degree. ``I have to prove that it (multiple personality disorder) is real and she's got it,'' District Attorney Joe Paulus said. ``In a case like this, there are always going to be skeptics.'' The defense is expected to argue that the alleged victim, a 27-year-old single woman from Oshkosh, is not mentally ill and that even if she is, Peterson did not know it. Judge Robert Hawley said the jury will be sequestered during the trial. A jury was expected to be seated and opening arguments to begin later today. Defense attorney Edward Salzsieder said he would try to convince the jury the woman was putting on a ``big show.'' He said the nature of the case requires the woman to go on trial as much as the defendant. The woman took the stand during a riveting preliminary hearing in August, blinking her eyes and pausing each time she was asked to switch personalities. The judge required her to take an oath each time. Each time, she was introduced to the lawyers in the case. Revealing the alternate personalities to the jury is ``my vehicle to show the victim's credibility,'' the prosecutor said. ``They are going to get to see her the way she is. She is a person of several personalities.'' Paulus said he would probably ask the woman to reveal six personalities. Defendants have claimed multiple personality disorder in mounting an insanity defense, but legal experts said they were not aware of any case in which such a disorder in a victim formed the crux of a case. Paulus said the case ``is really all about protecting the rights of mentally ill people, regardless of what type of mental illness they have.'' Inam Haque, a psychiatrist at Winnebago Mental Health Institute in Oshkosh, has testified he treated the woman for four years and diagnosed her in February as suffering from multiple personality disorder. The disorder is triggered by emotional or physical trauma during childhood; victims create separate personalities to avoid confronting reality. It affects about 7,000 people in the United States, psychiatrists said. Peterson has said the woman agreed to have sex with him in a car June 11 after he picked her up for a date. She testified that she told Peterson she had many personalities and that he took advantage of one of them, Jennifer, a fun-loving 20-year-old. During the preliminary hearing, the woman summoned three identities - herself, Jennifer, and Franny, a 32-year-old motherly type who reported the alleged rape to friends. The woman, who earned an associate degree in law enforcement from an Iowa college, has other personalities called Animal, Shadow and Emily, according to testimony. One of her male identities is a bodybuilder named Brian. She told the court that when an alternate ego takes over, her primary personality goes into a ``dark place, a place of nothingness. Time is not passing there.''

DOC.HEAD: Precedes BROCKTON, Mass.
Retransmitting a0578 to include editor's note
Families Hear From Hostages in Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands as a writethru to a0489, slugged Christmas-Hostage, which focused only on the family in Brockton.
DOC.TEXT: Families of some of the Americans being held by the Iraqi government got telephone calls from their loved ones over the weekend, and a few of the hostages were evasive on some subjects. Ann Hoffman of Columbus, Ga., said her son Miles called home about noon Saturday. He was a financial analyst and investor for the Kuwaiti government before the Iraqi invasion. ``He said they were lined up at the telephone. A whole lot of them'' were being allowed to call home, she said. Mrs. Hoffman, who has been concerned about her son's health since he was shot in the arm by an Iraqi soldier during an escape attempt Sept. 5, said her son's call was disconnected when she asked about his wound. ``I asked how his arm was. I told them the (recently released) French hostages told us he was not allowed to exercise - or couldn't exercise because it hurt,'' she said. ``He said something about `they must have seen my X-rays,' then we were cut off. ``Then he called back about half an hour later. I tried to discuss it again, but he said he didn't want to talk about him, he wanted to hear about all of us. ... He didn't want to discuss himself at all.'' Charles Keegan, 56, was allowed to call his daughters, Cathi Van Baale and Peg Keegan, in Des Moines, Iowa, on Saturday. ``He was really evasive,'' Ms. Van Baale said, adding that she thought the call was monitored. ``My sister asked him if he was being treated OK and he just changed subjects. ``He sounded kind of disgusted, like `Let's get this over with.' '' The women said Keegan told them not to worry about him because he is not ``at a crucial site,'' a reference to the Iraqi government putting foreign hostages at key military installations as human shields. Jim Brown said his twin brother Cecil was allowed to make a brief phone call Sunday to his wife and sons in metro Atlanta. Today is the twin brothers' birthday and Jim Brown, also of the Atlanta area, said the call was ``a gift in itself.'' But he said it would be ``a very empty day. ... Our birthday has always been thought of in terms of two. This situation interrupted that.'' Others plan more direct contact. Mary Trundy, 44, of Brockton, Mass., says she'll spend Christmas in Baghdad with her twin brother, John Stevenson. ``If this helps John's morale, so be it,'' she said. The U.S. government has urged families of captives in Iraq and Kuwait to ignore Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's offer to let them visit over Christmas. The White House fears the families could become hostages, too.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Has Huge Army, But It's Not Looking for a Fight
DOC.TEXT: Whenever the military option is debated as a solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, eyes turn to Turkey's military force of 800,000 men, the second-largest standing army in the Western alliance. Under the scenario of a ``second front,'' Turkish soldiers, supported by U.S. aircraft, could push from the north into Iraq, while the allied war machine in Saudi Arabia attacked from the south. But President Turgut Ozal, speaking to reporters last week, said any such scenario is a ``figment of the imagination.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who visits Turkey this week, is said to be trying to pin down allies about their willingness to fight Saddam Hussein, if it comes to that. Such talk makes many Turks nervous. Turkey's armed forces are large in numbers but short on firepower. Some equipment dates from the Korean war. In the past decade, Turkey has tried to modernize its army, but its leaders say it has not gotten enough support from its NATO allies. Equipment being moved from the European theater as part of Western arms reduction agreements with the Soviets will be made available to Turkey eventually. But any war in the gulf is likely to be over by then. Moreover, Turkey is unprepared for a posssible chemical weapons attack from Iraq. It lacks shelters, gas antidotes and gas masks and a good civil defense organization. Saddam has used chemical weapons in the past, against Iran during the 1980-88 war and against the rebellious Kurds. Turkey itself has had to contend with a long-running Kurdish rebellion, and its army spent years doing battle with guerrillas in the rugged mountains. ``Turkey has not a single soldier to send or a bullet to waste in the deserts of Arabia,'' wrote Hasan Pulur, one of the nation's most popular columnists in the newspaper Milliyet. Despite such misgivings, Turkey has come down firmly on the side of the anti-Iraq coalition since the start of the crisis. Soon after Iraq took over Kuwait on Aug. 2, Turkey closed down twin pipelines carrying Iraqi crude oil, effectively cutting off more than half of Iraq's oil exports. Turkey has also blocked Iraq's land access to the West, banning all bilateral and transit trade. After the United Nations authorized an air embargo on Iraq, Turkey began forcing Iraq-bound aircraft to land and be searched. As a result of all this, Turkey's relations with its southern neighbor are seriously damaged. Diplomats and analysts say Turkey will now have a hostile neighbor to contend with as long as Saddam stays in power. Even though they want Saddam out, Turks hope they won't have to go to war to accomplish that. In several public opinion polls conducted after the outbreak of the gulf crisis, three-fourths of the respondents opposed Turkey's involvement in any military action. The Turks also are being careful to stress that they have no territorial designs on Iraq, although they lost some land when borders in the region were re-drawn after World War I. The Turks had been allied with the losing Germans. Iraq cited historical claims on Kuwait as among the reasons for its attack. In Turkey these days, one commonly expressed fear is that the Western countries that need Turkey's help now will forget about it later. ``Once the crisis is over, we will be immediately forgotten. It will be business as usual for the Western powers that sold all the chemical weapons equipment to Iraq,'' said one government official, speaking on condition of anonymity. According to World Bank estimates, Turkey is the hardest hit by the international economic sanctions against Iraq, with its losses expected to total about $7 billion a year. That includes lost revenue from the pipeline, bilateral trade, construction business, unpaid Iraqi debts and tourist revenues. Other nations have said they will help make up the losses. So far, Japan has pledged $200 million, Kuwait $300 million, Germany $74 million and France $30 million. But Saudi Arabia has not responded yet to requests for cheaper oil or favorable loans, and there is no word yet from the United States on Ozal's request to lift restrictions on Turkey's competitive export goods, such as textiles, and iron and steel. Higher oil prices pushed up Turkish consumer prices by 8.7 percent in September and 6.8 percent in October. The government already has authorization from Parliament to send Turkish troops abroad and allow deployment of foreign troops here. But most officials believe application of the measure will be limited, perhaps only permitting U.S. aircraft to use the Incirlik NATO base in southern Turkey as a staging area. Although Ozal's executive powers are limited under Turkey's parliamentary system, he confers on the phone every week with President Bush and other world leaders. Ozal has repeatedly stressed that this Moslem country with secular laws is a bridge between East and West. He hopes the risks he is taking now will pay off later, perhaps leading to Turkish membership in the European Community.

DOC.HEAD: Deer Smashes Through Bank Windows
DOC.TEXT: A deer broke through a bank's window and smashed three others Monday, apparently mistaking its reflection for a rival, authorities said. It took police and game wardens about an hour to get the bleeding buck out of the Mellon Bank branch. ``What happened was he broke one window trying to get in and three others trying to get out,'' Police Chief Jack Lively said. A road crew used shovels to break the rest of the glass, lined up and drove the buck through the window and into a nearby forest. The damage was mostly blood stains and glass in the lobby, bank spokeswoman Norma Buhrman said. Game wardens and police suspect the buck thought his reflection in the bank's window was a rival. Deer are in their mating season and become protective of their turf.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Ready To Declare Victory in Medfly War
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture officials expect to declare victory this week in the 16-month, $52 million campaign to eradicate the crop-destroying Mediterranean fruit fly from Southern California. But the continued arrival of illegal fruit and vegetables, usually carried in travelers' luggage, virtually ensures future infestations, officials said Sunday. ``There is some perverse streak in human nature. They seem to believe its fun to outsmart authorities and bring in just one mango or just one pineappple from Hawaii,'' said Gera Curry, spokeswoman for the state Department of Food and Agriculture. ``All it takes is one person.'' Quarantines could be lifted by Thursday or Friday in areas of Southern California, Curry said. No flies were found in traps last month, but officials want to be certain the flies really are gone before declaring victory, she said. The quarantines were imposed on movement of fruit from infested areas. The big worry was that the flies could spread to agricultural areas and wreck California's $18 billion-a-year farm industry. Slightly smaller than a common housefly, the Medfly lays its eggs in fruit and vegetables, causing them to rot. Florida declared victory over the Medfly in August, four months after finding a single fly near Miami International Airport. The state spent less than $1.6 million for eight sprayings over a 20-square-mile area to eliminate the threat as quickly as possible. ``Our immediate reaction upon discovery of the Medfly and our all-out effort ... provides a vivid contrast between Florida's eradication program and what's happening in California,'' said Florida Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner. The fly has plagued California farmers since the early 1980s. From 1980 to 1982 state and federal officials spent $100 million to battle the pest, and farmers lost $100 million in damaged crops. The latest infestation caused a public outcry when the state repeatedly sent helicopters to spray the pesticide malathion in a 500-square-mile area encompassing dozens of communities. Citizens filed 300 damage claims and numerous lawsuits. Emotions continue to run high, and opponents of aerial spraying disputed the state's claim of victory. ``They're saying victory because it will calm us down, but it's a political facade,'' said Pat Reichenberger, a former Monterey Park mayor who opposed spraying over his community. ``I don't think it's over by any means. They'll be back.'' Roy Cunningham, chairman of the state Medfly Science Advisory Panel, said if the fly returns, enhanced detection measures should prevent infestations from reaching the same scale. In 1980 and 1989, the state waited too long to begin eradication, he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Diplomats Eat Tuna, Phone Home While Holding Out in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: They dine on canned tuna fish and fresh dates, shinny up the palm trees on the compound, compete in tennis and fight boredom. They spend part of every day trying to keep in touch with a secret network of fellow Americans in hiding in Kuwait and with their bosses back home. At night, they shiver when the temperature drops and worry about not having any blankets as the winter chill sets in. There are eight U.S. diplomats holding out inside the American Embassy compound in Kuwait. They are joined by 19 private citizens who sought refuge in the embassy. President Bush says Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is trying to ``starve them out.'' Most other Western countries that tried to keep their embassies open after Iraq ordered them closed have given up and pulled their people out. Two British diplomats, the ambassador and a consul, are still in their separate embassy about a mile away. The grounds are surrounded by Iraqi troops, and no one is permitted to enter or leave. But the four men and four women picked by the State Department to stay behind have kept the embassy operating despite growing personal discomfort. The department has provided few details of life inside the Kuwait embassy. But several officials agreed to discuss the situation there on condition they not be identified, and, with tidbits from the public record, provided a glimpse of life within the walls of the isolated U.S. outpost at the center of the Gulf crisis. In the three weeks between the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the Aug. 24 deadline for shutting down all diplomatic facilities in the capital of the overrun emirate, the seaside compound's occupants stocked up on non-perishable food and bottled water, laying in substantial quantities against the time when supplies would be cut off. At the time, more than 100 Americans occupied the ambassador's residence, chancery, three-story administration building and a cluster of prefabricated buildings that were shipped in after a truck bomb destroyed half the administration building in a 1983 terrorist attack. Many of those who sought refuge in the compound brought possessions and food with them and left much of it behind when they got out just before the embassy was sealed off. Officials refuse to say just what remains because they want to keep the Iraqis guessing how long the Americans can hold out. Bush said Thursday, ``They have enough right now.'' Shortly after the Aug. 24 deadline set by the Iraqis, electricity and water to the compound were cut off. The loss of air conditioning made the blistering heat almost unbearable, and some people chose to sleep outdoors to avoid the stifling rooms in the ambassador's residence or offices that had been converted to sleeping quarters in the administration building. There weren't enough generators or fuel to keep the freezers running, so the frozen food, mostly turkey, was eaten first. There was plenty at first, but it spoiled--none too soon for some compound inmates tired of the steady turkey diet. They've since resorted to canned tuna, supplemented by rice and fresh dates that grow on the compound. With the water cut off, they couldn't use toilets, so they dug a trench at one side of the compound and use it as a latrine. There were no showers, but they continued to use the swimming pool as long as possible. Sources say it is stagnant now, and the water unsuitable for most uses. Last week, however, Secretary of State James A. Baker III disclosed the embassy occupants had dug a well and struck water good enough for washing - they even washed their cars just to show off for the guards - and to water the vegetable garden they've planted behind the ambassador's house. They have yet to harvest any vegetables but are reported hopeful they will have a crop before the desert temperatures drop into the 30s in mid-winter. ``They're very elated about their new well,'' said Margie Howell, wife of U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, who was packing to come home when the invasion blocked his departure. Mrs. Howell, who had left a short time before, told the NBC Today Show last week she goes to the State Department every day and speaks to her husband over a special satellite telephone link that keeps communications open between the embassy and Washington. The principal assignment of those who remain behind is to keep in contact with the 600 or so Americans who are still in hiding in Kuwait to avoid being rounded up and added to the ranks of the ``human shield'' Saddam Hussein has assembled to protect strategic installations from attack. The loal phones still work, but the State Department says the Iraqis tap the embassy phone lines to try to catch Americans in hiding. To keep conversation to a minimum and prevent the Iraqis from tracing calls to people's hideouts, sources said, the diplomats use Voice of America radio broadcasts to signal citizens to call when there is news about evacuation flights, medicine or emergencies. And the embassy tries to maintain a team of ``wardens'' beyond the walls who serve as intermediaries between the diplomats and those in hiding. When they're not working the phones, Mrs. Howell said, those inside the compound work out on exercise equipment left behind by the Marine guards, read and play cards. ``Actually, this is our third war,'' she told NBC. ``We were in Egypt in '67, and then we were in Beirut in '75 when that war started.''

DOC.HEAD: Guam Voters Elect Governor - First Woman or First Repeater
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for AMs; polls close at 4 a.m. EST Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: Voters decide Tuesday whether to elect this U.S. territory's first woman governor or re-elect a governor for the first time ever. Republican Gov. Joseph Ada is running for re-election against Democratic territorial Sen. Madeline Bordallo, widow of former Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo, who chained himself to a statue in a busy Agana intersection and shot himself to death Jan. 30. Ricardo Bordallo was convicted of federal extortion charges and was to have begun serving an 18-month prison sentence Jan. 31. Ada, 46, who defeated Ricardo Bordallo in 1986, held a 2-to-1 edge over Madeline Bordallo, according to a poll by the Pacific Daily News. If he wins, Ada would be the western Pacific island's first governor to be re-elected. Bordallo, 57, would be the territory's first woman governor, and the first who is not a native Guamanian. She is originally from Minnesota. Ada and Bordallo differ on few issues. Both advocate controlled development, and back an appeal of the territory's restrictive abortion law. Pro-choice advocates were urging voters to boycott the gubernatorial election to protest the candidates' abortion stand.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Brings `War' to Arcades and Personal Computers
LaserPhoto NY29
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sunrise comes to the Persian Gulf as you strap youself into your F-15 fighter jet and roar away from the deck of a carrier. Welcome to the gulf war - in a video game simulation. MicroProse Software Inc. of Hunt Valley, Md., is giving would-be fighter jocks a chance to test their mettle with the closest thing to combat simulators: highly sophisticated video games. One of the games, F-15 Strike Eagle, has been especially popular. It contains a war scenario in which jets blow up enemy oil and military sites while outrunning tank and missile fire. Sales of F-15 Strike Eagle, Gunship, Airborne Ranger and other games are up 30 percent since the crisis began Aug. 2 when Iraq invaded Kuwait, said MicroProse spokeswoman Kathy Gilmore. ``We think it's because of the Middle East crisis. We think people know what's happening over there and our games realistically simulate a situation,'' she said. Even soldiers in Saudi Arabia may soon be at the controls of Strike Eagle. One of the game units is being flown out Tuesday for servicemen to kill time and imaginary enemies in the absence of outright hostilities. Gilmore declined to give exact sales figures, but said 500,000 ``computer pilots'' are now enjoying the F-15 simulation on home machines, in addition to thousands playing the game at coin-operated video arcades. MicroProse engineer David Bellamy, who demonstrated the game last week for a rapt audience at New York's noisy Broadway Arcade, said it's so real ``you start to feel like a real fighter jock.'' He put 50 cents in the console, throttled up his jet and took off on a mission on which he shot down an enemy plane and blew up oil tanks and two enemy speedboats, accompanied by stereo sound effects. Players gaping around the video console gave F-15 a thumbs-up. ``It's real fun,'' said 16-year-old Jesus Malena. MicroProse is preparing a more sophisticated gulf war game for personal computers. The scenario is being built into a game tentatively entitled Gunship 2000, awaiting a spring release at an expected retail price of $59-$69. Gunship 2000's chief designer, Jim Day, said its gulf scenario will feature Army helicopters that go out to destroy military and oil installations while rescuing ``guests'' detained at the sites. Playes select types and numbers of helicopters and weaponry, and bone up on maps and intelligence before their missions. No two missions are ever played the same way. Day said his researchers combed large amounts of publicly available military data for precise details on weapons and tactics, including the sounds they make. ``We are certainly not promoting war or anything, but an individual using the game as a simulation can relate to it,'' he explained. Ted Markley, MicroProse vice president of product development, underscored the point that no one wants a real war. In fact, he said, ``If we could send our product to Saddam Hussein and say, `Let you play this and we'll play yours,' then let's send our troops home.''

DOC.HEAD: `Big Green' Vote Among Tests of Environment Movement
DOC.TEXT: A $36 million battle over four California ballot issues that could shape the course of the environmental movement may have bought little more than voter confusion. Tuesday's vote on Proposition 128, called ``Big Green'' by its champions, is billed as a pivotal test for the national environmental movement. It features an ecologists' dream list of restrictions on offshore drilling, pesticide use and other pollutants. But a poll released Friday found ``Big Green'' has lost its big lead and is now trailing. Forty-three percent surveyed in a California Poll opposed it, 41 percent were in favor and 16 percent were undecided. Analysts say many Californians are confused by ``Big Green'' and the three other conflicting environmental initiatives affecting logging and pesticides. Various industries have spent $10 million condemning it as an economic disaster. They've also disparagingly dubbed it the ``Hayden Initiative'' after supporter Tom Hayden, a state assemblyman who still evokes strong emotions as a symbol of '60s anti-Vietnam War activism. Big business and environmentalists have spent a combined $36 million campaigning for and against the four issues. Industry has outspent environmentalists 2-1. Foes and supporters, each citing expert studies, have made wildly differing claims about the multibillion-dollar impact of the initiatives that would control emissions, pesticides, offshore oil-drilling and logging. California Poll director Mervin Field said confusion may prompt the electorate to vote no on all four issues ``as a way of maintaining the status quo.'' ``It's a horrible mess,'' said A. Alan Post, a former analyst for the Legislature. ``If you try to read the voter pamphlet, it's very difficult. If you try to read the propositions themselves, it's worse.'' The environmental cause faces other ballot tests Tuesday: -A Washington state initiative would require local governments to adopt land use plans to conform to state growth and environmental goals. -An Oregon measure would impose tight new recycling standards, and a second would shut down the state's only nuclear power plant. -Two South Dakota initiatives would curb gold and silver mining and regulate large garbage dumps. -Missouri's proposed ``Natural Streams Act'' would protect Ozark waterways. -A proposed $1.9 billion environmental bond in New York state would be used to acquire land for preservation, help close landfills and promote recycling. Among the other California measures, Proposition 130, dubbed ``Forests Forever,'' would restrict clear-cutting of forests and authorize bonds for purchase of old-growth redwoods. The issue held a narrowing lead in the latest opinion polls. Two industry-backed rivals to ``Forests Forever'' and ``Big Green'' would impose far less stringent restrictions on pesticides and logging. ``Forests Forever'' opponents, principally timber and wood-processing firms, have spent nearly $10 million mostly on television ads warning that the measure would increase fire danger by altering logging practices. Millionaire investment counselor Harold Arbit has given $5.1 million to the campaign for the measure, setting a state record for an individual contribution. Overall, backers have raised about $6.5 million. ``My banker keeps saying, `Are you sure you want to do this? Are you sure it's worth it?' And I keep asking myself what material possession would I rather have, versus knowing that I've helped save a unique natural heritage,'' Arbit said. ``Big Green'' supporters, who raised $4.5 million, say it would preserve ancient redwood forests, slow global warming by gradually curbing auto and other emissions, ban oil development in state waters and bar pesticides suspected of causing cancer. It also would create an elective post of environmental czar. Proponents - including Hollywood stars Jane Fonda, Chevy Chase and Sylvester Stallone - argue that the sweeping measure includes a patchwork of legislation rejected by lawmakers under pressure from special interests. They say it would save Californians several billion dollars in energy and health costs each year. But foes, including major oil companies based outside the state, insist it would cost Californians billions each year because controls would increase gasoline, electricity and food prices. Critics add that, if it passes, it would also fall short of goals and become snarled in legal battles.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three in Governor's Races Top Priority For Both Parties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, ``I think,'' to UPDATE with Bush comment; INSERTS 5 grafs after 6th graf pvs, Frant Newport, to UPDATE with Helms, Hartigan and Harris comment; DELETES now-redundant 10th graf, President Bush.
DOC.TEXT: A pessimistic electorate heard the final, frenzied appeals Monday of a midterm campaign in which the governorships of California, Texas and Florida are the key to partisan hopes for victory. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida forecast a come-from-behind victory over former Sen. Lawton Chiles, who held a narrow lead in the polls. ``I think when the votes are all counted tomorrow that we will have been successful ... and be the first Republican governor re-elected in the state of Florida,'' said Martinez as he left for a day of get-out-the-vote rallies. President Bush campaigned in Texas for embattled GOP gubernatorial nominee Clayton Williams, whose once-solid lead over Democrat Ann Richards melted in the heat of a long and nasty campaign. ``I urge all Texans ... to get out there and vote and do not take democracy for granted ... You have a chance to make a difference,'' said the president as he campaigned to boost Republican turnout. Neither party is anticipating major changes in Congress, although several senior legislators are battling for survival, including Republican Sens. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Mark Hatfield of Oregon and Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota. The mood of the electorate was variously described as pessimistic, unhappy, angry, and turned off. What reaction that might bring on Election Day was the major unknown. Would voters throw out incumbents, or just stay home? Frank Newport, editor-in-chief of the Gallup poll, said Americans are deeply concerned about the economy and dissatisfaction is at its highest level in eight years. ``This is a very Democratic mood out there,'' said pollster Louis Harris. ``There's no sign of the late Republican surge some have talked about.'' In Illinois, Democrat Neil Hartigan celebrated a poll that said he was 14 points ahead of Republican Jim Edgar in the race for governor. Another poll showed Edgar 2 points ahead. ``People feel very strongly that it is time for a change,'' said Hartigan. He and Edgar are battling to succeed Republican Gov. Jim Thompson, who is retiring after 14 years in office. At a news conference in North Carolina, Helms denied he has made race an issue in his campaign against Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt. ``I was born white and he was born black and there was nothing either one of us could do about it,'' said the senator. ``We have not made an issue of race, but he has gone around the state pleading for the bloc vote. He has a right to do that. But that has injected race into it.'' While Democrats were optimistic about their chances in the Florida governor's race, Republicans saw things going their way in California, where the governorship was the year's biggest electoral prize. Republican Pete Wilson and Democrat Dianne Feinstein were closing out their campaigns by heading in opposite directions - Wilson flying south and Feinstein heading north - for a long day of campaign rallies. Former President Reagan was joining Wilson at stops in Orange County and San Diego. In Texas, Richards spent the final weekend of the campaign hammering at Williams for his failure to pay income taxes in 1986, a year in which the oil millionaire says he was ``fighting for my life.'' ``It was a bad year for school teachers,'' said Richards, ``but they paid their taxes. ... It was a bad year for all people who work for a living, but they paid their income tax.'' Bush picked a name at random from the Houston telephone book Sunday and appealed to Mary Johnson to support Williams and the Republican ticket on Tuesday. The woman told the president she would vote - later she told reporters she was a Democrat who would cast her ballot for Richards. No Senate race was getting more attention than the pitched battle in North Carolina between Helms and Gantt. The race was too close to call, with everyone wary of opinion surveys in a polarizing contest between Helms, the symbol of hardline conservatism, and Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte. Two other senior Republicans were battling unexpectedly tough challenges. In Minnesota, Boschwitz appeared to have widened his lead over Democrat Paul Wellstone. But the chaotic political situation in a state where the GOP nominee for governor resigned from the ticket after allegations of sexual impropriety, left analysts wary of jumping to any conclusions. Hatfield also appeared to be recovering from a scare from Democratic businessman Harry Lonsdale, but the race remained too close to call. The best Republican hope for a pickup was in traditionally Democratic Hawaii, where Rep. Pat Saiki was challenging appointed Democratic Sen. Daniel Akaka. All told, 36 states will elect governors on Tuesday and voters will fill 34 Senate seats and the entire U.S. House. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana won re-election last month when he received more than 50 percent of the vote in an open primary contest against former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke. Democrats control the Senate by a margin of 55 to 45 and the House 258 to 175. Of the nation's governors, 29 are Democrats and 21 are Republicans. Pollsters predict people who go to the polls this year are likely to be in a gloomy and downright ugly mood. A nationwide New York Times-CBS survey depicted an electorate pessimistic about the economy and unhappy with its government. The survey of 1,445 adults reported that nearly four in 10 people surveyed expect things to get worse in the country. Only three in 10 expect them to improve. Two-thirds of those responding believe the economy is in bad shape and 77 percent believe government is run by special interests looking out for themselves. Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic Party, predicted Election Day gains across the board, adding to the party's majority of the nation's governors and increasing its margins of control over the Senate and House. White House staff chief John Sununu said he was ready to declare victory if the Republicans avoided the losses in Congress generally absorbed by the president's party in his first midterm election. ``What we have set as a goal is to be significantly better than the average result in an off-year election,'' said Sununu. ``And if we do that, it will be a success.'' That average is generally about two dozen House seats. But success in the 1990 election is more likely to be judged by which party strengthens its role in redrawing political lines to conform to the 1990 Census. Governors play a crucial role in that battle, particularly in California, Florida, and Texas, which will pick up 14 new House seats in the 1992 elections. All three states now have Republican governors and Democratic legislatures. In California, Feinstein campaigned Sunday at church in a black neighborhood in San Francisco and said Wilson's vote to sustain Bush's veto ``broke the back of the 1990 Civil Rights bill.'' The GOP senator told supporters in Bakersfield that Feinstein ads portraying him as supporting the rich were part of a ``campaign that depends upon dividing California, dividing the cities against the rural areas, the rich against the poor and the black against the white.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Aiming for Atlantis Launch Next Week
DOC.TEXT: NASA expects to launch Atlantis with a spy satellite around Nov. 16, a week later than planned because of cargo problems, officials said Monday. The Air Force has not yet announced a date for the shuttle's secret military mission. But Forrest McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center, said ``the best guess'' is that Atlantis will be launched at the end of next week. Air Force officials last week delayed the Nov. 9 launch, saying more time was needed ``to resolve anomalies discovered during cargo testing.'' They refused to elaborate. The satellite inside Atlantis reportedly will spy on Iraqi forces. NASA still plans to launch Columbia in early December, despite Atlantis' delay, McCartney said. Although the space agency likes to have at least three weeks between flights, it will expedite work in this case so Columbia's long astronomy mission can be completed by Christmas, he said. ``We're going to cut that time as short as we can,'' he said, referring to the period between missions. ``But we will not cut down on the normal inspections and data that we look at.'' The National Aeronautics and Space Administration would prefer not to fly any shuttles around Christmas so it can shut down certain operations at Kennedy Space Center to perform maintenance, McCar) - President Bush, stumping for GOP candidates in the final hours before Tuesday's elections, told voters today to ignore analysts ``telling us everything that's wrong with the United States'' and go vote ``to make a difference.'' ``I urge all Texans ... to get out there and vote and do not take democracy for granted,'' Bush said as traveled his home state. Bush wrapped up the campaign season trying to energize campaign workers in Texas and spur voters to the polls for an election looming with uncertainty for the Republican Party. ``You have a chance to make a difference,'' he said as he campaigned in East Texas with gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams and Sen. Phil Gramm. ``The cynics, these Washington pundits that we see on these tiring shows all the time ... I see all these great `inside-the-beltway' experts telling us everything that's wrong with the United States. ``Tomorrow you can go to the polls and say what's right about it,'' Bush said to cheers at a Tyler Junior College flag-waving rally. Meanwhile, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that the president would sign later today the $492-billion five-year deficit reduction package passed by Congress in the final days of its session. The measure, which includes over $140 billion in new taxes, has created political problems for Bush as he campaigns for Republican candidates after abandoning his ``no new taxes'' pledges. Fitzwater said that the president would also sign 13 spending bills to finance the government throughout the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1. Fitzwater said that the 14 pieces of legislation were being flown to Texas on a commercial airliner and that the president would sign them later tonight in Houston. Bush campaigned with Williams today in Tyler, a hotly-contested North Texas community of conservative Democrats. Voters in the agriculture-and timber-dependent area supported Bush in the 1988 presidential election, but bot Democrat Ann Richards and Williams are hoping to win the area on Tuesday. From Tyler, Bush was heading to Richards' home town of Waco to try and pull support for Williams in the central Texas, conservative Baptist stronghold. Bush continued to keep his message upbeat, after saying Monday that people should ignore ``all these gloomy assessments'' about the national mood and just go vote. On Sunday, Williams went to church and a campaign phone bank with Bush, then defended his failure to pay income taxes in 1986. ``I was fighting for my life in 1986. I didn't pay any tax because I didn't have any income'' due to the economic downturn in Texas from plunging oil prices at that time, he told reporters. Bush and Williams made voter-turnout calls to registered Republicans on a list at a local GOP phone bank. The president accepted a reporter's dare to call a name picked at random from the phone book. It turned out to be Democratic voter Mary Johnson. While reporters watched, hearing his end of the conversation but not hers, Bush told her he hoped she would vote for the GOP ticket. ``Will ya?'' he asked in apparent delight at her response. But the woman later said in a telephone interview that she would vote for Richards, not Williams, ``because I'm not a Republican.'' ``I just told him I was going to vote,'' she said. ``I didn't tell him who I was going to vote for.'' The president also sought by telephone Sunday to boost Republican efforts in other states. Bush gave telephone pep talks to rallies held by Senate hopeful Hal Daub in Nebraska, congressional candidates Genevieve Atwood in Utah and Wayne Gilcrest in Maryland, and gubernatorial contenders Arlis Sturgulewski in Alaska and Kay Orr in Nebraska. Bush urged his listeners to ``get out and vote'' on Tuesday. He told the Alaskans, ``I get sick and tired of all these gloomy assessments that I hear on television and read about in the papers.'' ``We have a lot to be grateful for in our country, and one of the things is individuals can make a difference.'' He bemoaned ``this cynical reporting we hear about, how everybody is gloomy and down in the dumps - I don't believe it. Alaskans have never been that way.'' The president's campaign focus has been upbeat in the face of uncertainties that could spell trouble on Election Day - including a grim economic picture, skyrocketing gas prices tied to the Persian Gulf crisis, the promised higher taxes from the new budget package and the uncertainty over whether war will break out in the gulf region. Bush kept his remarks short and enthusiastic Sunday, staying clear of controversial issues like his support of the tax-raising budget package. While accusing Democrats of trying to tax working people and ruining his tough-on-crime legislation, he has curtailed the harsh rhetoric he unleashed last week. His chief of staff, John Sununu, meanwhile, disputed suggestions that Bush's heightened focus on the gulf last week was a political tactic to get the focus off the budget and economic issues. ``The most important item on his agenda right now is the situation in the gulf. He was talking about that. He held an open news conference, and 97 percent of the questions from the press was on the situation in the Middle East,'' Sununu said on NBC-TV's `` Meet The Press.''

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Boy Who Received 16 Million Get-well Cards Visits Disney World
DOC.TEXT: A cancer-stricken British boy who received 16 million get-well cards is visiting Walt Disney World and other attractions. Craig Shergold, 11, also is visiting Sea World, Universal Studios Florida and other sites with his family. The London boy had an operation in January 1989 that removed most of a brain tumor. Craig developed a plan to earn a place in the Guinness Book of World Records by getting more get-well cards than anyone had ever received. Helped by friends and a Children's Wish Foundation in Atlanta, Craig received more than 16 million cards from all over the world. Craig's mother, Marion, has asked that no more cards be sent. She said doctors believe chemotherapy and radiation have stemmed the spread of his cancer. Craig will be in the 1991 edition of the record book.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Meets With Emir; Hostages Call Home
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs after 3rd pvs, ``The British...'' to UPDATE with State Department saying Americans received calls from hostages, some of whom are losing weight and doing without medication. Pickup 4th, ``Hundreds of...''
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. secretary of state met today with the exiled emir of Kuwait, and there were indications that Iraq was moving to further pressure the United States and Britain by allowing hostages to call home. Also today, the USS Midway entered the Persian Gulf, the second U.S. aircraft carrier to do so in four weeks. Like the USS Independence, which left the gulf last month after a few days, the Midway's presence was apparently intended as a show of force. The British Foreign Office said today at least 30 British hostages held in Iraq called their families in Britain during the weekend. The Foreign Office condemned the calls as another ``cruel and calculating Iraqi ploy.'' In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said at least 21 families in the United States receivedtelephone calls from relatives being detained in Iraq. ``Consistent with other reports we have received, many detainees said they were losing weight, that the food was poor and that with the approach of winter they were frequently cold,'' Boucher said. He added, ``We think if he (Saddam Hussein) is genuinely concerned about allowing husbands and fathers to talk to their wives and children, he should simply release all the hostages and let them come home.'' Boucher said some hostages expressed concern that the medication they were using was running out and that mail being sent by relatives was not being forwarded by Iraqi authorities. Hundreds of foreigners have been held in Iraq and Kuwait since Saddam's troops overran the emirate on Aug. 2. Saddam has offered to let relatives visit during the Christmas holidays - an offer reiterated in weekend phone calls by some hostages. Other hostages told their families not to give in. ``He said the telephone call was being recorded but he didn't give two mokkeys and to let the government know that the hostages want no negotiations with the terrorists and they are 100 percent behind them,'' one Briton said of his hostage son. British officials did not identify the father and son by name. In Brockton, Mass., however, a 44-year-old woman whose twin brother is a hostage said she'll go to Baghdad for Christmas, despite the opposition of the U.S. government. ``If this helps John's morale, so be it,'' Mary Trundy said of her twin, John Stevenson. She said her twin called their brothers in Florida during the weekend. ``I think it is a very positive sign that they are letting hostages call home,'' she said. ``We're all planning to spend the holidays with John.'' Meanwhile, a British lawmaker said families of the hostages should stop complaining. ``I am sick and tired of the mewling and puking of the relatives of hostages in the gulf and of some of the hostages themselves,'' said Sir John Stokes. ``During the last war we never heard sobs of widows. Cannot these people keep a stiff upper lip and think of the country as a whole?'' Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt was headed for Baghdad today on a controversial mission to win the release of German hostages. And Yasuhiro Nakasone, the former Japanese prime minister, sought the release of Japanese hostages in a meeting with Saddam on Sunday. Belgium's foreign minister complained that efforts by individual nations to win their citizens' freedom are eroding unity against Iraq. ``Saddam is creating this royal court of all sorts of Western pilgrims who visit him to obtain the release of hostages,'' the minister, Mark Eyskens, said in Brussels. Italy called a meeting of European Community foreign ministers in Rome tonight to consider the continuing breaks with the EC policy opposing negotiations with Iraq over freeing the hostages. In the Saudi resort town of Taif today, Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Kuwait's exiled emir. After the meeting, Baker said: ``This crisis is entering a new phase, and while we are still seeking a peaceful political and diplomatic solution, we have to put ourselves in a position where we would be able to exercise any options that might be available.'' Baker said he had not discussed a military timetable with the emir. He said ``the entire international community'' was seeking a peaceful solution to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, adding: ``I don't think that we can or should we rule out resort to force if that should be necessary,'' Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah said he would like to see his country liberated ``today and before tomorrow.'' ``What I would like to see is the liberation of Kuwait as soon as possible,'' he told reporters. Baker was received warmly in the Saudi Arabian desert on Sunday, but some soldiers expressed frustration. ``I'm ready to go home,'' one sergeant told reporters. ``I'm tired of eating this dirt. I'm tired of drinking hot water.'' The secretary of state told the troops he understood that ``this is a long way from home,'' but added: ``I think that Americans are home wherever our principles are. And that's really what this crisis is all about.'' Reports have suggested Baker is trying to fix a date for an attack on Iraq, or determine which allies could be counted on to join an offensive if the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq fails to force Saddam out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Argument That Juvenile Court Hearings Should Be Open
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court turned away arguments Monday that the public has a constitutional right to attend juvenile court proceedings. The court, without comment, rejected a Columbus, Ohio, newspaper's contention in a nationally publicized child-custody case that most juvenile court hearings should be open. Lawyers for The Columbus Dispatch argued that past rulings establishing a public right to attend criminal trials even over a defendant's objections should apply to juvenile court proceedings as well. The Ohio Supreme Court previously rejected that argument, noting that juvenile hearings ``are usually private'' and their records confidential. The dispute grew out of a ``surrogate mother'' contract in which Richard and Beverly Reams hired a woman to have a child for them. The woman, who was artificially inseminated with sperm from an unrelated donor, gave birth in early 1985 to Tessa Reams. The Reamses took custody of Tessa when she was a day old. The couple filed for divorce two years later, and both sought custody of Tessa. The custody issue was not resolved as part of their divorce,and in 1987 Mrs. Reams, then known as Beverly Seymour, sued her ex-husband seeking permanent custody of Tessa. The child's court-appointed guardian sought to exclude the public and news media from all hearings on Tessa's future. The guardian also sought a ``gag order'' under which Ms. Seymour would be barred from discussing the case with news reporters. The presiding juvenile court judge ordered the custody hearings closed to the public, and issued the gag order against Ms. Seymour. A state appeals court blocked enforcement of both orders, ruling that they unduly interfered with what it called a constitutional right of public access to juvenile courts. But on appeal, the Ohio Supreme Court last June said the appeals court was wrong. After the state Supreme Court's ruling, the custody hearing over Tessa was conducted in secret last August. Custody was awarded to Richard Reams. When Reams went to his ex-wife's home in Ashville, Ohio, a week later to pick up Tessa, he was fatally shot. Ms. Seymour has been charged with his murder. The custody issue continued after Reams was killed. Both the woman who bore Tessa, Norma Lee Stotski, and Ms. Seymour's sister, Christine Clay, sought custody. County officials, awarded custody by the presiding judge, last month placed Tessa in the home of Annabelle Reams, Richard Reams' mother. The county said Tessa recognized her as her grandmother, even though there were no biological ties. After Reams was shot, The Columbus Dispatch was given the record of the August custody hearing. But lawyers for the newspaper said the legal dispute is not moot because it could arise in another case.

DOC.HEAD: Farmer Attempts Suicide at GATT Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: A South Korean farm official tried to kill himself at the headquarters of the world's main free-trade association Monday, apparently to protest attempts to open his country's market to imports, officials said. The man pulled out a Swiss army knife and plunged it into his stomach as he was about to leave the building on Lake Geneva where the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is based, the officials said. He was rushed to a hospital for emergency treatment and his life was out of immediate danger, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The man was identified as Kyung-Hae Lee, president of the Korean National Future Farmer's and Fisherman's Association, one of the country's main farming lobby groups. He was part of a five-member delegation visiting GATT to highlight the problems of South Korean farmers. GATT, a 100-nation trade forum, is in the final stages of four-year negotiations to liberalize world trade. The talks, which are scheduled to end in early December, have prompted demonstrations in South Korea where farmers fear increased competition from imports, particularly in the sensitive rice market.

DOC.HEAD: Pregnant Woman Dies in Car Crash, But Baby Delivered Alive
DOC.TEXT: A woman pregnant six months was killed in a car accident, but her baby was delivered, authorities said Monday. Lori Jean Childs, 28, of rural Mankato, died after the car she was driving struck a protective barrier and rolled Sunday, according to Blue Earth County Sheriff LaRoy Wiebold. Childs was pronounced dead at Immanuel-St. Joseph's Hospital in Mankato. Her baby boy was delivered at the hospital and taken to the University of Minnesota Hospital, where he was in critical condition Monday. Mankato is in southern Minnesota, about 80 southwest of Minneapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Loses Court Challenge Over `Supergun'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A London High Court judge on Monday rejected an Iraqi government challenge seeking to overturn the seizure of eight steel tubes allegedly destined for a ``supergun.'' Judge Michael Nolan refused to consider the Iraqi Ministry of Industries' contention that the Customs and Excise seizure in April was unlawful. The judge also refused the Iraqi government's application for return of the tubes. The court refused an adjournment request by lawyer Bernard Cunningham, who represented the Iraqi Ministry. Cunningham said his instructions from Baghdad were to seek an adjournment until the situation in the Middle East was ``clearer'' and communications restored to normal. A previous adjournment had already been granted because of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. Nolan said the ``appropriate way'' for the Iraqi Ministry to challenge the seizure was to contest Customs and Excise proceedings to validate the seizure, which are scheduled to begin within the next few weeks. Iraq and the manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters, have insisted the tubes were for a petrochemical plant and not a long-range weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Tina Turner Ends 6-Month Foreign Tour, Taking Year Off From Performing
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Tina Turner has ended her 6{-month ``Foreign Affair'' tour that attracted 3 million fans, and says she's going to take a year off before performing again. ``I've always thought this would be the final one, but I must admit I now have mixed feelings,'' Miss Turner said through her Los Angeles publicist after Sunday's concert in Rotterdam, Netherlands. ``I'm the first woman to fill all these stadiums and the feeling from all those fans night after night was fantastic. I don't want to close that door completely,'' said Miss Turner, who turns 52 on Nov. 26. ``I'm going away for about a year and when I'm ready to return I just hope the fans will want whatever I have to offer.'' The Grammy Award winner, whose most famous hits include ``Nut Bush City Limits,'' ``Proud Mary'' and ``River Deep, Mountain High,'' concluded the tour before an audience of 30,000 packing Ahoy sports hall. Miss Turner, whose real name is Anna Mae Bullock, became famous in the mid-1960s in a duo with her then-husband, Ike Turner. Her tour began in April in Belgium and continued for 121 performances in 19 countries. More than 120,000 people, including Britain's Princess Diana, attended a concert at Woburn Abbey, a 15th century manor outside London. ``She will take an extended time off, but it is safe to say she will perform again,'' said her Los Angeles publicist, Maureen O'Connor. The tour helped push sales of Miss Turner's Capitol Records album ``Foreign Affair'' to more than 5.5 million copies, said O'Connor.

DOC.HEAD: Government Warns Against Letting Contestants Dip With Dolphins
DOC.TEXT: Would-be beauty queens may not swim with captive dolphins, except possibly at four designated aquariums, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Monday. NOAA said the Marinelife Oceanarium in Gulfport, Miss., was issued a written warning because it allowed several contestants from the Miss Teen U.S.A. contest to swim with its dolphins on July 2. William W. Fox Jr., assistant administrator of NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service, said in a statement that similar violations could bring fines or loss of permits allowing the display of captive animals. Marinelife's curator, Moby Solangi, issued a statement saying the fisheries service wasted taxpayers' money by investigating the Miss Teen U.S.A. affair. ``It is clear they are responding to emotionalism of animal rights extremists,'' he said, adding that he did not believe Marinelife had violated any regulations. Miss Teen U.S.A. contestants joined the dolphins for the filming of a segment that was to be shown during the pageant's broadcast. After the investigation was announced, pageant officials dropped the dolphin segment. Ronnie Salters, a leader of Citizens for Marine Mammal Protection, called the warning ``a fair decision.'' ``We didn't really expect them to give any fine or anything like that,'' he said. Programs in which tourists are invited to swim with dolphins have been criticized as possibly harmful to both the dolphins and the people. Only four facilities in the United States, not including Marinelife, have permits allowing swim-with-the-dolphin programs. Even at those four aquariums, provisions were tightened in a ruling this summer to protect the dolphins and to warn the public of the risks of injury, the NOAA announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Bail to IRA Member
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today declined to set bail for Joseph Doherty, the Irish revoltionary who has been jailed in New York for more than seven years. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum ruled that Doherty would likely flee if his release were approved. ``The evidence is overwhelming that petitioner, if released, would pose such a substantial risk of flight that no condition of bail could reasonably assure his surrender for deportation,'' Cedarbaum said in a 23-page decision. Doherty, 35, faces alife sentence in the United Kingdom for the murder of a British officer killed in a gunfight between British troops and Doherty's four-man IRA unit. He escaped from a prison in Northern Ireland in 1981 and came to the United States a year later. He was arrested in New York in 1983 and has been imprisoned in a Manhattan jail since then. Doherty has never been charged with a crime in the United States; he's been held without bail the entire time. A call to his attorneys was not immediately returned today. Doherty's request for bail was made in the form of a writ of habeus corpus, which claimed his constitutional right to due process was violated by his lengthy imprisonment. He had sought release on bail while continuing efforts to fight deportation and gain political asylum in the United States.
