While conceding that the length of his detention was ``extremely troubling,'' the judge rejected the argument that Doherty's constitutional rights were violated. She noted that many of the constitutional protections given people accused of crimes did not apply to aliens in deportation proceedings. She also ruled that the U.S. government was not responsible for delaying his deportation proceedings. ``To the contrary, his own strategic maneuvers have caused significant delays,'' Cedarbaum said. She said Doherty's continued detention ``continues to serve the valid regulatory purpose of keeping him available for deportation.'' Cedarbaum's ruling followed a hearing, held over several days in September and October, during which Doherty testified that he was no longer a member of the IRA. He had promised the judge that he would abide by any conditions of bail and would willingly return to the United Kingdom if he lost his bid for asylum. The U.S. government, which opposed Doherty's release, called as a witness an expert on terrorism, who testified that IRA membership was a ``cradle to grave'' proposition. The almost exclusively Roman Catholic IRA is fighting to push the British out of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, join it with the Republic of Ireland and set up an all-Ireland socialist state.

DOC.HEAD: Township Violence Kills 29
DOC.TEXT: Black students demanding a boycott of final exams to protest school conditions clashed with pupils who wanted to take the tests, leaving up to 19 people dead, police said Monday. Ten more blacks were killed in other township violence, including eight apparently caught in a feud between competing taxi companies, police reported. The student violence in Bekkersdal, outside Johannesburg, began Thursday and lasted through the weekend. It was unclear if all 19 deaths were the result of student clashes, but police Capt. Eugene Opperman said he believed most were. According to police, students opposed to the year-end exams had been trying to prevent other students from taking the standardized tests, which determine whether students may proceed onto the next grade or gain admission to universities. Last year, less than half of the black students passed the tests, compared with a pass rate of more than 90 percent for white students. The white-led government spends five times as much to educate a white pupil as a black pupil in South Africa, and anti-apartheid activists have complained for years about problems in the black schools. Opperman said not all the people involved in the Bekkersdal clashes were students. He said one body was found Monday, but it was unclear when the person died. He also did not know when the other 18 deaths occurred. Police used tear gas Monday to disperse stone-throwers, Opperman said. There were reports of arson, and one youth was seriously wounded in a stabbing, police Capt. Henriette Bester said. Also Monday, police said eight people died when men in vans randomly stabbed and shot people Sunday in the township of Kutloanong, 140 miles southwest of Johannesburg. They were believed to have been victims of a feud between taxi companies that began fighting each other last week in Kutloanong. Before Sunday's attacks, three people had died in the taxi war. There are an estimated 100,000 privately owned taxi-vans operating in black areas nationwide, and violent disputes over routes and passengers occur regularly. Also, the daily police unrest report said one man died in the township of Alexandra, outside Johannesburg. Another man was stabbed to death in Mganga Baboyi, a township in the eastern province of Natal, the unrest report added. It did not say when those deaths occurred. More than 5,000 people have died in Natal since 1986 in fighting between supporters of the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party. Both groups oppose apartheid but disagree on tactics to fight it and on their view of a future South Africa. Factional fighting involving university students broke out over the weekend in the Johannesburg township of Soweto, and one man was critically injured, officials said. The fighting involved students from the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg and occurred at a Soweto dormitory used by the university.

DOC.HEAD: Joint European Pledge to Stabilize Carbon Dioxide Emissions
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen European nations on Monday agreed to keep carbon dioxide emissions in their nations at 1990 levels to curb the threat of global warming. They also pledged to urge other countries to follow suit. But the draft of a ministerial declaration that will conclude a 10-day U.N. conference on global warming indicated that Washington's slower approach to controlling emissions is likely to prevail in the final document Wednesday. The United States has argued that in view of the great cost of limiting greenhouse gas emissions, more research is needed before drastic measures are taken. The target of limiting carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2,000 was set at a joint meeting of the environment ministers of the 12-nation European Community and six-nation European Free Trade Association. A joint statement invited ``all industralized nations to take similar action.'' Scientists have identified carbon dioxide as the main contributor to the so-called greenhouse effect, induced by heat-trapping gases. Other greenhouse gases are methane, nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons. Industrialized nations contribute three-quarters of all man-made greenhouse gases. Carlo Ripa de Meana, the EC environment commissioner, said the accord strengthened the European position at the conference, attended by about 700 scientists from about 100 nations. Ministers from more than 80 countries, including several heads of government, are expected at the two-day windup of the U.N. conference. The session will set the stage for formal negotiations in Washington next February on an international treaty on global warming. ``Europeans are leading in this battle,'' Ripa de Meana said. ``The question of how to persuade the United States and the Soviet Union will be a central task of this conference.'' But environmental groups attending the conference said the Europeans already had backed away from earlier proposals. Jeremy Leggett of Greenpeace Britain said he thought some governments would strip the final document of any targets. He said the United States, the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia were the principal opponents to swift action. The 30-point draft declaration circulated Monday avoids setting targets and makes no firm commitments toward reducing the greenhouse effect. Scientists at the conference have said immediate action is needed. The draft declaration said that over the past decade a ``clear scientific consensus has emerged'' on global warming expected to occur in the next century. In a paper approved unanimously on Saturday, scientists agreed that by the year 2005 many industrialized nations would be able to cut their output of carbon dioxide by at least 20 percent. A preliminary EC text had initially proposed that the ministerial declaration, to be issued at the close of the conference on Wednesday, should set targets for industrialized countries to stabilize emissions. The latest draft ``welcomes'' the European accord on carbon dioxide stabilization but omits any reference to targets for other countries. Other developed countries are urged ``to establish targets and-or feasible national programs or strategies which will have significant effects on limiting emissions.'' ``This waffle lets the United States off the hook,'' said Steward Boyle of the Climate Action Network, another environmental group. ``It means 18 months of doing nothing. Needless to say, the United States is delighted.'' The international treaty on global warming will be signed in mid-1992 at a conference in Rio de Janeiro.

DOC.HEAD: Hospitals Turn Away Patients Because of Doctor Strike
DOC.TEXT: Government hospitals turned away patients Monday as 10,000 doctors went on strike to protest the government health policy. Only critical cases were being treated during the 24-hour strike, said Mostafa Jll Mohiuddin, of the Bangladesh Medical Association. But an indefinite strike may be called if the government ignores the protest, he said. The doctors want government supporters to quit the eight-member committee set up by President Hussain Muhammad Ershad to forumalte health policy. The committee was appointed after a two-month strike that doctors called earlier this year when the government tried to ban private practice. In a separate anti-government action, about 3,000 people demonstrated outside the radio and television centers against what they called government propaganda on the state-run media. The protests were part of an ongoing campaign to pressure Ershad to resign and to hold free elections. One demonstration by 1,500 protesters at the radio center was led by Sheik Hasina, head of the Awami League and one of two main opposition politicians. The other opposition figure, Khaleda Zia of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, led about 1,000 people in a demonstration at a television center on the outskirts of Dhaka. About 500 people joined separate protests. Ershad seized power in a bloodless military coup in 1982. The opposition says three elections since then were rigged to keep him in office. The opposition campaign began in earnest in November 1987 and flares up periodically. The campaign was renewed in mid-October, when eight people were killed by police during demonstrations. There are no private radio or television stations in Bangladesh.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Asks Iraq To Resupply US Embassy In Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `The embassy...' with al-Mashat comments. Picks up 6th graf prvs, `To bolster...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Reverend Jesse Jackson urged Iraq's ambassador Monday to persuade his government to provide food, electricity and water to the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Jackson, who visited Iraq in August shortly after the country invaded Kuwait, said the Iraqis could improve the diplomatic climate by resupplying the American embassy in Kuwait. ``It would cost you little and gain a great deal if you were to allow basic supplies and amenities such as water and electricity to the people in those restricted quarters,'' Jackson said in a letter he sent to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein earlier this month. Jackson reiterated his request in a 20-minute meeting with Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat during which he also asked the Iraqis to arrange an airlift so that American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait could be home by Christmas. Al-Mashat told reporters after the meeting that he had relayed Jackson's message to Baghdad. He also repeated Iraq's pledge that it will release all foreign hostages if the U.N. Security Council or two of five nations - France, the Soviet Union, China, Germany and Japan - guarantee there will be no attack on Iraq. To bolster his plea, Jackson said his group, The National Rainbow Coalition, would circulate a petition seeking to have Iraq send supplies to the embassy. Eight diplomats and 19 other Americans are trapped at the embassy in Kuwait, where conditions are said to be deteriorating rapidly. ``The lights are off. All refrigerators are off... water is off'' and supplies are quickly running out, Jackson said. The Americans are digging trenches to use as latrines, he said. Jackson echoed the U.S. position that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and restore that country's sovereign leaders. But he said it was his impression that the Iraqis might be inclined to seek a diplomatic solution if both sides could tone down their rhetoric. ``Maximum rhetoric begets maximum rhetoric,'' Jackson said, referring to the tough line recently taken by President Bush and his secretary of state James A. Baker III.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 150 Because Of Rumors About Stolen Genitals
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 150 people for spreading rumors that sorcerers have been stealing men's genitals - rumors that led to at least three deaths, police said Monday. Deputy Police Commissioner James Danbaba announced the arrests after rumors about the purported thefts swept the West African capital. Mobs killed at least three people accused of stealing the organs. One policewoman who rushed to the aid of an alleged sorcerer was beaten by the crowd and remained in a coma Monday. According to the rumors, the alleged sorcerers approached strangers and asked them for directions. Later, the victims reportedly said their genitals were missing. Police dismissed the reports after investigators examined the supposed victims, Danbaba said.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Photo Hints at Iraqi Uranium Mine
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet satellite pictures have confirmed that an industrial operation is in place in northern Iraq, where Kurdish opposition groups have reported seeing a uranium mine, Jane's Defense Weekly said Monday. The respected defense industry magazine said the satellite photos, taken shortly after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, picked out new road systems built in the Gara mountains, 40 miles south of the Turkish border. John Moore, a mineralogist from Imperial College, said the photos showed signs of possible excavations at two sites, the report said. Experts from the National Imagery Center near Cambridge picked out a 2,500-foot long building at the site, Jane's Defense Weekly said. Those experts suggested three possible uses: chemical weapons production, a conventional weapons site, or a nuclear-related site. There are four Iraqi military bases nearby in the rugged territory, the report said. Jane's said the Kurdistan Democratic Party has claimed its agents penetrated the security around the site this year, and found two sites were being developed. Hoshyar Zebari, the party's European representative, told Jane's one site was a uranium mine. Nearby, he said, a huge tunnel was being dug but its purpose was unknown. Iraq is believed to be working to develop nuclear weapons. In 1981, Israeli jets attacked an Iraqi nuclear reactor which was thought to be part of a weapons program. Earlier this year, British customs agents seized electronic components, which could be used in nuclear bomb triggers, before they could be put aboard an Iraqi Airways flight from London.

DOC.HEAD: Another Death Reported in Moldavia
DOC.TEXT: A policeman has died of injuries suffered in last week's ethnic clashes in Moldavia, bringing the death toll to at least four, it was reported Monday. The independent Interfax news agency said the policeman, who was Moldavian, died in a hospital near the city of Dubossary, the site of Friday's clash between Moldavian Interior Ministry troops and Russian and Ukrainian separatists. According to the Moldavian Interior Ministry, three people were killed Friday and nine suffered gunshot wounds in the republic's eastern Dniester region, where about 200,000 Russians and Ukrainians live. The Tass news agency had reported Saturday that six people were killed and 30 injured. Before Monday's report, all the casualties had been identified as either Russians or Ukrainians. Viktor Pushkashu, vice president of the Moldavian Parliament, went on radio in the southwestern Soviet republic Monday and detailed the legislature's call for all volunteer, self-defense groups to disband and disarm, Tass reported. The republic of Moldavia, which has taken steps toward independence, faces separatist movements in the Dniester region by Russians and Ukrainians, and by the Gagauz, a Turkish Christian minority in its southern area. Both the Gagauz and Dniester separatists claim discrimination by Moldavians. Moldavian President Mircha Snegur appealed Sunday for an end to street demonstrations and urged his parliament to reconsider laws that have stirred unrest in the republic. A law that made Moldavian the national language has caused resentment among Russian speakers and the Gagauz, who speak a Turkic tongue. Moldavian - identical to Romanian, except for the Cyrillic characters imposed on the republic under Stalin's reign - is spoken by two-thirds of the 4.3 million people in the republic that borders Romania. A funeral rally to mourn the dead from Friday's unrest was scheduled for Tuesday in the Dniester region despite Snegur's appeal for an end to public demonstrations. Pushkashu appealed for a cooling of passions in Moldavia. ``It is necessary to make people return to work, as many of them have recently been diverted from their daily business,'' Pushkashu was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Former Contras Pressure Government For Aid With Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: Former Contra rebels staging a hunger strike in a Managua church have joined others protesting that the government has reneged on promises of aid to the demobilized anti-Sandinista guerrillas. About 200 former Contras blocked the Rama Road - the only overland route into southeastern Nicaragua - for the sixth day, cutting off a chunk of the region from the rest of the country. The church occupation, which began Sunday, was the latest action by the former rebels to pressure President Violeta Chamorro's government into coming through with programs designed to help the fighters rejoin civilian life. Other recent Contra actions included looting government warehouses in the Atlantic Coast town of Puerto Cabezas, a shootout with police in northern Waslala, and taking over the Sandinista Front headquarters in northern Quilali. ``In the same way that they (the government) pressured us to disarm, we're pressuring them to give us answers to our problems,'' said former rebel William Castellon, one of seven men occupying the Santo Domingo Church. Castellon said he was political adviser to the disbanded Democratic Revolutionary Alliance, which fought on Nicaragua's southern front and was directed by dissident Nicaraguans based in Costa Rica. Hunger strikers allowed some reporters into the church. Lt. Consuelo Solorzano, a spokeswoman at the Interior Ministry, said police had not tried to dislodge the dissidents because church officials have not requested help. But police patrolled the neighborhood on the outskirts of Managua. The former guerrillas say the government has failed to hand over promised land, food, medicines and building materials. About 20,000 Contras finished disarming in June after Mrs. Chamorro and her 14-party coalition defeated the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. They were promised aid in exchange for turning in their weapons. ``Violence still is a risk to democracy in Nicaragua,'' Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the archbishop of Managua, said in his sermon Sunday at his Santo Domingo Church just before the Contras occupied it. Obando said: ``The government must make an effort to speed up fulfillment of its promises.'' After the Mass ended, seven men walked into the church and declared themselves on a hunger strike. ``Carlos Hurtado, assassin of peasants in Yolaina,'' read a hand-written poster that hunger strikers tacked to the closed church doors. Hurtado is minister of the interior, the department that controls police. One person died and 14 were wounded in the south-central village of Yolaina last week when police and soldiers, still controlled by the Sandinistas, opened fire during a protest march. Castellon said the former rebels also wanted Mrs. Chamorro's government to disband the Sandinista police and army. The Contras resent having had to demobilize while the Sandinista police and Sandinista Peoples Army remain the official law enforcement and military forces in Nicaragua. That resentment is compounded because Mrs. Chamorro's pro-U.S. government allows both forces to retain the name of the leftist Sandinista Front, the Contras' enemy during nine years of guerrilla war. Two weeks ago the Interior Ministry, responding to Contra pressure, ordered that authority in Rio Blanco in north-central Nicaragua, be turned over to the Rural Police, a government force made up of demobilized Contras. The Contra blockade of the Rama Road, which is also the only overland route into the Atlantic Coast town of Bluefields, began Wednesday. Protestors there are demanding land and the withdrawal of Sandinista Police from the region.

DOC.HEAD: Sixth Person People Arrested in Halloween Attack
DOC.TEXT: A sixth young man was arrested Monday and charged with murder in a Halloween ``thrill'' rampage that left one homeless man dead and nine others injured on Ward's Island. Five of the defendants - one only 13, one 15 and one 16 - were arrested Sunday on murder charges in the death of Carlos Melendez, whose throat was slashed. More arrests are expected, according to police spokeswoman Sgt. Tina Mohrmann. The attack was the latest in a series of vicious gang attacks in the city, including the 1989 attack on a jogger in Central Park and the slaying of a Utah tourist during a subway mugging this summer. About a dozen youths, some wearing Halloween masks, screamed ``Trick or Treat'' during last Wednesday's attack on homeless men heading to a shelter on the East River island. Police said the youths were armed with bats, pipes, knives and meat cleavers. Police said the group apparently attacked the homeless men for thrills. Melendez, 35, died at the scene. Three other men required from 30 to 55 stitches to close head cuts. Detectives followed up on information from several sources, including anonymous tips, to arrest the six, said Mohrmann. Charged with murder were Robert Sherman, 23, of the Bronx, and four East Harlem residents: Hector Torres, 15, Aaron Ware, 13, and his brother Raymond Fenner, 22, and John Moreno, 16. Moreno was arrested Monday. An 18-year-old, Eric Williams, was charged with attempted murder in the attack on Roosevelt Jones, who was beaten about the face with a pipe, Mohrmann said. The gang waited in a dark wooded area and attacked the men as they walked over a narrow footbridge that connects East Harlem to a men's shelter on the island. The attack began at 9:15 p.m. and ended shortly before the footbridge closed at 10 p.m. ``It was Halloween, the homeless are there, they're an easy target,'' Capt. Daniel McKenna of Manhattan detectives said last week.

DOC.HEAD: US And Venezuela Agree to Help Each Other Combat the Drug Trade
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Venezuela signed an agreement on Monday to exchange financial information in a joint effort to fight illicit drug trafficking and money laundering. Under the agreement, both countries will exchange currency transaction information recorded by their financial institutions beginning Jan. 1. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who signed the pact for the United States, called it ``another significant step in the effort to track illegal profits around the world and put criminals behind bars.'' ``By developing a network of countries committed to identifying the profits of narcotics trafficking, we can begin to deprive traffickers of their financial lifeline and dismantle their criminal organizations,'' he said. Signing the agreement for Venezuela were Finance Minister Roberto Pocaterra and Pedro R. Tinoco Jr., central bank president.

DOC.HEAD: War In Gulf Would Have No Winners, King Says
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein of Jordan warned that ``no one will leave a winner'' from a war in the Persian Gulf and said Monday he fears armed conflict might be imminent. The Jordanian monarch made his remarks during an interview with Radio France International before meeting lwith President Francois Mitterrand. The king told RFI that nations contributing to the multinational force in the gulf are beginning to rethink the possibility of war in the world's largest oil-producing region. He named no specific nations. Asked if he thought war was imminent, Hussein responded: ``If it's going to happen, it will be very imminent. But I don't wish it.'' ``If we look at the situation on the ground, there exists the possibility of an incident happening, either by accident or on purpose,'' Hussein said. Jordan would suffer enormously in a war and already is affected by the U.N. embargo against Iraq, his country's largest trading partner, Hussein said. The embargo was imposed after Iraqi troops occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2. Hussein described his talks with Mitterrand as positive and underscored what he called ``common efforts'' by France and Jordan to find a peaceful solution to the Middle East's problems. Hussein urged an Arab solution to the crisis, something Mitterrand has said offers little chance of success, presidential spokesman Hubert Vedrine said. France has urged a diplomatic solution to the conflict but insists Iraq comply with U.N. resolutions demanding that Saddam Hussein free all foreign hostages and withdraw his troops from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: More Vegetables, Less Fat for School Lunches
DOC.TEXT: Dietary guidelines published by the federal government Monday look a lot like the old ones - eat more vegetables, less fat, sugar and salt - but there should be a greater effect this time. The guidelines will cause changes in school lunches eaten by millions of young Americans and in meals for mothers in government feeding programs. The recommendations, said Health Secretary Louis Sullivan, are also more specific than guidelines issued in 1980 and 1985. The new ones ``include more positive advice, oriented to the total diet, with clear wording and specific numbers,'' he said. For example, the 27-page booklet of guidelines being distributed by the government says Americans should get 30 percent or less of their calories from fat, with only 10 percent of that from animal fat and tropical oils. Other guidelines: -Eat two or three servings daily of meat, poultry, fish, dry beans or eggs. But no more than 6 ounces a day. -Trim fat from meat. Remove the skin from poultry and have cooked dry beans and peas instead of meat occasionally. -Have two or three servings of milk and dairy products daily. A serving is one cup of milk or yogurt or about 1{ ounces of cheese. -Have three or more servings of vegetables daily, eating dark-green, leafy and deep-yellow vegetables, dry beans and peas often. Also eat starchy vegetables, such as potatoes and corn. -Eat two or more servings of fruit, such as one medium apple, an orange or a banana, daily. -Use sugar and salt in moderation. -If you drink alcoholic beverages, do so in moderation. The guidelines define moderation in drinking alcoholic beverages as one drink per day for women and no more than two drinks a day for men. One drink means 12 ounces of regular beer, five ounces of wine or 1.5 ounces of distilled spirits, 80 proof. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the new guidelines would influence the national school lunch program run by USDA and the Women Infant and Children program, which provides food, vouchers for food and nutritional information to poor, pregnant women, nursing mothers and their babies. ``We reach a large segment of the public with our food programs,'' said Yeutter, who released the guidelines at a press conference with Sullivan. ``As children begin to eat with the family, usually at about 2 years of age, they should be encouraged to choose diets that are lower in fat and saturated fat and that provide the calories and nutrients they need for normal growth,'' says the pamphlet. What's revolutionary in the new recommendations, says the American School Food Service Association, is that the government is applying the guidelines to children for the first time. Anne Gennings, president of the school food service association, said schools across the country already offer a variety of food choices lower in fat, sugar and sodium. The report reinforces that effort, she said. But Ellen Haas, executive director of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, said the government could do more. ``What's important now is not focusing on the guidelines themselves, but concrete action plans for translating the guidelines,'' she said, advocating laws or regulations requiring schools to cut meals to no more than 30 percent fat, for example. The Center for Science in the Public Interest also was critical, saying the guidelines were weak and ``devoid of the urgency that the situation deserves.'' ``The government's mealy-mouthed advice can hardly be expected to spur the major overhaul in eating habits that most Americans should make,'' said Jane Hurley, the non-profit group's associate nutritionist. Food industry organizations, however, were supportive. ``The Salt Institute is pleased that the revised Dietary Guidelines now encourage Americans to `use salt or sodium in moderation.''' said the trade group, which opposed the words ``avoid salt'' in the 1985 guidelines. The American Meat Institute said the guidelines were ``a prudent road map to healthy, delicious and varied diets'' that ``provide ample room for all foods from all food groups to be included in Americans' diets.'' ``Today's lean, trimmed beef fits well into the kinds of diets being recommended,'' said the National Cattlemen's Association.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-German Chancellor Willy Brandt Arrives in Baghdad
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt arrived in this capital Monday night on a personal mission to win the release of hundreds of Iraqi-held hostages. The British government has criticized the effort and Brandt has been unable to stir up much support outside Germany for the trip. The German government says it backs the journey even though the 12-nation European Economic Community last week stated there should be no negotiations with Baghdad on hostages. Brandt, honorary head of the opposition Social Democrats in Germany, says his trip is a private mission and that he is not going to Baghdad as a representative of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government. In an interview with the Bonn newspaper General Anzeiger, Brandt said he would ``listen to'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein but not negotiate with him. Brandt traveled in a chartered Lufthansa Airbus that can carry about 250 people, bearing flowers and letters from relatives of the estimated 400 German hostages. Brandt is the latest in a line of former government leaders to visit Iraq on missions to win freedom for hostages, known as ``guests'' in Iraq, and try to find a peaceful solution to the three-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. At the same time, however, he said ``I hope I can help people held captive there, and not just our own (Germans),'' the newspaper reported in its Monday editions. Also visiting Baghdad is former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Testifies She Saw Her Father Kill Her Playmate 21 Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: A woman described to a jury Monday how her father cracked her playmate's skull with a rock 21 years ago. Eileen Franklin-Lipsker, 29, also testified in the murder trial of her father that he threatened to kill her if she didn't keep quiet about the bludgeoning of 8-year-old Susan Nason. ``I saw hair that was no longer attached. I saw something whitish. I saw blood,'' Franklin-Lipsker said. ``I saw him approaching Susie with his hands up above his head with a rock. I screamed, I yelled,'' Franklin-Lipsker testified. ``The next thing that I heard was two blows. It sounded terrible. It sounded like a crack.'' She said she repressed the memory until last year, when she went to police after memories flooded back as she looked at her own daughter, who bears a strong resemblance to the dead girl. George Franklin Sr., 51, a former firefighter, was charged with murder. He pleaded innocent and faces a possible life sentence if convicted. Franklin-Lipsker said Susan crumpled and fell to the ground after Franklin struck her Sept. 22, 1969. She said she ran to her father's van, where he grabbed her and knocked her to the ground. ``He said `It's over now. You've got to stop this. It's over now.' ... I was screaming,'' Franklin-Lipsker testified. Susan's body was discovered in December 1969 in a ravine off a highway. A blood-stained rock was nearby. Franklin told his daughter she would be blamed if she told authorities, Franklin-Lipsker testified. ``He said, `If you don't stop this, I'll have to kill you,''' she said. ``I was terrified but I absolutely believed him.'' Franklin's lawyer, Douglas Horngrad, said Franklin-Lipsker has told often conflicting versions of the slaying. The Franklin family, including a son and three other daughters, lived in the same neighborhood as the Nasons in Foster City in 1969. Franklin and his wife were divorced in 1977. Prosecutor Elaine Tipton said she planned to call more than 40 witnesses, including Franklin's ex-wife and another daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Roy Rogers Home from Hospital for Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Cowboy crooner Roy Rogers celebrated his 79th birthday Monday, finding his happy trail led home after surgery last month. ``He's not up to jumping up and down yet,'' said Roy ``Dusty'' Rogers Jr. His father underwent surgery Oct. 21 to correct an aneurysm in his aorta, the body's main artery. The actor-singer, released Friday from St. Mary Desert Valley Hospital, is on his feet and able to walk around the house, his son said. Recovery is expected to take six to eight weeks. Rogers starred in 87 Westerns, including 35 with his wife, Dale Evans. He recently recorded a country-western record album in Nashville with guest appearances by Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings and thers. During the recording session, 35 artists also joined Rogers in the studio to sing ``Happy Trails,'' the theme song for Rogers and Miss Evans, 77. Family tradition is to share one cake for three Rogers birthdays, because of their proximity, Dusty Rogers said. Dusty Rogers turned 44 on Oct. 28. His mother's birthday was Oct. 31.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Prosecution Of Cable System Carrying Playboy Channel
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to allow the prosecution of some Puerto Rico cable TV systems that carry The Playboy Channel, rejecting arguments that states' anti-obscenity efforts may be hampered unduly. The justices, without comment, left intact rulings that such prosecutions are pre-empted by federal law. In a separate case, the court let stand a ruling that lets prosecutors punish businesses convicted of dealing in obscenity by seizing their property. The court, again without comment, rejected an adult bookstore's challenge to an Illinois anti-pornography law. At issue in the cable TV case was the effect of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, which imposes mandatory access obligations on cable operators whose systems have at least 36 active channels. The law says such operators must make available, on a first-come, first-served basis, a certain number of channels for commercial use by programmers not affiliated with the cable system. Once an unaffiliated programmer obtains access, the cable operator is prohibited from exercising any editorial control over the programming transmitted on that channel. But the federal law also states that cable operators cannot be held accountable for any libel, obscenity or false advertising carried on a channel it surrendered under the mandatory access provisions. In the spring of 1987, a prosecutor in Puerto Rico's Department of Justice notified cable operators that criminal obscenity charges would be filed against all systems transmitting The Playboy Channel. Within a few months, all cable systems but one - Teleponce Inc. - had dropped The Playboy Channel, which features so-called adult entertainment. Playboy Enterprises Inc., which through a wholly owned subsidiary distributed The Playboy Channel, and the Puerto Rico Cable Television Association, a trade group, then sued the island commonwealth's Department of Justice. The suit, invoking a federal civil rights law, accused Puerto Rico officials of unlawfully interfering with free-speech rights. U.S. District Judge Jaime Pieras Jr. barred authorities from taking any action against any cable operator carrying The Playboy Channel under the federal Cable Act's mandatory access provisions. The judge said local obscenity prosecutions of such cable operators were precluded by the federal law. The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that ruling last June. In the case acted on today, the Chicago-based 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld an Illinois law challenged by Sequoia Books Inc., owner of the Denmark II bookstore in Kendall County. Sequoia Books was convicted of selling obscene materials 12 times between January 1985 and September 1987. An Illinois law that took effect Jan. 1, 1989, lets authorities seize property ``derived from or used to commit obscenity offenses.'' Any business convicted at least twice of obscenity violations is subject to forfeiting its property. The appeals court said the law may not be applied retroactively but said Sequoia's property may be seized for any obscenity violation from 1989 onward. The bookstore's owners said the law operates as a prior restraint on free expression. The 7th Circuit court rejected the argument, noting that the Illinois law is less sweeping than the seizure provisions of a federal anti-racketeering law that has survived similar challenges. Sexually explicit material, often characterized as pornography, is not necessarily obscene. Obscenity, a legal term, must be determined in a judicial proceeding. Sexually explicit material judged obscene enjoys no free-speech protection. If the material is not found to be obscene, it is protected by constitutional free-speech guarantees.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviets Asked to Join in Some Council Actions
DOC.TEXT: The Council of Europe, marking the 40th anniversary of its human rights charter, declared Monday that it wants the United States and the Soviet Union to join in some of its functions. The council is the oldest postwar body promoting European cooperation. On Tuesday it is to admit Hungary as its first member from the former Communist bloc. The 23-nation council issued a statement at the end of a meeting Monday saying it wanted to help coordinate human rights issues for the CSCE, or Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. That organization is a loosely defined body of 34 nations that has been a forum for talks between Cold War enemies. ``For this purpose, it (the Council of Europe) should adjust its structures and working methods to enable all the states participating in the CSCE which are not council members, including Canada, the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A., to take part in some of its intergovernmental and parliamentary activities in the human rights field on an equal footing,'' the declaration said. Earlier Monday, Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis opened the meeting by calling for the council's assembly to develop into a parliament bringing together the former Communist bloc and the West, including the United States. A U.S. official said Washington wanted to work with the Council of Europe in aiding emerging Eastern European democracies. But the official - Richard Schifter, assistant secretary of State for human rights - said the United States was unlikely to become a member of the Council of Europe. ``Joining the Council of Europe would mean that final judgments of U.S. courts can be reviewed and set aside,'' he said. Such a situation would require amending the Constitution, he added. ``Rather than deal with this aspect of it, there's many things we can do together,'' he said after Monday's meeting. The session brought together council ministers and observers from Eastern Europe, the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union and other states. They discussed what role the council would have in the post-Cold War era. The Council of Europe is hoping to emerge as a political counterpart to organizations like NATO, which has stressed military cooperation, and the European Community, which has focused on economic cooperation. In his speech, De Michelis suggested that the council's Assembly become the parliament for the CSCE countries. ``Only by maintaining the bigger picture involving the North American democracy, will it be possible to face the question, of historic dimensions, of the relations between Europe and the Soviet Union,'' he said. However, the United States has raised objections to the plan. Washington has traditionally been wary of the CSCE because of its unwieldly size and the fact that the U.S. voice carries only as much weight as that of the other CSCE participants. The Council of Europe's secretary-general, Catherine Lalumiere, said many speakers Monday suggested using the Council's European Human Rights Convention as the basis for human-rights accords regulating the post-Cold War order. ``It is essential to start building the Europe of the future on a sound basis,'' she said. The convention is the best-known of the 130 treaties signed by Council of Europe members. It is unique in allowing individuals to sue their governments in an international court whose decisions are binding. Lalumiere said other conclusions reached Monday included the need to reduce the backlog of such human-rights cases. There was also a need to give fresh impulse to the European Social Charter, which focuses on social and economic rights, she said. The Council of Europe includes Austria, Belgium, Britain, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Four Prisoners Stage Daring Helicopter Escape
DOC.TEXT: A hijacked helicopter plucked four convicts from a prison rooftop Monday and flew them toward the Spanish border, police said. The prisoners, armed with knives, took the keys for the main cell block from three guards and climbed to the roof, police said. They demanded to negotiate with authorities the release of another prisoner from solitary confinement. Police said the inmates apparently were stalling for time until the helicopter arrived. Police were surrounding the building as the helicopter arrived and then lowered a rope ladder. The prisoners clambered aboard and the helicopter headed for the Spanish border, 30 miles away. Police said the prisoners appeared to be led by Frederic Boulay, 28, convicted in 1984 of two murders and 17 attempted killings and sentenced to 20 years in jail. The other prisoners - Gilbert Ghislain, Jose Dos Santos and Hamid Mamouz - were serving 20-year terms for murder or armed robbery. The helicopter belonged to a company in Toulouse, Heli-Inter. A spokesman said the pilot, Claud Berschied, took off Monday afternoon with a woman ``wishing an aerial baptism.'' Berscheid landed a few hours later to refuel at an airport in Blagnac, police said. There, he apparently picked up a male passenger who police believe hijacked the helicopter, forcing the pilot to head for Lannemezan. The helicopter had not been found late Monday. Boulay, Ghislain and seven other inmates escaped from the high-security Lannemezan prison last December, blowing off a cellblock door with explosives and climbing over a wall with ropes. All eight were eventually recaptured.

DOC.HEAD: Helms, Gantt Make Final Senate Pitches
DOC.TEXT: Incumbent Sen. Jesse Helms said Monday he had been forced into running a negative Senate campaign, and Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt said he had stuck to the high road. ``It has been a spirited debate, albeit a vicious one,'' Helms told reporters on the final day of campaiging before the election. He repeated his charges that Gantt has lied about his record. ``I regret his tone,'' Helms said. ``We had hoped we could run a positive campaign, but from the beginning they came in with slashing commercials ....'' Helms' speeches and ads in the last week accused Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, of supporting racial quotas in jobs. Other ads accused Gantt of running a ``secret campaign'' aimed at getting blacks to the polls. But Helms, who is seeking a fourth term, denied that his campaign had injected race into the contest. ``Race is not an issue in this campaign,'' Helms said. ``I was born white and he was born black and there is nothing either one of us could do about it. ``We have not made an issue of race, but he has gone around the state pleading for the bloc vote. He has right to do that, but he has injected race into the campaign.'' In Newark, N.J., a federal judge ruled Monday that the Republican National Committee was not involved in efforts aimed at intimidating black and elderly voters in the Helms-Gantt race. Democrats had accused the national GOP of indirectly aiding a ``ballot security'' program for Helms. The Democrats' complaint said that violated a 1982 consent decree on voter intimidation that was issued in the federal judge's court. The ruling centered on mailings sent by North Carolina Republicans that warned voters in predominantly minority districts that it was a federal crime to provide election officials with false information. Gantt told more than 1,000 people at a rally in Raleigh that he had campaigned on values that are important to the state. ``We've said it was important for us to care about our children, to care about the environment, to care about health care, to care about the human condition,'' Gantt said. ``We've kept to the high road. We're going to win on tomorrow, that's right. How sweet that's going to be. ``We want to turn things around. We don't want to have the divisiveness that has characterized our senior senator.'' Democratic Sen. Terry Sanford said the election would send a message to the world. ``People all over the nation, indeed all over the world, are watching this election more than any other,'' Sanford said. ``We now have the opportunity to let people know what kind of people we are.'' Federal drug czar William Bennett, who accompanied Helms on his flying tour of six cities, said he wanted ``to try to prevent this national mugging organized by liberals from taking place.''

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Settles On Charges Of Billing Subscribers For Unwanted Books
DOC.TEXT: Field Publications has settled charges that it mailed books to its subscribers that they had not asked for or agreed to receive, and then billed them for payment, the Federal Trade Commission said Monday. Field, the publisher of Weekly Reader Books and other book plans, said it has acted to correct shortcomings of which the FTC had complained. Field spokeswoman Pat Sears said the company offers its book club members two or three opportunities a year to purchase ``quality materials'' and ``the FTC felt that we needed to do a better job of explaining how these programs work.'' ``We agreed with them. In September of 1989, we put into place a number of changes, including some not requested by the FTC, to assure that our customers would be properly served,'' Ms. Sears said from the company's office in Middletown, Conn. The FTC said the publishing company will pay civil penalties of $175,000 and will be prohibited in the future from the practices complained of, under a consent decree filed in federal court. A complaint acompanying the decree said Field mailed additional books to subscribers who had consented to receive the company's regular subscription books. It said the customers had not requested the shipment of the additional books or given express consent to having them mailed. Field then sent the customers invoices and dunned them for payment for the books, the complaint said. The FTC said this violates the Unordered Merchandise Act, a postal statute. It prohibits the mailing of unordered merchandise except for free samples that are clearly and conspicuously marked. It also prohibits the mailing or any bill or dunning notice to a recipient of unordered merchandise.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Strike Leader Has a Revolutionary Past and Present
DOC.TEXT: Striking Daily News columnist Juan Gonzalez doesn't object to being called a revolutionary, long after he began to agitate on behalf of fellow Puerto Ricans as a youth. ``When there's injustice, you have to fight it,'' he said. ``I still consider myself a revolutionary, if you mean someone who gets at the root of a problem in society and tries to correct it.'' Gonzalez, a strike organizer for The Newspaper Guild, was once a leader of the militant youth group Young Lords. His past draws respect and a certain amount of amusement from his colleagues at the newspaper. In the Daily News library, his photo file still says: ``Puerto Rican revolutionary.'' ``That's crossed out. Now, it says, `Daily News columnist,''' said fellow striker Robert Gearty. Gonzalez file may or may not be changed again, depending on the outcome of the strike by nine of 10 unions at the newspaper that has thrust him into the role of a strike leader. One minute, he is talking through a megaphone at a rally in front of the News building. The next, he is meeting with Jesse Jackson before a rally. Gonzalez' colleagues on the picket line react energetically when he puts his hand on their shoulders to discuss how to produce the next union newsletter or strategy on the picket line. Gonzalez is co-chairman of his union's strike organizing committee. ``Isn't Juan amazing?'' Gearty said. ``I saw him the other day. I said, `Juan, where do I go to sign up for the Young Lords?''' The Young Lords battled with authorities to push the cause of Puerto Rican independence and fair treatment of Puerto Ricans in the United States. During the group's heyday from 1969 to 1974, Gonzalez served as its minister of education and health and at one point as minister of defense. They blocked major avenues in East Harlem with garbage to protest poor trash collection. They collected eggs, bacon and bread from merchants and cooked breakfast for schoolchildren. They staged sit-ins at a hospital and a church, the latter leading to the arrest of 110 demonstrators. At one point, the group tried to replace police at the front of a parade, leading police to attack the demonstrators and causing a major disturbance. ``We got a little arrogant in our popularity,'' Gonzalez said. ``We were blamed, and rightly so, for a raucous ... mess.'' Born in Puerto Rico 43 years ago, Gonzalez was raised in New York by a mother who was a garment worker and a father who labored in a restaurant. Both belonged to unions. In 1968, Gonzalez refused to accept his diploma from Columbia University when the school asked him to plead guilty to violating university regulations for his role in a student strike that shut down the school for six weeks. The same year, he participated in protests at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Gonzalez spent the next decade steam pressing men's suits at a garment factory and as a pressman at a printing plant because ``I was afraid if I became a professional I would become a sellout or a wimp.'' He eventually gave in to his lifelong dream of writing for a newspaper by accepting a clerk's position at the Philadelphia Daily News, where he quickly became a reporter and helped organize a strike in 1985. Marnal Whitley, a striking librarian, said when he first learned about Gonzalez's past, ``I thought maybe it was an ironic twist, that maybe he had sold out.'' ``But when I read his columns, I saw he was still a revolutionary. He is still on the side of the oppressed,'' Whitley said.

DOC.HEAD: Voters to Cast Ballots in Clerk's Home
DOC.TEXT: Larry and Bonnie Carlson's living room will be the most popular spot in Dean Lake Township on Tuesday. That's where the township's 42 registered voters will go to cast their ballots. Residents usually vote at the township hall. But the old hall was so dilapidated it was deliberately burned down. And the new hall isn't ready to be used yet. So with no polling place, Bonnie Carlson, the township clerk, volunteered her home. ``We needed a place to vote, and our place was available,'' she said. The home, which overlooks the Mississippi River and is about 10 miles northeast of Crosby, is also new. The living room floor is unfinished, but that's just as well considering Tuesday's foot traffic. If past history is a guide, most of the township's registered voters will cast ballots. The township's single voting booth has been set up in the living room. Tuesday morning, Carlson will set up a table for the three election judges. Then she'll start serving coffee and cookies. Carlson isn't concerned about opening her home to the voters. ``I know all the people,'' she said. ``And we won't talk politics.''

re gulf-desert voting, The Justice Department, meanwhile, filed suit against Tennessee, the only state it said had refused to accept absentee ballot applications sent by fax by GIs stationed in the Middle East. The lawsuit seeks a court order directing Tennessee officials to accept three applications sent to Shelby County voter registars. The department also wants the state to send absentee ballots to the three GIs so they can vote in Tuesday's election. wx-rowley

DOC.HEAD: `NBC Nightly News' To Do Entire Show on American Concerns and Hopes
DOC.TEXT: In the equivalent of a newspaper devoting an entire edition to one subject, ``NBC Nightly News'' will use all of Friday's show to report on the state of the nation and how Americans feel about their country. However, if there is major breaking news that day, ``we'll put it on, of course,'' said Steve Friedman, the program's executive producer. NBC announced the unusual move Monday. The ``CBS Evening News'' and ABC's ``World News Tonight'' never have devoted one of their broadcasts to a single subject, spokesmen for those programs said. Friedman conceded the action was unsual but said the importance of the subject warranted it. He noted that the three network newscasts in early August were largely devoted to a single subject - the Persian Gulf crisis. Friday's ``Nightly News'' will include satellite hook-ups in which people can question their elected officials. It also will include reports on the economy, foreign competition, and young Americans entering an uncertain marketplace. Anchored by Tom Brokaw, ``Nightly'' has been battling with Dan Rather's ``CBS Evening News'' for second place in ratings in evening newscasts. Peter Jennings ``World News Tonight'' has been consistently first in the A.C. Nielsens Co. ratings.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Elections: Some Vote Absentee, A Few by Fax
DOC.TEXT: A handful of GIs voted by fax and thousands more cast absentee ballots. But other troops in Operation Desert Shield said they had too much on their minds to think about Tuesday's elections back home. ``What election is it?'' asked Sgt. Marceline Griffin, 39, of Philadelphia, an operating room technician with the 326th Medical Battalion. ``I haven't seen an absentee ballot yet.'' Cpl. Patrick Locke, 20, of Spokane, Wash., who was repairing the engine of a tanker on Monday at a forward Marine base in eastern Saudi Arabia, was equally astonished. ``I think we have so much on our mind now, and have so much work to do, we don't have time to think about it,'' he said. ``The way they vote, they help decide how long we'll be over here. I wish I knew more about it.'' A three-week ``get out the vote'' blitz on Armed Forces Radio and voting information booths in many of the big mess halls produced good results. About 100,000 applications for absentee ballots were handed out by the Judge Advocate's office of the Army Forces Central Command, which was in charge of promoting registration. The Navy launched a similar campaign for the elections, which include congressional and gubernatorial races. Sailors aboard the USS Biddle, a guided missile cruiser, voted by absentee ballot three weeks ago in Alexandria, Va. ``Voting is your right,'' said Chief Petty Officer Steven Sisk, 45, of Fremont, Calif. ``If you don't vote, don't bitch.'' Maj. Jerry Kineen, 46, of Boston, a lawyer on the staff of the Judge Advocate in the Army Forces Central Command, said it's a misconception that most troops didn't vote. ``Probably, of those who were over here, more of them voted in this election than would have voted had they not been here because it was made easier for them,'' said Lt. Col. Kevin V. Murphy, 44, of Hanover, Mass., the deputy staff judge advocate. ``They didn't have to drive down to a polling place and take time off from work to vote. We came right to them,'' he said. Marine Cpl. Daryl Cherry, 21, of Harrington, Del., watching a football game during a break from work, said: ``I know the opportunity is here to vote. Really, I don't know who to vote for. I don't even know who the candidates are. It would be like drawing straws and I'd rather not do that.'' Staff Sgt. Lee Corkran, 28, of Tucson, Ariz., who is with the Air Force Combat Camera Team, said he didn't vote because he felt removed. ``From here, America seems like some kind of dreamland,'' he said. Many servicemen said they had trouble with the mail. Cpl. Frank Gillyard Jr., 21, of Mansfield, La., with the Marine Wing Support Squadron, said he hadn't received his absentee ballot and probably wouldn't get to vote. With 60 to 90 tons of mail arriving every day, and delays on outgoing mail as well, it's impossible to say how may servicemen and women actually received ballots and voted. The election marked the debut of fax voting. ``There has been a limited voting by fax. Some of the individual cities and towns did allow this,'' said Kineen. The Justice Department, meanwhile, filed suit against Tennessee, the only state it said had refused to accept absentee ballot applications sent by fax by GIs stationed in the Middle East. The lawsuit seeks a court order directing Tennessee officials to accept three applications sent to Shelby County voter registars. The department also wants the state to send absentee ballots to the three GIs so they can vote in Tuesday's election. Murphy said a few ballots arrived by fax, and were faxed back after completion, but added, ``One of the problems of sending them by fax is that there is no envelope to put the ballot back in. It's supposed to be a secret ballot.'' Lt. Col. Bill Hagan, 43, of Key West, Fla., the staff judge advocate with the Army who is in charge of the registration program, said he sent his absentee form early. ``I'm so glad I voted because I got mail - I got campaign mail from across the board in Florida,'' he said. ``It made me feel closer to home.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds National Republicans Not Involved in Helms Mailing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs of comment by Justice Department official. Debevoise is pronounced deb'-eh-voy
DOC.TEXT: The Republican National Committee was not involved in efforts aimed at intimidating black and elderly voters in North Carolina's close U.S. Senate race, a federal judge ruled Monday. ``The Democratic National Committee has not been able to establish that the Republican National Committee is involved directly or indirectly with activities taking place in North Carolina,'' said U.S. District Judge Dickinson Debevoise. Democrats had accused the national GOP of indirectly aiding a ``ballot security'' program for Republican Sen. Jesse Helms, who is locked in a neck-and-neck race with Democrat Harvey Gantt, who is black. The Democrats' complaint said that violated a 1982 consent decree on voter intimidation that was issued in Debevoise's court. The election-eve ruling centered on mailings sent by North Carolina Republicans that warned voters in predominantly minority districts that it was a federal crime to provide election officials with false information. Party officials, Republican and Democratic, hailed the ruling. ``What the judge did today was stop a fishing expedition,'' said Thomas Kirby, an attorney retained by the RNC. ``There was no indication that we were involved in what was going on in North Carolina.'' Democrats also claimed victory. ``I'm satisfied because I want the RNC to know that we're watching,'' said Bob Bauer, the Democrats' counsel. ``We will be watching every county and precinct in North Carolina for minority disenfranchisement.'' At issue are 150,000 postcards that the North Carolina GOP sent to predominantly minority Democratic precincts. A section on the card told voters it is a federal crime ``to knowingly give false information about your name, residence or period of residence to an election official.'' Voter mailings also have been distributed to mostly elderly Democratic voters in Texas to encourage them to forego absentee ballots. The hearing did not address the Texas mailings. Debevoise found that Republicans had failed to inform their staff and state campaigns of the 1982 consent decree that bars voter intimidation. The decree was issued after the party was reported to have hired armed guards to watch over various polling places in New Jersey. Deveboise ordered national Republicans to remind their campaign staffs not to violate the decree, and suggested that Democrats should turn to North Carolina courts if they were not happy with the voter mailing. Democrats also have charged Helms with playing on racial stereotypes in television advertisements. Republicans have denied the charges. RNC counsel Ben Ginsberg said he did not know if the national GOP had asked Helms to stop his mailing campaign and similar tactics. In Washington, Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said the agency was taking ``appropriate steps to ensure there is no voter intimidation'' in North Carolina. But Eramian declined to way what steps the Justice Department was taking in response to a request from the Democratic National Committee that it investigate the mailings in North Carolina.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Scramble on Last Day of Campaign
DOC.TEXT: With polls showing the governor's race almost a dead heat, Democrat Ann Richards stumped through traditional Democratic strongholds Monday and Republican Clayton Williams got a push from President Bush. The president, not wanting to be embarrassed in the state he calls home, campaigned alongside Williams in Tyler, Waco and Houston. ``I urge all Texans ... to get out there and vote and do not take democracy for granted. You have a chance to make a difference,'' Bush said in Tyler. Richards, riding Williams' weekend admission that he paid no income tax in 1986, campaigned from Orange in eastern Texas to the Rio Grande Valley on the Mexican border. The winner of Tuesday's election will succeed two-term Republican Gov. Bill Clements, who is retiring. The governor's election was `too close to call' as of Sunday night, said the Houston firm of Tarrance & Associates, which wrapped up a telephone survey of 1,000 registered voter. And a poll published Sunday by the Houston Chronicle showed oilman-rancher Williams with a slim lead over two-term state treasurer Richards, 44 percent to 39 percent. That same poll in mid-September had shown Williams up by 15 points, 48-33. ``The only person who can elect Richards is Claytie, and he's working hard at it,'' pollster Richard Murray of the University of Houston told the Chronicle. That poll was conducted before Williams' two last-minute gaffes - his no-income tax admission and his apparent failure during a TV appearance to understand the proposed constitutional amendment on gubernatorial appointments. Richards said the remarks bolstered her arguments that the Republican, making his first bid for public office, didn't understand state government and that as one of the state's wealthiest men he didn't understand the needs of average Texans. She hit the airwaves with a last-minute radio commercial that charged: ``Millions of average Texans paid taxes, while (Williams) took advantage of loopholes for the rich.'' Williams said he paid no income taxes because he lost money when oil prices tumbled from near $30 per barrel to less than $10. Williams' spokesman Gordon Hensley said Williams' creation of 26 companies and 100,000 jobs proved he could run state government. He labeled the income tax attack a last-gasp assault. The governor's race was the most expensive in Texas history. A week before the election, Williams had reported spending $20.4 million, including $8 million of his own money. Richards' campaign spending topped $11 million.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes Down, Expected to Stay That Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 10th graf, The median, to make Southern median price $87,200 sted $97,200.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes from July through September slipped 2.5 percent from their level a year earlier and will remain slow in the first half of 1991 because of the weakening economy, a real estate trade group said Monday. The National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.66 million units in the three-month period. Sales declined in the year's two previous quarters as well. The Realtors recorded sales of 3.78 million last year, down from 3.95 million in 1988. Although there were areas of strength in the housing industry during the third quarter, sales declined in 28 states and were unchanged in Oregon. Nineteen states posted increases. Statistics were unavailable for Alaska and Maine. Overall, however, ``the market will remain slow for the rest of 1990 and into the first half of 1991, as the country experiences a mild recession,'' Realtors President Norman A. Flynn said. The Realtors also reported the median price of an existing home was $96,600, 1.8 percent above that for the third quarter of 1989. It ranged from $375,000 in Honolulu to $49,200 in Saginaw, Mich., among the 96 metropolitan statistical areas surveyed. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. The survey includes detached homes, town houses, apartment condominiums and co-operatives. The only region experiencing increased sales was the South, where sales rose 1.4 percent to an annual rate of 1.42 million. Several oil patch areas that had suffered adverse market conditions in recent years recorded increases. Texas had a third-quarter increase of 8.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 246,300 units. Oklahoma, another oil-producing state, posted a 7.3 percent gain to 55,100 units. Sales were up 5.9 percent in Louisiana to 37,100 units. The median price of a home in the South was $87,200, up 1.8 percent from a year earlier. The Midwest's sales rate of 1.0 million units dropped 1.0 percent in the third quarter. The median price jumped 3.6 percent to $75,100. John A. Tuccillo, the Realtors' chief economist, said the availability of moderately priced houses boosted sales in the South and kept them from falling faster in the Midwest. Sales in the West fell 8.8 percent to an annual rate of 580,000 and in the Northeast were down 8.5 percent to a 650,000 rate. Tuccillo said the decline in the West largely resulted from a sharp drop in coastal California markets. The median price dropped 5.3 percent to $138,200, reflecting more purchases in less costly, inland markets. Sales in the Northeast have been sluggish for nearly two years and, ``although Pennsylvania resale activity appears to be recovering, the rest of the region, particularly along the Boston-New York corridor, remains down in the dumps,'' Flynn said. The median price of a home in the Northeast dropped 2.7 percent to $143,100. ``Home sales along the New York-Boston corridor have been gridlocked by sellers who've been reluctant to lower their prices to fit a buyers' market, and by buyers who've been waiting for lower prices,'' Tuccillo said.

DOC.HEAD: Election Win Seen as No Victory for Japan's Troop Bill
DOC.TEXT: Both sides claimed an edge Monday in a special parliamentary election viewed as a referendum on a government proposal to send troops to the Persian Gulf. But the low turnout was seen as an even clearer sign of Japanese sentiment. Only 38.7 percent of the 4.8 million eligible voters in the Aichi district bothered to vote Sunday. Yoshihisa Oshima, a 50-year-old dentist from the governing Liberal Democratic Party, narrowly defeated Michiko Goto of the Japan Socialist Party for a seat in the upper house, winning a 45 percent to 43 percent plurality. The Liberal Democrats backed away from calling the slim victory an endorsement of its troop deployment bill, which faces likely defeat in Parliament. Aichi is an LDP stronghold and the home district of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, sponsor of the troop deployment bill. The Socialists called the election results a clear repudittion of the proposal because Goto and Communist Party candidate Yukiko Seko together drew 55 percent of the vote, or 1,003,815 votes to Oshima's 833,371. Kanju Sato, the Socialist Party's election committee chairman, declared: ``This was proof that a great number of citizens oppose the Self-Defense Forces deployment bill. We will fight harder to prevent the bill from being passed.'' A statement issued by Kaifu read, ``I'm so glad that we won as a result of the efforts by the candidate and the entire party.'' Kaifu visited Aichi, southwest of Tokyo, twice during the campaign. The Japan Times said more than 100 LDP members of the Diet (parliament) were sent in to campaign for Oshima. Hideo Sato, international politics professor at Tsukuba University, commented, ``Japanese voters are most interested in bread and butter and the bill has little to do with that.'' Parliament now is debating the ``United Nations Peace Cooperation Bill.'' The prime minister says any troops sent to the gulf under the measure would be limited to non-combat roles. He has been under pressure from the United States and other nations that want Japan to provide more than money for gulf multinational forces following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some members of Kaifu's own party agree with the opposition's argument that the proposal would violate Japan's post-World War II constitution, which prohibits the use of force to settle international disputes.

DOC.HEAD: Black, White Church Leaders Meet to Discuss South Africa's Future
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu urged churches once divided over apartheid to work together for a peaceful future as he opened a church conference Monday. About 300 delegates from 90 churches are meeting in hopes of reaching agreement on how to help South Africa move peacefully to a non-discriminatory democracy. They will spend five days at the National Conference of Churches, billed as the largest such meeting to be held in South Africa. The conference in Rustenburg, 62 miles northwest of Johannesburg, has brought together the white branch of the Dutch Reformed Church with its black and mixed-race branches. The white Dutch Reformed Church, the main church of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who dominate the government, argued for decades that the Bible supported apartheid. It has changed that view and says it wants to merge with the other branches. The black and mixed-race branches have staunchly opposed apartheid. Tutu, the Anglican archbishop who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his anti-apartheid activism, called for reconciliation. ``We come here not to engage in recrimination,'' he said in the opening speech. ``In this land we are bound together by common humanity, by having one God. The only way we will ever be able to survive, to be free, to be human, is together, black and white,'' Tutu said. Khoza Mgogo, president of the South African Council of Churches, urged delegates to adopt strategies for redistribution of wealth, most of which is in the hands of the white minority. ``The beauty of the meeting is that we are bringing the whole Christian community of South Africa together - the establishment Afrikans churches and their anti-apartheid counterparts,'' the Rev. Frank Chikane, a conference organizer, told the Sunday Times. ``For the first time there is the distinct possibility that the Christian churches - representing 78 percent of the population - can speak with one voice on apartheid and the country's future,'' he said. Two relatively small white churches that still support apartheid - the Afrikaans Protestant Church and the Reformed Church - are not attending. Many of the churches represented belong to the South African Council of Churches, which often has been at the forefront of the anti-apartheid movement. Chikane is the general secretary of the council. The nation's church leaders met 30 years ago in an attempt to forge a united front to challenge apartheid, but the agreement collapsed when the Dutch Reformed Church rejected it. The current conference was organized after President F.W. de Klerk urged church leaders to develop a common position on the role they envision for the church in the future. De Klerk has said he wants to dismantle the apartheid system and negotiate a new constitution that would allow the country's 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power. South Africa is predominantly Christian, with large numbers of Catholics, Anglicans, Methodists, Zionists and Pentecostalists. There also are many Jews and Moslems in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Students Call Anti-Government Strike
DOC.TEXT: Demands grew in Bulgaria on Monday for Socialist Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov to resign, and the main opposition alliance declared it was ready to form a new government if he stepped down. Students called a sit-in strike at Sofia University on Monday to press demands that the Socialists, the former Communists, accept guilt for past mistakes and that party property be returned to the state, the state BTA news agency said. Many students also demanded Lukanov's resignation, it said. TV news reported that workers at the main petrochemical works at Bourgas demanded the government resign within three days. BTA said the independent Podkrepa trade union backed the students' demands. Interior Minister Pencho Penev asked the students to reconsider. He warned on the evening TV news of ``undesirable political consequences.'' Students have wielded considerable political influence in Bulgaria since longtime Communist leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted in a Politburo coup one year ago. In July, a monthlong student sit-in prompted the resignation of Socialist President Petar Mladenov. Last Thursday, Lukanov himself threatened to resign if Parliament refused to support his proposals for pulling Bulgaria out of its economic and political chaos. He demanded a clear answer within a week. He said then that the Socialists could not refute ``accusations of our guilt'' but warned against ``witch hunts'' while the country is in crisis. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces holds 144 of the 400 seats in Parliament. It has refused to join a Socialist-led government or back the government's program. UDF parliamentary floor leader Stoyan Ganev told a news conference Monday that the 17-party alliance was prepared to form a government. He said a UDF-dominated government would not mean a coalition with the Socialists, who hold 211 parliamentary seats. Ganev said the UDF would want to hold the prime minister's job and key ministries, including foreign policy, defense, internal affairs, economics and finance. ``Representatives of the Bulgarian Socialist Party who accept our conditions could also take part in this government,'' Ganev said. Ganev said Monday the idea of a UDF-dominated government had the support of the two largest trade unions. The UDF claims it would have broad support. It says that according to opinion polls, the opposition would win a majority if elections were held now.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrated French Chef Raymond Oliver Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Oliver, one of the greatest French chefs of the century and author of 26 books on cooking, died Monday after a long illness, his family announced. He was 81. Born at Langon in the celebrated Bordeaux food region in 1909, Oliver was the son and grandson of cooks. His maternal grandmother gave him cooking lessons at an early age and he began his apprenticeship under his father at age 15. In 1948, he purchased one of the great Parisian restaurants, Le Grand Vefour, and turned it into an exclusive dining spot for celebrities like politician Andre Malraux, actor Jean Cocteau and writer Colette. Oliver detested the light nouvelle cuisine popular in recent years. His specialty was perfecting the rich cuisine of his Bordeaux youth: foie gras, Sauterne, dove and caviar. ``The important thing is design,'' he once said. ``To make good cuisine, it's necessary to have a solid base.'' La Vefour earned Michelin's prized third star five years after Oliver bought it. He ran it until his retirement at 75 following a terrorist bombing at the restaurant. Together with Guy Gerard, Jean-Claude Vrinat and Jacques Maniere, Oliver was one of the most highly regarded chefs of his era. He won several of France's top honors, including Officer of the Legion of Honor. But his gift of communication elevated Oliver above his contemporaries. He was a prolific writer and from 1953 to 1968 played host to the country's most popular television food program, ``Art and Magic From the Kitchen.'' A series of recorded recipes, ``Cuisinorama,'' sold hundreds of thousands of copies and Oliver defended French cuisine in lectures and seminars in the United States, Japan, South Africa and Iceland. He was married and had four children. One of his sons established a chain of restaurants in French train stations. His family did not disclose the cause of death, and other details on survivors were not disclosed. Funeral arrangements were not announced.

DOC.HEAD: Size of U.N. Central American Monitoring Group is Cut
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council on Monday cut the size of the U.N. border patrol force in Central America, saying the monitors' main mission has been accomplished with peace in Nicaragua. In the unanimous vote, the 15-member council also extended the mandate of the U.N. Observer Group in Central America for six months. U.N. officials said Central American presidents requested the extension, seeking to maintain a U.N. military presence in the region to deter cross-border support for insurgencies. Since its formation a year ago, the multinational force has been deployed in five Central American countries, but its main role was to oversee the demobilization of Nicaragua's Contra rebels following a nine-year civil war. More than 22,000 Contras in Nicaragua and neighboring Honduras had disbanded by July after Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and a 14-party coalition defeated the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. Mrs. Chamorro now is president. The Security Council voted to cut the number of monitors from 413 to 158 by mid-December and put it under the command of a brigadier general. The 11-nation force has been led by Maj. Gen. Agustin Quesada Gomez of Spain. The council also voted to halve the number of helicopters from 12 to six, sending home nearly all of a 130-member Canadian air unit. The vote followed recommendations of a report by Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar that acknowledged the multinational force was ``very limited'' in its efforts to detect secret shipments of weapons or ammunition from one country to another.

DOC.HEAD: Arens Says Gulf Crisis Readiness Costing Israel $1 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Israel has spent nearly $1 billion to raise the army's alertness because of the Persian Gulf crisis, Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Monday. Spokesman Danny Naveh quoted the minister from a speech to the U.S.-Israel Chamber of Commerce in Tel Aviv. ``The gulf crisis has forced Israel to raise its level of alert, to mobilize certain reserve units and reorganize the positioning of some forces,'' Arens said, according to Naveh. The remarks also were broadcast on state radio and television. Arens said the moves cost Israel about $1 billion and that he had asked the United States for more military assistance to cover the costs, Naveh said.
