Israel has so far maintained a low profile in the crisis, which began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The army has distributed gas masks to Israeli citizens following Iraqi threats to attack with chemical weapons. The military announced Monday that it would issue the masks to foreign nationals from Nov. 12-16. Meanwhile, a prominent newspaper reported Monday that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had sought a meeting about a year ago with then-defense minister Yitzhak Rabin via an Arab-American businessman. But Saddam canceled two meetings, that were to have been held in Europe, the Haaretz daily reported. It also said Rabin had refused a proposal for PLO representatives to be at the meeting, and the plan was put on hold in February. The arrangements were reportedly made while Rabin was in Philadelphia visiting the businessman, identified only as an oil magnate and president of a prominent bank. According to Haaretz, the businessman himself initiated the contacts after meeting Saddam in Baghdad, and got to Rabin through Israeli businessman Azriel Einav. The newspaper said it was generally assumed that Saddam wanted to see Rabin following reports that Israel was likely to attack chemical weapons factories in Iraq. It said the White House was informed of these indirect Israeli-Iraqi contacts. Haaretz wrote that Rabin refused comment on the report, and that his former spokesman Eitan Haber confirmed ``something like that'' was true, without elaborating. Neither Rabin nor Haber could be reached for comment on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Says Large Cities, Counties Must Limit Storm Runoffs
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency said Monday that large cities and heavily populated suburban counties must develop programs to reduce contamination of water that flows through storm sewers. The requirements apply to cities with a population of more than 100,000 as well as to heavily populated suburban counties and is hoped to reduce the discharge of pollutants into public storm sewer systems and eventually into public waterways. The EPA said that about 100,000 industrial facilities also must obtain federal permits for discharging water into public sewer systems. The new EPA rules are required by a 1987 law that ordered the agency to reduce runoff pollution in water that flows into storm sewers. Storm water often contains a wide range of pollutants including toxic pesticides from lawns and oil or grease from roads and parking lots. ``The best way for municipalities and industry to meet the storm water regulations and protect the quality of our waters is to prevent pollution before it washes into the storm sewers,'' said LaJuana Wilcher, an EPA assistant administrator. Pollution in storm sewers often is released directly into rivers, streams, lakes and wetlands, posing threats to drinking water as well as the recreational use of these waters, said the EPA. The release of the storm water regulations was welcomed by environmentalists. But Bob Adler, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the regulations should cover more municipalities and urban areas. The EPA rules ``cover only about half of the urban areas required by the 1987 law,'' said Adler.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls in Midwest, Rockies. Rain Dampens Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Snow was scattered Monday over the Midwest and the Plains and rain dampened much of the country. At least 11 inches of snow blanketed parts of Idaho and at least 10 inches fell in Yellowstone National Park. The Great Lakes region and the Missouri Valley also got snow. Travel was dangerous in northern Michigan, where wind chills dipped to zero. Gaylord, Mich., got at least 10 inches of snow. Snow also fell in northwest Missouri. Power was knocked out for several hours to about 5,600 people in Independence after snow-heavy tree limbs toppled electricity lines, said David Ferguson, a spokesman for Independence Power & Light. Kansas City received at least 4 inches of snow and Polo got about 10 inches. North Dakota, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Utah and the Idaho panhandle also received snow. Rain, turning to sleet in some spots, fell in Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa, Wisconsin, South Dakota and other parts of Michigan. Other snowfall during the six-hour period that ended at noon CST included four inches in Drummond, Mont., Helena, Mont., and Lander, Wyo. The early winter blast, four days after a spell of Indian summer sent temperatures soaring to the 70s, drew a mixed response from Michigan residents. ``I think everyone in northern Michigan knows it can approach real fast and bury you,'' said Sherry Barrett, from Petoskey. ``I'm ready to ski. If I can't be playing in the sun and the sand, I want snow.'' Rain on Sunday and overnight overflowed the banks of some streams and rivers in Indiana and Michigan. Temperatures around the nation at 2 p.m. CST ranged from 20 degrees in Glasgow, Mont., to 86 degrees in Jacksonville, Fla. The low Monday in the Lower 48 states was 8 degrees at Sioux Falls, S.D.

DOC.HEAD: Turbulent Governor's Race Appears Headed For Cliff-hanger Conclusion
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota's turbulent governor's race on Monday appeared headed for a cliffhanger. Pollsters declared the election between Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich and Republican Arne Carlson too close to call. Perpich, 62, seeking an unprecedented fourth term in Tuesday's election, spent half the day drumming up enthusiasm for the Democratic-Farmer-Labor ticket in northeastern Minnesota, the party's traditional stronghold. State auditor Carlson, 56, wound up his abbreviated campaign in southwestern and central Minnesota, where GOP sentiment is strong. Carlson became the Republican candidate only last week after GOP nominee Jon Grunseth withdrew amid allegations of sexual improprieties. Results of polls published Sunday in the Star Tribune of Minneapolis and the Saint Paul Pioneer Press showed the race a virtual dead heat. The Star Tribune-KSTP-TV Minnesota Poll showed Carlson with 44 percent and Perpich with 43 percent. Three percent of the respondents favored other candidates and 10 percent were undecided. The poll surveyed 1,003 likely voters from Wednesday through Saturday and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points. In the Pioneer Press-WCCO Poll, Perpich was favored by 39 percent and Carlson by 38 percent. Twenty-two percent of those surveyed were undecided and 2 percent favored other candidates. Results of the poll, conducted Oct. 29 through Thursday among 760 likely voters, are considered reliable within a margin of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Both campaigns focused Monday on getting their supporters out to vote and swaying undecided Minnesotans to their side. ``We're getting a very strong sense the undecideds are breaking strongly not only to the governor but to the DFL ticket,'' said John Stanoch, Perpich's campaign chairman. Lars Carlson, the GOP candidate's brother and campaign chairman, said internal polling showed Carlson's strength increasing in western Minnesota and in northern Twin Cities suburbs. ``The trend is good,'' Carlson said. ``It's not dramatic, however. It is very, very tight. The outcome will hinge on turnout. We're hoping for good weather and a strong turnout.'' Carlson's first wish may be granted: the outlook is for good weather, at least by Minnesota standards for November. ``It'll be a little bit dreary, basically - a typical, gray November sky,'' said forecaster Rich Naistat of the National Weather Service in Minneapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Dismisses Spy Suspect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 4th graf prvs, `Bloch's dismissal...' with addl State Dept. comment, editing change in 5th graf prvs, `The telephone...' SUBS 8th graf pvs, `During the...' to show investigation continuing
DOC.TEXT: Felix S. Bloch, the career diplomat who was suspected of espionage, was fired Monday by Secretary of State James A. Baker III because of ``deliberate false statements,'' the State Department announced. Bloch, who had been under investigation since early last year on suspicion of passing secrets to Soviet agents, was given written notice of Baker's decision. In a brief statement, the department said Baker found that the 55-year-old Bloch's removal from the foreign service ``was necessary because of his deliberate false statements or misrepresentations to the FBI in the course of a national security investigation.'' Bloch's dismissal also was based on his ``behavior, activities and associations,'' the statement said. There was no further elaboration. ``In view of the national security aspects of this case and the privacy rights of the individual employee, the evidence against Mr. Bloch cannot be made public,'' the State Department said. The department's legal affairs office is reviewing Bloch's pension rights. The telephone at Bloch's residence was answered by a machine and he did not immediately respond to messages seeking his reaction to Baker's decision. Bloch submitted his resignation on July 5 and withdrew a request for a hearing on the State Department's attempt to fire him. But State officials said they would not act upon his resignation until Baker had ruled on whether to fire him on security grounds. On Feb. 8, the State Department suspended Bloch from his $80,700-a-year job in the European Affairs Bureau and said it would seek to fire him. The 30-year veteran of the foreign service was suspected by the FBI of selling secrets to the Soviet Union. But the FBI was never able to identify any specific instance where Bloch passed classified data to the Soviets, and charges were never filed. A criminal investigation of Bloch's activities remains open. During the summer of 1989, Bloch was the subject of extensive FBI surveillance which was widely covered by news media. He led processions of FBI agents, reporters and cameramen on walks around the Washington area, and up to the New York City suburbs to visit relatives, after it was first publicly reported in late July 1989 that he was under suspicion. The surveillance ended late last year after the bureau decided it was unlikely it could prove a case in court. But in U.S. District Court here in May, the State Department won the right to use evidence gathered from secret FBI electronic surveillance of Bloch in the dismissal case against him. Investigators believed Bloch was recruited to spy for the Soviets in 1974 while he was serving as economic counselor in the newly opened U.S. Embassy in East Berlin. He spent two years there after transferring from West Berlin where he had served since 1970. Bloch served in Austria from 1980 to 1987 as economic counselor and then as the second-ranking official in the U.S. Embassy. Electronic surveillance was reported to have picked up Bloch telling his wife in 1989 that he had accepted payments from the Soviets. French agents acting on a U.S. tip reportedly photographed him meeting in Paris in the spring of 1989 with a Soviet agent. A former Viennese prostitute told the federal grand jury that has been examining his finances that Bloch spent roughly $10,000 a year for her services over seven years - an amount investigators could not find withdrawn from Bloch's acknowledged bank accounts.

DOC.HEAD: More Blows to Once-Sacred Soviet Holiday of Revolution Day
DOC.TEXT: Officials in Soviet Georgia have decided to move Wednesday's Revolution Day military parade from the streets of the republic's capital of Tbilisi to a field on an army base, Tass reported Monday. The decision in the southern republic, where non-Communists have just scored a big electoral victory, marked the latest blow to the once-sacred holiday and a further erosion of the Communist Party's role in society. The holiday marks the anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. At least two officially sanctioned counterdemonstrations by anti-Communist groups are being held this year in Moscow, with the protesters urging a ``day of mourning'' for people killed by the totalitarian regime. Alternative rallies also will be held in Leningrad, Kiev, Minsk and other cities. Also on Monday, the government newspaper Izvestia printed on its front page a message by Russian Orthodox Church Patriarch Alexi II, in which he called for a sober analysis of the holiday. ``Let this day be a day of neither celebrations nor damnations, but a day of meditation from the depth of human conscience,'' the patriarch wrote. ``Let all the years that passed (since October 1917) rise in our conscience one after another and persuade us not to pay for politicians' experiments and principles with human destinies,'' he said. Officials of the Transcaucasian Military District in Georgia will hold the march by soldiers and the display of tanks and other hardware on a parade ground of a Tbilisi garrison unit, the official Soviet news agency said. The traditional parade route is the central thoroughfare of the capital. ``This step was prompted by the difficult socio-political situation in the republic and by our desire not to aggravate it,'' said Lt. Gen. A. Skory, a member of the district military council. In parliamentary elections in Georgia last month, non-communist parties scored victories on a platform of capitalism and independence from the Soviet Union. ``Members of the general public, war veterans, veteran workers and families of servicemen have been invited to watch the parade,'' Skory told Tass. A traditional parade will take place in Leningrad, the birthplace of the Revolution. But several anti-Communist groups announced they will hold their own rallies, including a memorial service for ``victims of the Communist regime'' at St. Nicholas Cathedral. Authorities in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius broadcast a statement telling the population to ignore the military parade that will be held in Lukiskes Square on Wednesday. The statement said it is a working day, and not a holiday. The Baltic News Service reported that authorities in the Latvian capital of Riga prevented a wooden reviewing stand from being burned down last week and arrested several people. In the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh in the republic of Azerbaijan, holiday celebrations have been canceled, Tass reported. Maj. Gen. V. Safonov, the military commandant of the mountainous region that is predominantly Armenian but located inside Azerbaijan, said he canceled festivities in the main city of Stepanakert because of the emergency situation there, the news agency said. Villages are still being attacked, people are abducted, cattle is rustled and crimes by armed men are common, it said. In the town of Inta, in northwestern Russia, members of the Union of Working People plan to carry the flag of pre-Revolutionary Russia in a protest rally on Wednesday, the Postfactum news service reported. ``Citizens, by turning this mournful date into a holiday, we are once again committing an act of outrage with respect to all sons and daughters of Russia who perished in the bloody meat-chopper started by the Communists,'' the group said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Cartoonist Dies of Cancer at Age 30
DOC.TEXT: Political cartoonist Daniel Sanchez Flores, known throughout Latin America by his penname Roger, has died of cancer, the newspaper Barricada reported Monday. He was 30. The newspaper, a pro-Sandinista publication in which Sanchez's incisive cartoons ran, carried a story about his death Sunday with a banner headline proclaiming, ``National Humor is in Mourning.'' Sanchez directed the weekly humor sheet La Semana Comica, wrote several comic books and contributed to various newspapers, including the pro-government La Prensa. Considered an irreverent leftist, iconoclast and eroticist, Sanchez's cartoons made him a controversial figure. He condemned double standards, bureaucracy and authoritarians. He admired the Sandinista revolution, but criticized it for its shortcomings. Sanchez won the Special Solidarity Prize in Cuba's 1980 annual cartoon contest. His works, some of which were translated into English, include the comic books ``This is Serious,'' ``Popular Cartoons,'' ``Two of Lime and One of Salt'' and ``Erotic Humor.'' Sanchez is survived by his wife, Marta, and their son, Lucas.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal Would Require Drug Makers To Report Effects On Elderly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with quotes, comment and more detail
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers would have to tell physicians how prescription drugs affect elderly patients under a government proposal announced Monday. The information, some of which is already provided voluntarily by many companies already, would have to be included in drug labeling sent to physicians and pharmacists, said the Food and Drug Administration. This labeling, required by the FDA, is usually available to patients upon request. ``As our knowledge has grown of how drugs work within the body, we've recognized the special concerns associated with drug use in the elderly,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said in a statement. ``Physicians need to be provided with any patient information that's available about the drugs they prescribe for senior patients,'' he said. One of the differences between an old patient and a young one is the ability of their kidneys - people lose a third or more of their kidney function between the ages of 30 and 90, Sullivan said. With less kidney function, drugs do not clear the body as fast. This might mean that a muscle relaxant that works fine for a young person might relax older people too much, causing them to fall and break a hip, he said. The American Association of Retired Persons said the proposal is important because those over 65 account for more than 30 percent of people taking prescription drugs while comprising 12 percent of the population. ``One of the factors in drug misuse (by the elderly) is the amount of elderly-specific information that comes from clinical trials and then goes to physicians to guide their prescribing practices,'' said Susan Raetzman, an AARP research analyst. The proposal would require manufacturers to include in physician labeling all available information on the effects of the drug on the elderly. This information could come from the clinical trials in which the drug was tested before it was approved for commercial sale, or from medical literature, said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health at HHS. If no information is available, that would have to be stated clearly in the physician labeling, but this would be the case primarily with drugs developed more than six years ago, said Dr. Robert Temple, director of the FDA's Office of Drug Evaluation I. In the mid-1980s, the FDA began requiring companies to include in drug applications any important data relating to the effects of the drug on the over-65 population, he said. By 1988, most were doing it, he said. In March, the FDA issued guidelines to encourage drug companies to include the elderly when testing their products so they can pass on any effects of the drug in the elderly. The labeling proposal ``could be made stronger if the FDA made their guidelines for clinical trials mandatory,'' AARP's Raetzman said. ``As it is now, their new labeling proposal is only as good as the information underlying it.'' The FDA's proposal would update the labeling regulation to standardize and make clear what information should be included. The labeling information is also available in the Physicians Desk Reference, which provides information on all prescription drugs. The FDA said it will accept comments from the public for 60 days. After that, a final rule will be drafted and published in the Federal Register. Drug manufacturers would have one year from the date of publication to comply, updating the labeling of all their prescription products.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of Hezbollah, Amal Sign Peace Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details on 13 Western hostages held in Lebanon, CORRECTS spelling of Nabih Berri, Subhy Tofeili to conform with style. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: After more than three years of fighting and 1,100 dead, the leaders of Lebanon's main Shiite militias signed a treaty Monday allowing the Lebanese army to expand its control over the nation. Nabih Berri, leader of the Syrian-backed Amal militia, and a top official of the pro-Iranian group Hezbollah signed a peace accord to allow army control of Shiite Moslem areas that included the southern slums of Beirut where the 13 Western hostages had been believed held. The peace agreement, which becomes effective Saturday, was signed at the end of a 10-hour meeting with Syrian and Iranian officials by Berri and Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheik Subhy Tufeili. Amal, which means Hope in Arabic, and Hezbollah, or Party of God, have fought intermittently since June 1987 vying for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiite Moslems. They are among the major militias that Lebanese President Elias Hrawi's government is trying to disarm to implement a peace plan to end 15{ years of civil war. Present for the signing of the agreement were Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa and his Iranian counterpart, Ali Akbar Velayati. Velayati said the subject of Western hostages in Lebanon, believed to be held by groups loyal to Hezbollah, was not discussed. Before Iranian and Syrian officials went into three days of talks, there was speculation the hostage issue was a prime topic. But, Velayati said, ``We did not discuss this subject at all.'' Sharaa and Velayati held a joint news conference after the signing in which they expressed confidence the dispute between Amal and Hezbollah is over. ``It is defititely settled,'' said Velayati. ``We are sure that two sides will fully implement this agreement, and we are committed to provide the Lebanese army with any support it might need,'' said al-Sharaa. The agreement stipulates that: -The two groups will eliminate all obstacles in the way of the deployment of the Lebanese army in southern Lebanon ``in light of the improvement of the army capacities to maintain law and order.'' -In the event of disputes, ``the two parties are committed to the interpretation provided by representatives of Syria and Iran.'' -All people displaced as a result of the fighting between the two parties will return to their areas' villages and homes. Hrawi's government wants all Christian and Moslem militias to leave Beirut and its immediate suburbs as a first step toward spreading the authority of the army throughout Lebanon. Major Christian and Druse militias have expressed approval of the plan since the Lebanese and Syrian armies put down the rebellion of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun on Oct. 13. Hezbollah is the umbrella for Shiite Moslem fundamentalist factions believed to hold most of the Westerners in Lebanon. Lebanese security sources have said the hostage-holders moved their captives from south Beirut to other hideouts, mainly in the eastern Bekaa Valley, before the military move against Aoun. Syria, with its 40,000 troops in Lebanon, is the major powerbroker in the country. It controls the Bekaa Valley, except for pockets still possessed by Shiite groups. The missing westerners include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. Longest held is Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. There have been reports more of them would be released as Iran improves its relations with Western nations, particularly Britain. Other sources have said the U.S-led military buildup to confront Iraq in the Persian Gulf has discouraged hostage-holders from releasing their captives. Both Iran and Syria have condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But Iran has also denounced the Western military presence in the region, while Syria has committed more than 15,000 troops to the multinational force.

DOC.HEAD: EC Says It Won't Negotiate Hostage Releases With Saddam
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: The European Community pledged anew Monday to remain united against Saddam Hussein by refusing to negotiate individually for the release of hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. Italy, president of the 12-member EC, convened an emergency foreign ministers' meeting Monday night at the request of Belgium and the Netherlands to discuss potential cracks in the Community's Iraq policy. The meeting followed a series of missions to Iraq, including a trip to Baghdad on Monday by former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. The ministers did not specifically condemn Brandt or any other political figure. EC leaders adopted a declaration at a summit meeting in Rome a week ago pledging not to send government representatives to Baghdad and to discourage others from doing so. German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told reporters after Monday night's meeting that his government does not consider Brandt's trip a violation of EC policy. Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy, who presided at the meeting, told a news conference the ministers agreed unanimously to uphold the declaration on hostages. He said Saddam's policy of selectively releasing hostages increases the prospect of military conflict in the Persian Gulf. ``We have achieved an important political result in a very difficult situation,'' De Michelis said. ``We have clearly stated that the political will of the 12 governments is the same - that is, no government will accept any type of negotiations, explicit or implicit, with the Iraqi government on the hostages. ``If the aim of Saddam Hussein is to utilize the hostages for political advantage, he now has a clear answer from Rome - no. He can have no political advantage from the hostage issue.'' De Michelis said the 12 agreed the United Nations should be the only mediator with Iraq on the hostages. He said he would press U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to increase his efforts to send a personal envoy to Baghdad to discuss the issue. De Michelis said EC foreign ministry officials will meet this week to examine a German proposal to send a Community delegation to Tunisia, Algeria and Jordan to sound out prospects for a political solution to the gulf crisis. The crisis began three months ago with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Britain and some other EC members have publicly criticized Brandt's mission to Iraq. But De Michelis said Monday's meeting was not called to consider Brandt's initiative. Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman Giovanni Castellaneta quoted Genscher as saying his government ``does not want to give a positive or negative judgment'' on the trip by Brandt, the 1971 Nobel peace laureate. Castellaneta said Italy respected Brandt as a statesman and was convinced he would not violate EC policy. Brandt says his trip is a private mission and he is not going as a representative of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government. In an interview with a German newspaper, Brandt said he would not negotiate with Saddam. He said he hoped he could help win the release of German and other hostages. Brandt is just one of several prominent political figures visiting Baghdad to obtain freedom for the hundreds of hostages Iraq has detained to discourage the United States and its allies from attacking. Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone met with Iraqi officials over the weekend in an effort to free some of the more than 300 Japanese held in the country. Former prime ministers David Lange of New Zealand, and Anker Joergenson of Denmark are also reported to be planning trips to Iraq. Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath traveled to Iraq last month and won freedom for 38 Britons. In calling for the EC meeting, Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said Sunday, ``Saddam is creating this royal court of all sorts of Western pilgrims who visit him to obtain the release of hostages.'' The meeting was only called on Monday. Just six foreign ministers managed to attend. The rest sent high-ranking deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Americans Unhappy With How Bush, Congress Dealing With Economy
DOC.TEXT: An overwhelming margin of Americans believe the nation's economy is worsening and are unhappy with how President Bush and Congress are dealing with the problem, an ABC News poll reported Monday. By a margin of 61 percent to 36 percent, respondents said they disapproved of Bush's handling of the economy. And the survey found a comparable disapproval rating - 61 percent to 33 percent - when people were asked to rate congressional Democrats' handling of the economy. The disapproval rate was somewhat higher for congressional Republicans - 69 percent to 26 percent. Seventy-seven percent of those questioned said the economy was getting worse, while only 4 percent said it was improving. The figures came from a survey of 1,015 people questioned between Oct. 23 and 25. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. The survey found Bush's approval rating has rebounded from its low of 51 percent a week ago to 59 percent. Public opinion of Congress continues to drop, but those questioned still like their own representatives. Disapproval of Congress was voiced by 72 percent of those interviewed, while only 24 percent approved of the way the body was doing its job. But when asked to rate their own representative, 54 percent approved and 37 percent disapproved. Three weeks ago, approval of individual representatives was at 64 percent. The survey also found the public strongly perceives Bush and his party as tilting to the rich. ``Overall, would you say Bush cares more about serving poor and lower income people, middle income people, upper income people, or would you say he cares equally about serving all people?'' the survey asked. In response to that question, 3 percent said poor and lower income, 5 percent said middle income, 55 percent said upper income and 36 percent said all equally. When the same question was asked about congressional Republicans, 2 percent said poor and lower income, 11 percent said middle income and 59 percent said upper income.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Make First Callup of Combat Reserves for Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps is ordering the first call-up of reservists for combat roles in the Persian Gulf crisis, a Pentagon source said Friday. The Marine callup is relatively small and won't add substantially to the U.S. combat capabilities in the gulf. However, the Pentagon is considering calling major Army reserve combat units to active duty, possibly before year's end. The Marines will call up individual infantrymen from various units around the country, not entire units, the source said. The New York Times reported Monday that the Pentagon already has decided to put major reserve combat units on active duty. Maj. Doug Hart, a Pentagon spokesman, said he was unaware of any such decision and that no combat units had been activated. All of the more than 34,000 reserves from all the armed services already called to active duty for Operation Desert Shield are being used in support roles such as truck driving, water purification and military intelligence. The Marines had accounted for only 200 of the 34,000 total. The Marine infantrymen being called up will be among approximately 800 reservists in a variety of military jobs being ordered to report for active duty later this week, the source said. The source declined to say how many of the 800 are in combat roles. Use of reserves in combat jobs is politically sensitive because it can be viewed as putting the country on a wartime footing. No shots have been fired in the confrontation with Iraq, other than warnings shots across the bows of ships, but President Bush has not ruled out the use of force to oust Iraq from occupied Kuwait. The Pentagon has been under pressure from some congressional leaders to use combat reserves. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had resisted using them, saying the 180-day maximum period of activation for reserves was too short to make good use of them, even though some Army three-brigade divisions were designed with one brigade a reserve brigade. Such divisions now in Saudi Arabia took an active duty brigade from elsewhere in the Army, rather than the so-called ``round-out'' brigades, when they let for the Persian Gulf. Congressional concern was erased earlier this month when Congress, shortly before adjourning, doubled the limit on active duty service for combat reserves to 360 days. It appeared that the Marine combat reserves would become part of a specially tailored Marine Expeditionary Brigade that eventually would replace one of several such units already deployed in the gulf area during a rotation of Marine units. Gen. John R. Dailey, the deputy commandant of the Marines, said in an interview Monday that the rotation plan is mostly complete but that no decisions have been made on when a rotation of fresh forces would begin or how they would be structured.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Gulf Crisis Entering New Phase

DOC.TEXT: JIDDAH, Saudi Arabia - Secretary of State James A. Baker III reached an agreement Monday with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia that if U.S. troops are sent into combat against Iraq they will be under U.S. command, a senior Bush administration official said. The decision, 2nd graf prvs

DOC.HEAD: Mount St. Helens Belches Ash
DOC.TEXT: Mount St. Helens belched volcanic ash and steam nearly 6 miles into the air Monday, and the powdery fallout settled up to 65 miles away in Oregon. There were no reports of damage and scientists said they had no evidence of a bigger eruption in the offing. Ashfall from the 8,364-foot mountain 100 miles south of Seattle was reported as far away as The Dalles, Ore., 65 miles to the southeast, said geologist Steve Brantley of the U.S. Geological Survey. Residents of neighboring towns were not in any danger, authorities said. The explosion, recorded on volcano seismographs at 2:07 a.m., sent a plume of ash 30,000 feet into the air, said Chris Jonientz-Trisler, a researcher at the University of Washington. Winds carried the ash plume to the southeast, toward the Columbia River and into Oregon, the National Weather Service said. Jonientz-Trisler said the explosion was ``very minor, minor, minor'' compared with a May 18, 1980, eruption that leveled 230 square miles of forest, left 57 people dead or missing and sent up an ash cloud that circled the globe. ``This kind of thing is more like the steam and ash explosions that occurred last winter in December and January,'' she said. ``Any hazards should be fairly confined to the crater.'' Scientists monitoring the volcano say there has been a gradual increase in small earthquakes there in the past three years. There was no evidence, however, that they were associated with Monday's eruption. ``The steam and gases that are involved here could come from a couple of sources,'' Jonientz-Trisler said. ``It could come from the magma, bubbling out of solution, or it could be rain and snowmelt percolating down (to hot areas) and bursting into steam. It's probably a bit of both processes.'' In the past, series of earthquakes have occurred in the days before eruptions of Mount St. Helens. The volcano's last large eruption was on March 19, 1982, when mud flowed from the crater for six miles. Since then, the mountain has had a series of ``dome-building'' eruptions in which the mountain adds lava to the heap in its crater. The last one occurred in October 1986. The cataclysmic 1980 eruption blew off the top 1,300 feet of the once-symmetrical peak, a lava dome dating to about the 16th century.

DOC.HEAD: EC Fears Catastrophic Famine in East Africa
DOC.TEXT: The European Community expressed concern Monday about the dangers of a catastrophic famine in East Africa. ``The council (of ministers) stressed the very real danger that the present drought, combined with a persistent difficult political situation, will lead to famine on a catastrophic scale'' in East Africa, the final communique read. The council of ministers said substantial short-term emergency food supplies will be necessary in the next few months. It said the United Nations has estimated that in Sudan as many as 5 million people are at risk. The council urged coordination of help among donors and called on all EC member nations to make their people aware of the seriousness of the situation, including ``the Community's concern about destuuction of refugee camps.'' Lynda Chalker, British minister for development, said the situation is even worse than the drought of 1984-85. She said there was evidence the government in Sudan was covering up cases of malnutrition.

DOC.HEAD: British Hostages Able to Call Families Over the Weekend
DOC.TEXT: At least 30 British hostages held in Iraq telephned their families in Britain last weekend, the Foreign Office said Monday. The Foreign Office condemned the calls as a ``cruel and calculating Iraqi ploy.'' Some of the hostages reiterated Iraq's invitation last week for women to spend Christmas with their husbands, but the Foreign Office advised families against traveling to Iraq or Kuwait, occupied since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``Iraqi undertakings should not be trusted,'' a spokesman at the Foreign Office said, adding that officials realized the advice would be difficult for some family members to take. The calls were placed directly to the families, the Foreign Office said. The family of John Rattenbury spoke for five minutes to the 61-year-old businessman, their first phone call since Aug. 1. ``He said they were being well looked after. He was obviously disappointed that he could not come home with Ted Heath but is still in good spirits,'' Lilian Rattenbury said. Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath traveled to Baghdad last month and negotiated the release of 37 British hostages who were elderly or ill. Some families received tape-recorded messages from their husbands, brought back by recently released French hostages, the Foreign Office said. A British hostage said in a taped message he had lost more than 30 pounds on a daily diet of ``one tomato, one onion, one pepper, a four-inch piece of cucumber and a bit of bread, two pieces of bread if you are lucky.'' A Conservative party lawmaker called on families of British hostages to be brave and stop complaining. ``I am sick and tired of the mewling and puking of the relatives of hostages in the Gulf and of some of the hostages themselves,'' said Sir John Stokes. ``During the last war we never heard sobs of widows. Cannot these people keep a stiff upper lip and think of the country as a whole?'' Stokes said. Dorothy Goodwin, who said she intends to fly to the gulf to visit her husband, called Stokes' criticism ``unhelpful and unnecessary.'' ``He obviously doesn't have any relative trapped in Iraq or he wouldn't talk that way.'' The Foreign Office said there are 800 British citizens held in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: EC Ministers Suspend Farm Subsidy Talks for One Day
DOC.TEXT: European Community agriculture and trade ministers late Monday suspended talks on a proposal to cut farm subsidies until Tuesday to give time for high-level consultations between EC governments. Officials said French President Francois Mitterrand and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl were among the heads of state who would be talking by phone to try to hammer a final farm plan into shape. EC officials expressed guarded optimism that Tuesday's talks would yield agreement on a proposal that could be submitted to the Uruguay Round of world trade talks. ``The danger of failure has passed,'' Germany's economics and trade minister, Helmut Haussmann, said. Failure to reach agreement could torpedo the Uruguay Round, a four-year effort of more than 100 nations to liberalize world trade. The United States and other countries have threatened to abandon the Geneva-based trade talks if the Community fails t make a proposal. British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer said of the Community's efforts: ``If we lose this opportunity, I believe it might have a long-term and very serious effect on the world economy.'' The ministers were at odds over a proposal to trim farm subsidies on major crops by 30 percent over a 10-year period, from 1986 to 1996. Some reductions already have been made. France and Germany have insisted on guarantees that their farmers would not be seriously hurt. The European Commission, the EC's executive body, drew up a list of guarantees designed to allay the nations' fears. EC ministers failed in six tries last month to reach an accord. The Community is the only major participant that has not yet submitted a proposal to the agricultural trade talks within the Uruguay Round. The talks, held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, seek to lower trade barriers in 15 areas, including textiles, manufactured goods and services such as banking and telecommunications. But the United States and other countries insist agriculture is the key to the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Makes First Spectrum Measurement Of Faint Object
DOC.TEXT: An instrument on the Hubble Space Telescope focused on a quasar billions of light years away to make the first spectral observations of a faint object by the $1.5 billion orbiting telescope, NASA announced Monday. The instrument, a faint object spectrograph, targeted the quasar known as UM675 in a study of the chemical composition of the early universe. A NASA announcement said that the quasar appears to be receding from the Earth at a speed of about 80 percent of the speed of light. To make the readings, the space telescope focused on UM675 for 33 minutes in each of three different orbits. A computer at the Goddard Space Center then combined the data to create a single data set. The readings by the faint object spectrograph were in the far ultraviolet portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. Radiation of this type cannot be detected on Earth because the planet's atmosphere blocks it, but it can be detected in space. Quasars, or ``quasi-stellar objects,'' are puzzling celestial bodies that emit more energy than would be expected from an objects of their size. Astronomers study quasars in several spectra in hopes of understanding their nature. Hubble has a focusing problem that seriously affects instruments, such as cameras, that work only in the visible portion of the spectrum. The focusing flaw, however, has less effect in the invisible portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.

DOC.HEAD: Sir David Stirling, Founder of SAS Special Forces, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Col. Sir David Stirling, who founded Britain's SAS elite special forces in World War II, has died, his biographer said Monday. He was 74. Stirling died Sunday night in the London Clinic after a long illness, said Alan Hoe, a former SAS major and Stirling's official biographer. The SAS, or Special Air Service, with its motto ``Who Dares Wins,'' continued after the war and has kept its reputation for swift, clandestine and effective action. One highly publicized exploit was its assault on the Iranian Embassy in London May 5, 1980, to end a siege by gunmen holding hostages. Born Archibald David Stirling on Nov. 15, 1915, the son of a Scottish brigadier general, he joined the Scots Guards at the outbreak of World War II. Six months later he transferred to No. 3 Commando group of the Brigade of Guards and went with them to the Middle East. He persuaded military authorities that ``an army within an army'' was needed to make swift, secret raids against the enemy. They gave him six officers and 60 enlisted men to try out his theories in the Western Desert. Stirling became known as the ``Phantom Major'' among the German troops of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps after destroying 250 enemy aircraft and scores of fuel and ammunition dumps in attacks on the enemy rear. His tactics of operating so far behind German lines that his men could virtually walk into their targets - and then ``retreating'' even farther into enemy territory against all expectations - helped give him legendary status. In 1943, Stirling was taken prisoner in Tunisia. He escaped, was recaptured and was transferred to Colditz Castle prison camp where he remained for the rest of the war. Stirling left the army on his release, but retained close links with the regiment. He became head of a series of private armies and security organizations, many in Africa. In 1974, he founded the controversial organization Great Britain '75, which aimed to keep Britain running in the event of a general strike, following a devastating mineworkers' industrial action that year. Hoe said Monday: ``The SAS is still based on the same concept of small, highly trained groups of soldiers being used strategically rather than tactically.'' Former chief of the Defense Staff, Field Marshal Lord Bramall, said Stirling was regarded as founding father of the SAS. ``It all started with this young 25-year-old who had this idea that a few highly trained men inserted at very vulnerable points could do tremendous damage to the enemy. ``It is an immense achievement and he has always been held with tremendous respect and regard.'' Stirling was not married. No survivors were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Baker, Saudis Reach Command Accord in Event of Iraqi War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with Baker-Saudi agreement on command of forces, Marine Corps call-up. Picks up 4th pvs, `Iraq, meanwhile' with minor editing thereafter to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JED1
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III reached agreement Monday with Saudi Arabia that if U.S. troops go to battle against Iraq they will be under American command, a top Bush administration official said. A former West German chancellor meanwhile flew to Iraq to seek freedom for foreigners held hostage by Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, and the European Community convened a special session in hopes of keeping members in line. The decision on command and control was announced after Baker held a two-hour meeting with King Fahd. The senior official, who insisted on anonymity, said the Saudis would play a decisive role because they would share command of American troops used to defend Saudi Arabia and would have to give a green light before the 100,000 U.S. troops in the oil-rich kingdom are sent into action. Once the Americans enter battle, U.S. commanders will direct them, the official said. The USS Midway, one of four American aircraft carriers deployed as part of Operation Desert Shield, entered the Persian Gulf on Monday. Like the USS Independence, which left the gulf last month after a few days, the Midway apparently was sent in as a show of force. Later Monday in Washington, a Pentagon source said the Marine Corps is ordering the first call-up of reservists for combat roles in the gulf crisis. The Marine call-up is relatively small and will not add substantially to the estimated 220,000 U.S. forces in the gulf region. However, the Pentagon is considering calling major Army reserve combat units to active duty, possibly before the end of the year, the source said. Iraq, meanwhile, said that in the event of war over Kuwait, it would attack Arab countries participating in the U.S.-led multinational force. The latest mission to Baghdad was mounted by former Chancellor Willy Brandt, who arrived in the Iraqi capital late Monday aboard a chartered Lufthansa Airbus that can carry about 250 people. Brandt, who was seen off by Iraq's ambassador to Germany, carried letters and a bouquet of flowers from relatives of the estimated 400 German hostages. Brandt's mission has the backing of the German government despite the EC's stand against negotiating for the release of the hundreds of foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait. Saddam has tried to use the hostages - whom he calls ``guests'' - to splinter the alliance against him. Also Monday, a delegation of Irish legislators left Baghdad after talks with Iraqi officials aimed at winning freedom for an estimated 220 Irish citizens. ``We are given to believe that the Iraqi government will soon resolve the issue of Iraqi guests,'' said Irish lawmaker Michael Higgins. Former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan also was meeting with Iraqi officials in hopes of winning the release of more than 300 Japanese hostages. Diplomatic sources in Baghdad said David Lange, a former prime minister of New Zealand, and Anker Jorgensen, a former prime minister of Denmark, plan to come to Iraq. Ireland, Germany and Denmark are EC members. A special meeting of European Community foreign ministers was scheduled in Rome for Monday night to discuss departures from the EC policy. During the weekend, about 50 British and American hostages in Iraq were allowed to call relatives at home. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher quoted many of the hostages as saying they had lost weight, that the food was poor and that they were often cold. He added: ``We think if he (Saddam) is genuinely concerned about allowing husbands and fathers to talk to their wives and children, he should simply release all the hostages and let them come home.'' One father said his hostage son told him Britain should not yield. ``He said the telephone call was being recorded but he didn't give two monkeys and to let the government know that the hostages want no negotiations with the terrorists and they are 100 percent behind them,'' the father said. British officials did not identify the father and son by name. But in Brockton, Mass., Mary Trundy said she'll go to Baghdad for Christmas if it will help her twin brother, John Stevenson. She said he had called other relatives in Florida, adding: ``We're all planning to spend the holidays with John.'' Baker was in Saudi Arabia as part of a seven-nation tour aimed at testing support among Arabs, Europeans and the Soviets for military action against Saddam. In the Saudi town of Taif, Baker met with the emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who was driven from his homeland by Iraqi invaders Aug. 2. ``As far as I am concerned I would like my country to be liberated today and before tomorrow,'' the emir told reporters. Baker said the Persian Gulf crisis ``is entering a new phase, and while we are still seeking a peaceful political and diplomatic solution, we have to put ourselves in a position where we would be able to exercise any options that might be available.'' While Baker said he had not discussed a military timetable with the emir, he added: ``I don't think that we can or should ... rule out resort to force if that should be necessary.'' In Iraq, the army newspaper Al-Qadissiyah said Arab nations that join the multinational force would suffer if there is a war. ``All dens of evil everywhere, and whoever supported them, would not be safe from our attacks,'' said the editorial carried by the official Iraqi News Agency. The dispatch monitored in Cyprus said that ``if war occurs as a result of the U.S.-Western conspiracy and because of traitors such as (Saudi King) Fahd and (Egyptian President Hosni) Mubarak ... our counterattacks will be destructive and will not be limited to securing our country's sovereignty.'' Besides the forces massed by the United States, Britain, France, Syria, Egypt and Morocco also sent troops to bolster Saudi forces. In other developments: -Special international aid to countries affected by the gulf crisis and U.N. embargo on Iraq has reached nearly $13 billion, the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group announced. Most aid came from gulf states, and about 80 percent of it will go to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan. -Three French soldiers captured by an Iraqi patrol last week exceeded their orders by straying too close to Iraq's border with Saudi Arabia, French Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement. He did not confirm the soldiers strayed into Iraqi territory. The three returned to France on Sunday. -Four fighter jets violated Iraqi airspace Sunday by crossing the border from Saudi Arabia, the official Iraqi News Agency said. INA said the intruders, two F-15s and two F-14s, all turned around shortly after entering Iraqi airspace.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Governmet Survives Another No-Confidence Vote
With AM-Israel-Arab Jobs, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES second sentence of quote in 12th graf because words are missing; pickup 13th graf pvs, `Shamir commands...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government narrowly defeated a no-confidence motion in Parliament on Monday, the second such challenge to his fragile right-wing coalition in two weeks. In the occupied Gaza Strip, soldiers kept 150,000 Palestinians under curfew for a third day. One Arab was killed and at least 185 people were wounded by army gunfire during weekend rioting. Eight Palestinians and an Israeli soldier were wounded in continuing clashes in Gaza on Monday, Arab reports said. In one attack, masked assailants opened fire on soldiers and troops fired back, but there were no reports of injuries. Reporters were barred from Gaza unless under military escort. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the unrest ``will not move us to surrender (control of the occupied lands). ... It will not influence us.'' The parliamentary challenge to Shamir was called by seven opposition parties protesting the government's failure to build enough housing for an influx of Soviet immigrants. A record 120,000 immigrants arrived this year and at least 75,000 more are expected through December. But according to Israeli reports, fewer than 10,000 new apartments are being built. Much of the lag is because of bureaucratic infighting among ministries. Fueling the anger of left-wingers was a Cabinet decision on Sunday to give Housing Minister Ariel Sharon a free hand in distributing lands to contractors. The move was said to be an attempt to cut through red tape, but critics said it left the door open to corruption. ``All this time nothing has been done and now suddenly you wake up and see there's no housing, so you take emergency powers to get things done?'' complained Labor Party legislator Shimon Shitreet on Israel television. ``The mishandling of the immigrants has broken all records ... lots of panic with no action,'' Avraham Shohat of Labor told lawmakers. Sharon responded by accusing his detractors of trying to delay efforts to provide housing and seeking to ``deter Russians from immigrating.'' ``When I look at the way the opposition benches are acting, a wave of sympathy engulfs my heart,'' Sharon added. Shamir commands 62 seats in the 120-member Knesset, or parliament. He seemed assured of his majority Monday, until Interior Minister Aryeh Deri's five-member party threatened to join the opposition over a squabble involving a scandal investigation. Deri's party kept lawmakers in suspense for several hours before a three-hour debate. The government won the confidence vote 57-50, with two abstentions. The remaining lawmakers were absent. Deri suggested on Israel radio his party was angry with police handling of a protracted investigation into alleged illegal handouts of thousands of dollars to religious councils. He also said he was also dissatisfied with Israel's ``lack of flexibility'' toward the United States over Middle East policies during the Persian Gulf crisis, and the government's heavy hand in dealing with Palestinians. Egypt on Monday blamed Israel for violence in Gaza over the weekend and urged self-restraint on the part of Israeli forces. The statement from the Egyptian Foreign Ministry said harsh Israeli measures against Palestinians only ``lead to worldwide condemnation.'' Egypt is the only Arab country that has diplomatic relations with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Trudeau Said Interested in Gulf Mediating Role
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau is interested in acting as an intermediary to seek release of Canadians held in Iraq and Kuwait, Liberal member of Parliament Lloyd Axworthy said Monday. Axworthy said he had not talked to Trudeau personally but used a go-between to discuss the matter. A secretary at the Montreal law firm where Trudeau works said Trudeau had left for the day, as had Trudeau's secretary. Axworthy has been pressing the government to send an official representative to Iraq to gain the release of about 50 Canadians held in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. External Affairs Minister Joe Clark repeated Monday that Canada will have no part of such a mission. He argues that an official emissary would undermine international efforts to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, which it overran three months ago.

DOC.HEAD: Haitians Fear Violence as Election Officials Rule on Candidates
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Tension mounted in Haiti on Monday, the eve of a ruling on whether supporters of the Duvalier dictatorship that terrorized the country for nearly three decades can run in the December elections. The Electoral Council was expected Tuesday to ban at least three Duvalierists from participating, and many Haitians worried such a ruling could unleash a wave of violent retaliation as it did in 1987. ``November evokes for some a vision of apocalypse,'' Jean Dominique, director of the independent Radio Haiti-Inter, said in a radio commentary. ``In 1987, disqualified candidates put an already devastated country to the torch.'' As night fell Monday on the capital of Port-au-Prince, where more than 1 million people live, huge traffic jams formed as Haitians stocked up on supplies and food in case of violence. After the council barred 12 Duvalierist candidates from the 1987 race, dozens of people were killed. Five radio stations were riddled with machine-gun fire and put out of commission. On Election Day, goon squads in collusion with the army hacked and shot to death at least 34 voters at the polls. The government then canceled the election. This year's elections are set for Dec. 16. The campaign officially begins Wednesday and runs until Dec. 14. The Electoral Council has constitutional authority to decide on the eligibility of the candidates. The 1987 constitution bars ``architects'' of the Duvalier dictatorship from running for office. Of this year's 26 presidential candidates, four are avowed Duvalierists. Adding to tensions is the candidacy of the Rev. Bertrand Aristide, an ardent foe of Duvalierists and the military who has survived at least three assassination attempts. Many fear violent confrontations between Duvalierists and his supporters. A liberation theology advocate who believes the Church should be involved in the social struggles of the poor, Aristide, 37, was ousted from his Roman Catholic Salesian Order in 1988 for allegedly inciting violence with his fiery sermons. He is believed to have a mass following among Haiti's poor, a majority in this Caribbean nation of 6 million people. The most feared Duvalierist candidate is Roger Lafontant, who ran the private Tonton Macoute militia that kept the Duvalier family in power for 29 years. The dictatorship ended in February 1986 when Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile, but Haiti has been wracked by political turmoil since he was toppled. The current provisional government of Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, appointed in March, is the fifth since Duvalier fell. There is a warrant for Lafontant's arrest charging him with conspiring against national security. But it has not been served and he's thought to have military support. Lafontant returned to Haiti in July after nearly five years in voluntary exile. Two other Duvalierists candidates, former army chief of staff Claude Raymond and Clemard Joseph Charles, a banker, were barred from the 1987 elections. Remy Joseph, a doctor who was health minister under Duvalier, is regarded as a moderate and is expected to be allowed in the race. About 800 observers from the United Nations and Organization of American States are expected to monitor the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Make Final Rounds Amid Voter Dissatisfaction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs on Justice Department, minority postcard dispute after 10th graf, ``Race is; INSERTS 1 graf on Richards blast on taxes, money after 19th graf, ``Millions of; deletes last 2 grafs
DOC.TEXT: Candidates for Congress and 36 governor's seats made their final campaign rounds Monday amid signs of extraordinary voter dissatisfaction but without any indication of a looming anti-incumbent landslide on Election Day. Democrats were confident they would retain their majorities in both houses of the new 102nd Congress, and nary a Republican disputed their claim. The GOP hoped to counter with victories in the big-state gubernatorial races. Buddy MacKay, a Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor in Florida, spoke for nervous candidates everywhere when he declared, ``I'm not saying the race is over. Anything can still happen.'' His running mate, gubernatorial candidate Lawton Chiles, was leading in the late polls. Overall, pollsters and analysts said Tuesday isn't likely to bring a thorough house-cleaning of the political establishment. ``Americans are very dissatisfied with the way things are going in this country,'' and mention economic concerns more than any other, said Frank Newport, editor in chief of the Gallup Poll. Still, he said, in an assessment shared by others, ``It's not necessarily clear we're going to have a massive get-rid-of-the-incumbent'' outcome. Fresh evidence of voter dissatisfaction emerged in an ABC News poll, which reported that 77 percent of those surveyed believe the economy is getting worse, and only 4 percent believe it is getting better. The White House dispatched drug policy director William Bennett to North Carolina to campaign for GOP Sen. Jesse Helms, a three-term conservative in a tight race with Harvey Gantt, a black former mayor. ``Race is not an issue in this campaign,'' said Helms, who has accused Gantt of supporting job quotas based on race. ``We have not made an issue of race, but he has gone around the state pleading for the bloc vote.'' But the Justice Department sent a team of lawyers to North Carolina after Democrats charged that the state GOP was trying to intimidate black voters. The state GOP sent out postcards advising voters that they were ineligible to cast ballots if they had moved in the last 30 days. The statement on the cards is misleading, said a Justice Department official. Democrats said the postcards were targeted to heavily black precincts. The state GOP has pledged not to use any information it obtained from returned postcards to challenge the eligibility of voters at the polls on Tuesday, said the Justice Department. Gantt dreamed of the upset that would make him a national figure: ``How sweet it's going to be.'' In final rallies, he stressed how important it is to ``care about our children, to care about the environment, to care about health care, to care about the human condition.'' In the biggest state of all, GOP candidate Pete Wilson embarked on a five-city tour of California, tagging Democratic rival Dianne Feinstein as soft on crime and a big spender. Countered Ms. Feinstein, trailing in the polls, ``For eight years they (the Republicans) have taken us in the wrong direction. For eight years we've had uncontrolled growth, increasing crime and declining schools.'' In all, 34 Senate seats are on Tuesday's ballot, a new 435-member House will be chosen and three dozen governors will be elected. More than 6,000 legislative races, local contests and a healthy assortment of initiatives complete the ballots. The legislative races, in particular, were drawing more interest than usual from the national parties. Both sides want the legislatures on their side when states redraw the boundaries of U.S. House seats to reflect population shifts detected in the 1990 Census. President Bush on Monday spent his second straight day in Texas stumping for gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams and other GOP candidates - ``every single one of them.'' Democrat Ann Richards launched a new radio advertisement taking aim at millionaire Williams' admission that he paid no income taxes in 1986. ``Millions of average Texans paid taxes, while (Williams) took advantage of loopholes for the rich,'' her ad said. Williams says he paid no taxes because he lost money when oil prices tumbled. Her supporters passed out buttons reading, ``I paid my taxes in '86.'' She nicknamed her opponent ``Mucho Dinero.'' Newport said a late-October poll found that only 24 percent of those surveyed approved of the job Congress was doing. Yet 61 percent said they approved of the job performance of their own representative. He noted that despite a precipitous drop in Bush's approval ratings in October, the president still is well above 50 percent and the trend is up. Democrats control the current Senate, 55-45, and most estimates were for little, if any, change in the lineup. The closest Senate races appeared to be North Carolina and Hawaii, where appointed Sen. Daniel Akaka faced a stiff challenge from Republican Rep. Patricia Saiki. Final pre-election polls pointed to new terms for Republicans Mark Hatfield of Oregon and Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota, both of whom hurried home from Washington in October to confront unexpectedly strong challenges. Democrats were nervous about incumbents Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island; Tom Harkin of Iowa and John Kerry of Massachusetts. But they harbored hopes of defeating GOP Sen. Mitch McConnell in Kentucky. In the House, most estimates were for a gain of roughly 10 seats for the Democrats,who hold a 258-175 edge with two vacancies. The Illinois gubernatorial battle between Democratic Attorney General Neil Hartigan and Republican Secretary of State Jim Edgar defied prediction. The final polls gave Republican George Voinovich the edge in his bid to claim the Ohio governorship for the Republicans. Two independents - both of them former Republicans - were making strong gubernatorial bids, Lowell Weicker in Connecticut and Wally Hickel in Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Shoring Up Their Leads Heading Into Election Day
With AM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs on minority postcard dispute, Justice Department after 8th graf, Gantt told
DOC.TEXT: Senate incumbents worked to shore up their leads in the final rush toward Election Day and only the races in North Carolina and Hawaii remained tossups in the polls. Voters in 34 states elect senators on Tuesday and Democrats appeared to be in no danger of losing their control of the Senate, now split 55-45 in their favor. Most observers predicted the Senate would shift only a seat or two in either direction, but that didn't dampen the intensity with which candidates were competing for votes in races across the country. Fights broke out over the weekend between supporters of three-term incumbent Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and backers of challenger of Harvey Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte. Polls differed as to who was ahead. In no other states were voters being offered so clear a choice - Helms, a leader of the right wing of the Republican party, and Gantt, an unabashed liberal who is black. Helms accused Gantt of supporting racial quotas but denied Monday that he made race an issue in the campaign. ``We have not made an issue of race, but he has gone around the state pleading for the bloc vote. He has a right to do that. But that has injected race into it,'' said Helms. He toured the state with President Bush's drug czar, William Bennett, in tow. Gantt told supporters if Helms wanted to call him a liberal, fine. ``If you care about people, you can call me a liberal,'' Gantt said. Meanwhile, the Justice Department sent a team of lawyers to North Carolina after Democrats charged that the state GOP was trying to intimidate black voters. The state GOP sent out postcards advising voters that they were ineligible to cast ballots if they had moved in the last 30 days. The statement on the cards is misleading, said a Justice Department official. Democrats said the postcards were targeted to heavily black precincts. The state GOP pledged not to use any information it obtained from returned postcards to challenge the eligibility of voters at the polls on Tuesday, said the Justice Department. In Hawaii, the differences between the candidates were less dramatic, and the campaigning much more genteel. Incumbent Democratic Sen. Daniel Akaka was fighting for election to the seat to which he was appointed last spring. The islands are overwhelmingly Democratic, and so Akaka's challenger, moderate Republican Rep. Pat Saiki, is asking Democrats to cross over on Tuesday. She pointed over the weekend to the fact that Sen. Daniel Inouye, Hawaii's senior Democratic senator, was supporting Oregon Republican Mark Hatfield's re-election bid. Hatfield was ahead in the polls, although not safely out of reach of Democrat Harry Lonsdale, a businessman and scientist. After six terms in the Senate, Hatfield enjoyed support from a huge array of fellow politicians. Lonsdale was in striking range largely because of his ads portraying Hatfield as too much the insider. Similar themes mark the contest in Kentucky between incumbent Mitch McConnell, a first-term Republican, and Democrat Harvey Sloane. Another insider-outsider campaign is in Minnesota, where GOP incumbent Rudy Boschwitz was favored to win re-election over Democratic upstart Paul Wellstone, a college professor. In one of the more unusual campaign pitches this fall, the Boschwitz campaign sent a letter to the Minnesota Jewish community pointing out that while both men are Jewish, Wellstone had married a non-Jew and was not raising his children in the religion. Wellstone on Sunday called the letter ``unforgivable ... the most personal attack of all.'' Personal attacks have been routine in the Senate campaigns this year. In Massachusetts, incumbent Democrat John Kerry responded to Republican Jim Rappaport's attacks by running a series of ads raising questions about Rappaport's personal finances. In New Hampshire, Democratic John Durkin accused Republican Robert Smith of being in the pocket of the ``Japs,'' because his campaign was being assisted by independent advertising from Japanese auto dealers. New Hampshire, Idaho and Colorado are the three states where incumbents senators are retiring this year. In all three, Republicans are expected to retain control of the seats. In Iowa, incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin is trying to become the first Democrat in that state ever re-elected to the Senate. His Republican challenger, Rep. Tom Tauke, was less than 10 points behind in the latest polls. Other incumbents nursing uncertain leads into the final days were Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., who faced Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider, and Sen. Larry Pressler, R-S.D., who was being challenged by businessman Ted Muenster in another throw-the-rascals-out effort.

DOC.HEAD: Top Communist Leader, Linked to U.S. Killing, Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A senior Communist leader who was believed to have helped plan the 1989 killing of a U.S. Army colonel was arrested on a suburban street, the military announced Monday. Reynaldo Bernardo, alleged deputy commander and intelligence chief of the New People's Army in the Manila area, was arrested Sunday as he was waiting for a ride in Quezon City, according to Maj. Gen. Guillermo Flores, chief of the Philippine army. Flores said Bernardo was involved in the planning of the April 21, 1989, killing of U.S. Army Col. James Rowe, who was gunned down on his way to work at the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group in Quezon City. Rowe, a counterinsurgency expert, spent eight years as a prisoner of the Viet Cong until he escaped. Flores said Bernardo was ``deeply involved in the selection of quality targets'' for assassination by the Manila-based Alex Boncayao Brigade. The brigade has claimed responsibility for the killing of more than 300 troops and civilians in the capital since it was established in 1984. It also claimed responsibility for burning passenger buses during last month's labor strike for higher wages. Flores said the initial confusion over identity resulted because Bernardo was a ``relatively new personality'' in the underground ``who rose from the ranks.'' The New People's Army has waged a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state in the Philippines. At least five other senior officials of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines have been arrested in Manila this year. In another development, the military said six rebels and one soldier were killed in a series of clashes on Samar island since last Tuesday. Samar, the third largest of the 7,100 Philippine islands, is a longtime rebel stronghold.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Sending Team To North Carolina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lede, inserts 2 grafs after 17th pvs bgng: ``The investigation'' with more detail on location of mailings, picks up 18th graf pvs bgng: ``The North''
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department sent lawyers to North Carolina on Monday to try to ensure that black voters aren't disqualified at the polls with information gathered by the state Republican Party. Assistant Attorney General John R. Dunne said the state GOP has pledged not to use any information it obtained from returned postcards to challenge the eligibility of voters at the polls on Tuesday. Democrats charged the GOP sent out the postcards to intimidate black voters and discourage them from casting ballots the neck-and-neck race between GOP Sen. Jesse Helms and former Charlotte mayor Harvey Gantt, who is black. In addition, Democrats feared that in cases where the postcards were returned to the state GOP as non-deliverable, indicating that someone had moved, the party might challenge those people at the polls if they tried to vote. Dunne said a team of Justice Department lawyers would be in the state Tuesday to consult with election officials and, if necessary, seek court injunctions to prevent the misuse of information from the postcards. The postcards advised voters that they were ineligible to cast ballots if they had moved in the last 30 days. Officials feared that if the returned postcards were used to challenge eligibility it would place an unfair burden of proof on voters. ``In our judgment, the statement on the cards was misleading if not totally inaccurate,'' Dunne said. Dunne said the investigation began last Friday, a day after Democratic Party Chairman Ron Brown charged in a letter that the North Carolina GOP had sent postcards bearing misleading and false information to residents of heavily black precincts. Brown's hand-delivered letter demanded an investigation by the Justice Department's civil rights division. The charge was made as race flared as an issue Helms' bid to defeat a stiff challenge from Gantt. Helms has accused Gantt of favoring racial job quotas and he is airing an advertisement showing the hands of a white job applicant crushing a rejection letter. The announcer states that the job went to a minority applicant to fulfill a hiring quota. The votes of blacks in North Carolina are considered a crucial ingredient in Gantt's efforts to unseat Helms, a three-term conservative Republican. Dunne said the investigation determined that the postcards had been ``disseminated on a fairly broad basis.'' Earlier in the day, a federal judge in Newark, N.J., held that the Republican National Committee was not involved in the North Carolina mailings, which Democrats charged violated a 1982 consent decree signed by the national GOP. FBI agents spent the weekend interviewing state party officials and two Justice Department voting rights lawyers were dispatched to North Carolina on Monday to pursue the investigation. Others were being sent to join them, Dunne said. ``We will continue to look at the whole scheme that was utilized'' to determine if any civil rights violation occurred, Dunne said. ``What we were concerned about in the short term was countering any negative or deterring effect these cards might have.'' The investigation so far has determined that the postcards were mailed to voters in 29 different counties, though Dunne said the department had not had an opportunity to verify the Democratic charge that they were targeted to heavily black precincts. Dunne said investigators were compiling a list of the precincts ``for the specific purpose of advising our team what to look for.'' Dunne said a large number of mailings were made in Mecklenburg County, near Charlotte. Some were also reported in Edgecombe County, in eastern North Carolina where 36 federal officials had already been sent to observe the election. The North Carolina Republican Party has turned over documents from the mailing campaign to the Justice Department. Dunne said evidence of any violations could be used to pursue a civil suit. He stressed that there was no evidence of any criminal violations of civil rights laws. Republicans had dismissed the Democrats's complaint about the mailings as ``much ado about nothing.'' ``It's merely an effort to ensure that it's a fair, honest election,'' Rick Shelby, political director of the National Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee said last week. Jack Hawke, the North Carolina GOP chairman, last week defended the postcards, saying ``the only people who received a mailing from us are those that are improperly registered.''

DOC.HEAD: Imprisoned Irish Revolutionary Denied Bail
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge refused to set bail Monday for Joseph Doherty, who for seven years has fought deportation for the 1980 slaying of an army officer in Northern Ireland. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum rejected Doherty's request for bail, saying he was likely to flee if released. Doherty, 35, was arrested in New York in 1983. He faces a life sentence for the 1980 slaying of a British officer killed in a gunfight between British troops and Doherty's four-man Irish Republican Army unit. Doherty has never been charged with a crime in the United States and has been held without bail since his arrest. He has said he quit the IRA before coming to the United States in1982. ``The evidence is overwhelming that petitioner, if released, would pose such a substantial risk of flight that no condition of bail could reasonably assure his surrender for deportation,'' Cedarbaum said in her decision. Doherty escaped from prison in Northern Ireland in 1981 and hid in this country with help from Americans sympathetic to his cause, she said. While conceding that the length of detention was ``extremely troubling,'' the judge rejected Doherty's contention that his lengthy imprisonment violated his constitutional rights. The judge said many constitutional protections did not apply to aliens in deportation proceedings. Doherty's lawyer, Mary Pike, said she would appeal the ruling. ``There is something very ominous in the notion that an individual who is unconvicted of any crime can be imprisoned for in excess of seven years,'' Pike said. The Irish-American community has rallied around Doherty, naming him honorary grand marshal of St. Patrick's Day parades around the country and sending him thousands of letters of support. Dozens of politicians and religious leaders have visited him in prison. The city also gave his name to a street near the facility. The IRA is fighting to drive the British out of Northern Ireland and unite the province - where Protestants outnumber Roman Catholics by a 3-2 margin - with the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic. More than 2,700 people have been killed in Northern Ireland since political and sectarian violence erupted in 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Cardinal Says He's Going Home
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, Cardinal Myroslav Lubachivsky, said Monday he will visit his homeland in April for the first time since leaving in 1937. The church was legalized last month after more than 40 years of suppression. Lubachivsky, 76, who is based in Rome, said he was invited by the City Council of Lvov.
