DOC.HEAD: General Cinema Calls Off Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Less than a week after announcing it would buy the remaining stock in Neiman Marcus Group, General Cinema Corp. announced today the deal was off. General Cinema, which already owns a little more than half of the 33.2 million shares of outstanding common stock in Neiman Marcus, said it would not begin its $14.40 per share offer for the remainder. General Cinema said it took the action because a special committee of the Neiman Marcus board of directors had decided to withdraw its recommendation of the tender offer. General Cinema announced the deal last Tuesday, saying it had a large available pool of cash for buying the stock. Analysts said although the retail industry is sluggish, Neiman Marcus represented a good long-term investment for General Cinema. Aside from its stake in Neiman Marcus common stock, General Cinema also holds an issue of convertible preferred stock in the specialty retailer which, if converted, would increase General Cinema's total interest to about 60 percent. General Cinema owns 16.8 million shares of common stock in Neiman Marcus.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed On Lack Of News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade amid a lack of significant developments to move the markets. Soybeans were mostly lower while the corn and soybean markets were very narrowly mixed. Analysts said wheat drew slight support from indications the Philippines was seeking to buy more than 600,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat. The Agriculture Department announced this morning that the Philippines bought 92,000 metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said harvest-related selling kept pressure on the corn and soybean markets although the harvest is nearly done. The USDA's weekly harvest update was scheduled for release today after the close. On Thursday, the government will release a monthly crop report containing revised estimates of 1990 U.S. corn and soybean production. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to { cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.64} a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower across the board with December at $1.21} a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents lower to { cent higher with November at $5.90{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Most pork belly contracts rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound, reflecting stronger cash markets. Live cattle futures were .15 cent to .28 cent higher with December at 77.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .30 cent higher with November at 87.47 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .45 cent higher with December at 52.80 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.75 cents to 2 cents higher with February at 66.20 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Fridays; pork futures rose.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Announces Expansion of Service to Japan
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines on Monday announced plans to expand its service to Japan in 1991 with new flights to Tokyo through Los Angeles and to Nagoya from Portland, Ore. The flights will begin Feb. 6 and 7, respectively. The Atlanta-based airline also selected the Tokyo-Los Angeles flight, which originates and ends in Orlando, Fla., to introduce its new MD-11 aircraft. The plane will feature advances in aerodynamics, propulsion, aircraft systems, cockpit avionics and interior design. Nagoya joins Tokyo, Seoul, Taipei and Bangkok as the fifth Asian destination served by Delta.

DOC.HEAD: Eagle-Picher Says Settlement Possible Within 30 Days
DOC.TEXT: Eagle-Picher Inc. said Monday it hopes to settle thousands of asbestos disease lawsuits and future claims within 30 days. The automobile parts and industrial machinery maker said if a settlement is reached by Dec. 2, a federal judge in New York then could order more than 60,000 pending claims consolidated into a single class-action lawsuit. The move would be a breakthrough in resolving tens of thousands of lawsuits nationwide against former makers of products containing asbestos, a widely used insulation material that can cause lung cancer and other respiratory ailments. Eagle-Picher and other companies have been trying to get federal judges to consolidate thousands of liability lawsuits and order mass settlements in an effort to limit the damages they have to pay. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who is overseeing the asbestos litigation, issued an order Saturday barring Eagle-Picker from making payments on personal injury or wrongful death claims, except in hardship cases, until Dec. 2. ``The company is pleased that a settlement appears to be imminent,'' Eagle-Picher Chairman Thomas E. Petry said in a statement. Petry said that if Weinstein approves a class action, the judge then would hold a hearing to address the settlement. Eagle-Picher made an asbestos-containing pipe insulation compound used on Navy ships. Eagle-Picher had $20 million in sales of the product from 1934 until the company stopped making it in 1971. Eagle-Picher has paid more than $500 million in settlements and lawyers' fees for asbestos disease cases. About 64,000 of 130,000 claims filed against Eagle-Picher are outstanding, company spokesman J. Rodman Nall said. In September, a court report said Eagle-Picher has been financially devastated by liability for asbestos disease claims and faced insolvency by the end of 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Scott Agrees to Joint Venture With Feldmuhle AG
DOC.TEXT: Scott Paper Co. announced Monday it has formed a joint venture with Feldmuhle AG to own and operate the Europ`There is little doubt in our minds that the company needs a lot of money and it needs a lot of money fast. We are simply saying that they are coming to the wrong people to get that kind of money.'' ``These employees can't afford a 35 percent wage cut,'' Dahl said. ``They (UPI officials) have come to us for concessions probably seven times in the last decade and there is no more left to give.'' He said officers of the union were sticking to their recommendation that the contract be rejected, but would submit it to the full membership because they believe ``this is a very, very serious situation that every member should have the opportunity to have their own say on.'' UPI announced Friday that it has cut management salaries by 35 percent for 90 days and would seek similar concessions from employees represented by the guild as it seeks a buyer for the news service. UPI has changed ownership three times in the past eight years. The news service announced in September that it would close bureaus in five states and said Oct. 12 it was dismissing an unspecified number of employees. Vanbennekom, in a message to employees transmitted over the company's wires, said, ``UPI in its last few decades never had a real chance at taking its rightful place among the successful giants of the growing information industry. It is up to us now to make sure we get a real chance.'' He cautioned, however, that approval of the pay cut would not ``guarantee UPI will be successfully sold.'' ``The only thing it guarantees is that we will be able to take the process to its conclusion, giving us vital breathing room to find the best possible home for UPI,'' he said. Vanbennekom said last Friday that several offers had been made for the news service, which is owned by Infotechnology Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Sentencing Set for Next Week
DOC.TEXT: The sentencing of junk bond financier Michael Milken will take place next week, a federal judge said Monday. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood said a specific date and time for the sentencing would be announced later this week. Milken, 44, faces up to 28 years in prison. The former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department pleaded guilty in April to six felony counts related to illegal securities trading. The sentencing follows eight days of testimony on additional allegations against Milken that the government says merit a lengthy prison term. The defense says those charges are untrue and has asked Wood to sentence Milken to a term of community service.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Reports Income, Sales Up
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Co., Japan's No. 2 automaker, on Monday reported a 16.5 percent increase in net income and record domestic sales in the first half of fiscal 1990. But Atsushi Muramatsu, a Nissan executive vice president, said the company may face falling consumer demand, higher costs and funding constrictions in the second half. He said the Tokyo stockmmarket's plunge and the uncertainties of Gulf crisis may prompt households to reconsider spending plans. For the six months ended Sept. 30, net income was 46.84 billion yen, or $367.8 million, a 16.5 percent increase from the same period a year earlier, Nissan reported. It said brisk consumer demand for new models kept sales growing for the seventh consecutive fiscal half. Unconsolidated sales rose 7 percent from a year earlier to 2.05 trillion yen, or $16.1 billion. Worldwide, the parent company sold 1.18 million vehicles, up 0.2 percent. Nissan sold a record 717,915 vehicles on the domestic market, up 8.4 percent from a year earlier, but its share of the domestic market fell to 23.6 percent from 24.2 percent in the first half of fiscal 1989. Domestic sales totaled 1.09 trillion yen, or $8.6 billion, up 13.0 percent. The company sold 462,979 vehicles abroad in the half, down 10.4 percent from a year earlier, while proceeds from the sales grew 1.3 percent to 599.13 billion yen, or $4.7 billion. Overseas production fell 3.8 percent to 308,713 vehicles. Muramatsu attributed the decline to model changes at factories in the United States and Britain, and said production was expected to increase in the second half. But he warned that a recession in the United States could lead to lower auto sales. Nissan forecast unconsolidated sales of 4.1 trillion yen, or $32.2 billion, for the full year, up 2.4 percent from fiscal 1989. It projected net income of 90 billion yen, or $706.7 million, up 5.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Aid to Countries Hit By Gulf Crisis Reaches $13 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Special aid to countries hit hardest by the Persian Gulf crisis has reached nearly $13 billion, a new coordinating committee announced Monday. Since the United Nations embargo was imposed against Iraq for invading Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Gulf states have pledged $8.4 billion in assistance for countries hurt financially by observing the embargo, said the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group. The 12-nation European Community has promised another $2.2 billion, Japan pledged $2 billion and other countries committed $300,000, the group said. About 80 percent of the aid will go to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan, the group said. Another $2.5 billion will be sent to other countries, including Syria, Morocco, Djibouti and Lebanon, according to the group. ``We're very, very satisfied with these commitments, which are very sizeable,'' said David Mulford, the U.S. undersecretary of the Treasury. The Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group was proposed by U.S. President George Bush in September. The group determines which countries need aid most, and works to assemble and disburse the money quickly. The United States was not listed as a donor because ``the U.S. is forgiving almost $7 billion of Egyptian military debt, and also has 250,000 troops on the front line,'' Mulford said. He said the group's figures are the first substantive accounting of the aid to nations affected by the U.N. embargo. Before the group reached the conclusions presented Monday, he said, it was believed that $10 billion to $11 billion had been promised to countries hurt by their compliance with the embargo. However, a Western diplomat said many of the earlier ``numbers were political numbers that didn't have a recipient attached,'' and were simply estimates of aid that might be given. ``As of today, these numbers are the commitments - and that's important for Mr. Saddam Hussein to see,'' Mulford said. He said that more than one-third of the money had already been disbursed in the form of low-cost loans, grants, and contributions of oil and other goods. The $13 billion in aid comes in addition to countries' contributions to the multinational military force and previously established bilateral assistance. More than 25 nations sent delegations to Monday's meeting, the group's third, representing countries in Western Europe and the Middle East as well as Japan, the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Representatives of the European Community, the Gulf Cooperation Council, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank also attended.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Bank, Insurance Company Announce Merger Plans
DOC.TEXT: The Netherlands' largest insurance company and its third-largest bank announced Monday they plan to merge, forming a financial giant with combined assets worth $156 billion. The Nationale Nederlanden insurance firm and NMB Postbank said in a joint statement that the merger would be in line with both companies' target of expanding in Europe and at home. The new company, whose name hasn't been determined, would be able to offer a wider range of financial services than either do separately and would combine their distribution networks in the Netherlands, according to the announcement. The move follows several earlier mergers in the Dutch financial world, including the Oct. 4, 1989, combination of the Nederlandse Middenstandsbank and Postbank, the privatized banking arm of the Dutch PTT. Under the latest proposed merger, a new holding company would issue shares in exchange for existing NMB Postbank and Nationale Nederlanden stock, the annoucement said. The offer would not be available in the United States. Further details will be worked out in the next few weeks, including an agreement with the powerful Dutch labor unions, the announcement said. ``Although cost efficiencies are possible in the long term ... the merger would not give rise to either short-term savings or short-term costs,'' the anouncement said. It did not say whether any jobs would be lost. The two companies employ approximately 16,000 people outside the Netherlands. Nationale Nederlanden, which employs 25,000 people, earned $579 million on sales of $13.6 billion in its latest fiscal year. NMB Postbank, which employs 23,000 people, earned $391 million on sales of $3.15 billion in its latest fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Seek Another Airfare Increases Because of Persian Gulf Standoff
DOC.TEXT: The leading airline industry group on Monday recommended up to an 8 percent increase in passenger fares and 7 percent rise in cargo prices to help airlines offset high fuel costs caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. The International Air Transport Association's recommendations, issued during its conference in Geneva, marked the second time since the crisis began three months ago that the airline industry has moved to raise prices because of fuel inflation. Any increase is subject to approval by affected countries. The airlines want the increases to take effect by mid-December, but association officials said some governments might not address the question until after the Christmas holidays. Airline industry profits have been battered by slowing economies in the United States and elsewhere. The rising cost of jet fuel since Iraq seized Kuwait three months ago has made matters worse for many carriers, who must buy enormous quantities of fuel at prices that fluctuate daily. The association said in a statement the increase in prices to customers are ``to recover, at least partially, continued cost increases, particularly in fuel prices.'' In August, airlines in the association said they would initially boost international passenger fares by 8 percent. Unlike fares in the United States, which have been deregulated since 1978, most international fares are determined by agreement among airlines and national governments. Industry officials say the previous fare increase, which generally took effect this month, failed to cover higher costs caused by the jump in oil prices. Seesawing crude-oil prices in recent weeks have added to the financial strain. The International Air Transport Association is the industry's leading group, with about 200 member airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Help Wanted Index Drops As Employment Demand Shrinks
DOC.TEXT: Demand for labor continued to decline in September as the economy weakened, according to a survey released Monday by the Conference Board. The business research organization said its Help Wanted Index, which tallies the volume of employment advertising in 51 major newspapers, fell to 122 from 127 in August. A year earlier, the index stood at 146. The Conference Board said advertising volume rose in only two of nine reagions of the country - the Mountain region, which includes Denver, Phoenix and Salt Lake City; and the West South Central region, which includes Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, New Orleans, Oklahoma City and Tulsa. The Labor Department reported the nation lost 52,000 jobs in September and 70,000 in October - which means the October Help Wanted Index is likely to show yet another drop. The unemployment rate fell to 5.7 percent in September and remained at that level in October. Ken Goldstein, an economist with the Conference Board, said the economy ``much too soft to generate enough job growth to keep unemployment from climbing.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Sag to 3-Month Low Amid Export, Harvest Bearishness
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices sagged to new three-month lows Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as hopes for new sales of soybean meal to the Soviet Union faded. Corn finished slightly higher, wheat slightly lower. The soybean market was further pressured by expectations that Thurday's Agriculture Department crop report will contain a significant increase in the estimated 1990 U.S. soybean harvest, said Joel Karlin, an analyst in Chicago with Research Department Inc., a brokers' advisory service. Karlin said he expects the USDA to raise its soybean production estimate to 1.85 billion bushels from last month's estimate of 1.82 billion, and some analysts believe the number may be as high as 1.9 billion. Karlin said the sharp midday decline featured heavy selling yy speculative funds that had bought soybean contracts last week in anticipation of a U.S. offer of export credits to the Soviet Union to enable the Soviets to buy soybean meal. But no such announcement came last week. On Monday, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter indicated President Bush had not changed his position of withholding export credits to the Soviets until Moscow loosens up its emigration policies. Soybeans for delivery in November fell as low as $5.80 a bushel during the session, the lowest price for near-term soybeans since Aug. 3. At the close, soybean futures were 3{ cents to 12 cents lower with the contract for delivery in November at $5.81 a bushel; wheat was } cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $2.64{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1} cents higher with December at $2.30} a bushel; oats were } cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $1.21 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Once-Freewheeling Developer Holds Household Liquidation Sale
DOC.TEXT: Former freewheeling developer Kenneth Good has resorted to what many Americans do when short on cash - a garage sale. All day Sunday, Good opened his home to deals on household items ranging from a zebra-skin rugs to plastic tissue dispensers. ``Kenneth Good Estate Liquidation Sale Today - art, furniture, TVs, stereos, kitchenware, bedroom sets, and more!'' read signs at the entrances to the ,,000-acre Tampa Palms development he built in the mid-1980s. Good, who greeted bargain-hunters to the home he once tried to sell for $650,000, said he was moving but told a reporter he did not want to talk to the press. ``We're just getting rid of some stuff,'' said a young man who identified himself as Good's son. Good is known for his business links to Neil Bush, the president's son, who was a director at the Silverado Savings and Loan Association in the 1980s. Bush is under government scrutiny for failing to inform fellow directors of his ties to Good and another developer who eventually defaulted on $132 million in loans. Silverado's collapse in 1988 cost taxpayers $1 billion. Good's empire began to crumble last fall. In April, after he missed payment on more than $200 million in debt, lenders seized control of his Gulfstream Holding Co. and its properties, including Tampa Palms. Recently, Barnett Bank took over Good's Tampa Palms house in a foreclosure auction. Some of Sunday's shoppers apparently found a few steals. One woman left cradling a jumbo box of pots and pans. Another man hauled a silver object d'art to his silver Mercedes. Others found the unmarked items too pricey. ``Everything's expensive,'' said Gerry Cameron of Tampa Palms. Good, a former Dallas developer, narrowly escaped bankruptcy in the 1970s. He moved to Denver in time to ride the wave of the oil boom and quickly entered the top social and political circles. He moved to Tampa in 1985 after buying Tampa Palms. He later bought the Gulfstream Land and Development Corp. of Florida and gained control of more than 30,000 acres in Florida and Georgia.

DOC.HEAD: Lower Yields on Bills
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in more than two years. The Treasury Department sold $9.8 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.07 percent, down from 7.12 percent last week. Another $9.8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.05 percent, down from 7.13 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.05 percent on Aug. 15, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 6.99 percent on July 11, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.30 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,812.30 and 7.41 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,643.60. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.41 percent last week, down from 7.50 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Broker Settles Insider Trading Charges
DOC.TEXT: A former stockbroker on Monday settled charges that he illegally traded on information in advance copies of Business Week magazine. John L. Petit, an ex-broker with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in Newport Beach, Calif., was the 11th person charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with illicit trading involving the weekly business magazine. Petit, who now lives in Boca Raton, Fla., agreed to pay $195,528 in illegal profits, fines and interest to settle the charges. He was barred permanently from the securities industry. The SEC said Petit did not admit or deny guilt, but agreed to cooperate in the commission's continuing investigation. The charges, filed in Manhattan's federal court at the same time his settlement was announced, said Petit obtained advance copies of Business Week from a client who was a salesman for the magazine's printer, R.R. Donnelly and Sons Co. Inc. in Torrance, Calif. Petit allegedly used the inside information to buy securities of at least 42 companies for his own account between September 1986 and July 1988. The SEC additionally accused him of sharing the information with a customer and a business partner who also traded in securities of companies mentioned in pre-release issues of the magazine. The SEC said the salesman gave Petit advance copies of the magazine in return for a discount on brokerage commissions and later for cash payments. Their transactions took place in Smith Barney's parking lot and a parking lot of a McDonald's restaurant, the complaint said. The salesman, Shayne Walters, settled similar charges with the SEC and is awaiting sentencing on a related criminal charge. Petit's payment to the SEC included $66,555 in profits he made from the illegal trades; $11,836 in brokerage commissions he earned as a result of his customers' trading activities; $23,288 in interest; and $93,847 in penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Say Late October Car, Light Truck Sales Rise
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers' sales of North American-made cars and light trucks rose 5.3 percent in late October and were up 2.7 percent for the first month of the 1991 model year, the companies said Monday. The upturn countered other portents of a slowing economy, incral of which are expected to testify. Lawyers promised to raise new issues about sexual consent and mental illness during the trial of Mark A. Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh. ``There are a lot of people who are just plain skeptical about this thing,'' District Attorney Joseph Paulus told reporters during a court recess. ``The bottom line will be if (the jury) believes it (the disorder) or not.'' Under Wisconsin law, sexual contact is forbidden with those suffering from a mental illness or deficiency so severe they can't understand the consequences of their behavior. Prosecutors allege Peterson had sex with one of 27-year-old woman's personalities last June after learning she was mentally ill. Peterson's lawyer, Edward Salzsieder, said he will show Peterson didn't know the woman was mentally ill and thought he had proper consent. The attorney said he also would try to convince the jury that the woman doesn't suffer from a mental illness and has put on ``a big show.'' The woman was expected to take the stand under the influence of six or seven of her personalities, which psychiatrists have documented. Circuit Judge Robert Hawley ruled the jury will be sequestered during the trial, which was expected to last three days. The charge against Peterson carries a maximum prison term of 10 years. The woman changed personalities on the witness stand during a preliminary hearing earlier this year. She blinked her eyes and paused each time she was asked by lawyers to switch identities. The judge required during the hearing that each of her personalities take an oath before testifying. A psychiatrist who has treated the woman for four years said he diagnosed last February that she suffered from multiple personality disorder. The disorder is triggered by emotional or physical abuse during childhood, forcing victims to create separate personalities to avoid confronting reality. It affects about 7,000 people in the United States, psychiatrists said. The woman, a college graduate, testified at the preliminary hearing that she told Peterson she was a woman of many personalities. One of her personalities is that of a male body-builder.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Agrees to Buy Remaining 50 Percent Interest In Health Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. has agreed to buy the 50 percent interest of In Health magazine and related businesses it does not already own from an investment group for an undisclosed price, it was announced Monday. In Health magazine covers consumer health topics and appears every other month with a rate base that will increase in March to 800,000 from 650,000. The magazine, published from Sausalito, Calif., was launched in April 1987 as Hippocrates magazine. Time Warner bought a 50 percent interest in late 1988. The owners spun off a magazine for physicians only in early 1989 and called it Hippocrates while using the name In Health for the remaining consumer magazine. Hippocrates, which is included in the latest deal, is sent to 120,000 doctors. Time Warne has interests in a number of regional or special interest publications, including Southern Living, Cooking Light and Parenting.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Fall, Crude Trading Seems To Have Shed Its Craziness
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell more than $2 a barrel Monday, reflecting what traders called the growing realization that global demand has declined and supplies remain adequate despite the Persian Gulf crisis. Oil trading strategists noted that the market has now gone more than a week without any wild trading based on war jitters or speculation that peace could be near. They said the market may have settled into a phase of trading based more on the fundamentals of supply and demand. ``A lot of people are not playing the market,'' said trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``I think they're waiting for some real substantial news. They're not reacting any more to the bullish news and rumors. You get a sense it's going to be a real drawn-out thing.'' Light sweet crude oil fell $2.04 to $31.96 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months all fell by the market-imposed daily limit of $1 per barrel. Volume was light. Crude had opened lower in New York following a pattern set earlier in London's petroleum market. Prices stayed down all day. Analysts said oil traders have calmed down recently as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, particularly key member Saudi Arabia, pretty much made up for the shortfall of 4 million barrels a day brought on by the international boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Also, recent reports have shown that world demand for oil has tapered off amid sharply higher prices. Oil analyst Peter Beutel, of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., agreed the market has seemed to stop moving on tidbits of news, at least for the past week. He nonetheless said the bullish news has perhaps kept oil prices propped up. ``One thing that kept prices high last week was a constant stream of comments from the White House,'' Beutel said. In a series of Republican campaign appearances, President Bush pointedly refused to rule out the use of force to push Iraqi troops out of occupied Kuwait and said his patience was waning. Other news, such as Bush's announcement he would visit troops in the Gulf for Thanksgiving, has given traders a sense that the crisis will drag on for a while without escalating into a shooting war. Senior oil analyst Ann-Louise Hittle of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said part of crude's initial rapid rise came at a time when OPEC members could not agree on whether they would lift production quotas to make up for the shortfall of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. Now they have stepped up production and the shortfall has been virtually eliminated, so the oil market has fallen back. Refined petroluem products weakened along with crude in Monday's session. Home heating oil was off 2.96 cents at 84.46 cents a gallon on contracts for December delivery. Unleaded gasoline dropped 1.67 cents to 87.54 cents a gallon for December delivery. Later months closed lower for both products. Natural gas prices were mixed, with cold-weather months trading higher and later months trading lower. December delivery contracts fell 2.7 cents to $2.385 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Sanders Made President of Tissue Company
DOC.TEXT: The board of Kimberly-Clark Corp. has elected Wayne R. Sanders as president and chief operating officer, the company said Monday. The election signals Sanders as the most likely successor to Darwin E. Smith, who is retiring as chairman and chief executive officer in April 1992. Smith has led Kimberly-Clark since 1971. The election is part of a plan implemented several years ago to prepare for Smith's departure, said Kimberly-Clark spokeswoman Tina Berry. The company has not had a president since 1985 and chief operating officer is a new post for Kimberly-Clark. Sanders, 43, was most recently president of the company's international and service and industrial operations, based in Neenah, Wis. He joined the company as a financial analyst in 1975, rose through the ranks of Kimberly-Clark's Canadian affiliate and later became president of the company's personal care sector. The Dallas-based company makes Kleenex facial tissue, Huggies diaper products, newsprint and other specialty papers.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market forged ahead Monday, extending last week's rally on the strength of continuing hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.39 to 2,502.23 on top of last week's 54.70-point gain. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,029 up, 547 down and 425 unchanged. Analysts attribute the market's recent upswing to expectations of a drop in interest rates. With evidence mounting of weakness in business activity, many observers say, the Federal Reserve is getting more and more leeway to relax its credit policy. Wall Streeters hope cheaper money will alleviate the credit problems that have been unsettling the banking industry and the real estate market. In the credit markets Monday, prices of long-term Treasury bonds, which move in the opposite direction from interest rates, showed gains approaching $10 for each $1,000 in face value. The depressed bank stocks, which began an upswing late last week, were mostly higher again Monday. Manufacturers Hanover rose ~ to 18{; BankAmerica 1{ to 21~; J.P. Morgan 1[ to 40[, and C&S-Sovran [ to 16 as the most active Big Board issue. Among other prominent financial issues, Federal Home Loan Mortgage gained 1{ to 37}; Federal National Mortgage ~ to 30[; Kemper Corp. | to 19{, and Travelers Corp. { to 14]. Falling oil prices provided another plus for the market. Crude oil for December delivery dropped more than $2 a barrel, to just under $32 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Retailing issues rallied on hopes that lower interest rates and oil prices would help reverse the recent slide in measures of consumer confidence. Sears Roebuck climbed } to 26]; Kmart 1~ to 26; Woolworth 1[ to 27[, and J.C. Penney 1| to 42. But Neiman Marcus Group fell 1~ to 12}. General Cinema, which owns about 60 percent of Neiman Marcus, said it had dropped plans to make a tender offer for the remaining stock in public hands. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 147.51 million shares, down from 168.70 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 185.40 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $26.71 billion, or 0.92 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.42 to 171.49. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.59 to 368.44, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.74 at 314.59. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 4.31 to 340.76. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 291.58, up 1.60.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Sag to 3-Month Low as Exports Weaken, Harvest Grows
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices sagged to new three-month lows Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid disappointment over export sales and perceptions that the 1990 U.S. soybean production will exceed expectations. Grain futures finished mixed. On other commodity markets, oil futures fell sharply; precious metals rose; coffee was down; livestock futures were mixed; and pork bellies soared. Soybean futures settled 3{ cents to 12\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in November at $5.81{ a bushel, the lowest settlement for near-term soybeans since Aug. 2. Analysts traced the steep midday sell-off to two main factors: fading hopes for sales of soybean meal to the Soviet Union and expectations that Thursday's Agriculture Department crop report will contain a significantly larger soybean harvest projection than last month's government estimate of 1.82 billion bushels. Joel Karlin, an analyst with the Chicago-based brokers' advisory service Research Department Inc., said some of the heaviest sellers were speculative funds that bought soybean contracts last week expecting the Bush administration would grant export credits to the Soviet Union to enable the Soviets to buy soybean meal and other agricultural commodities. But there was no such announcement and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter indicated Monday that President Bush had not changed his position of withholding export credits to the Soviets until Moscow relaxes its emigration policies. After the close, the USDA's weekly export-inspections report showed 7.7 million bushels of soybeans were inspected for export last week, compared with 26.6 million a year ago. Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the report was another indication of slack foreign demand for soybeans. The soybean harvest estimate in Thursday's USDA crop report is widely expected to exceed last month's projection of 1.82 billion bushels, analysts said. Frick said she expects the USDA to peg the soybean crop at 1.835 billion bushels, Karlin said he's looking for 1.85 billion and Sparks Commodities Inc., a Memphis-based analytical firm, estimated 1990 U.S. soybean production at 1.9 billion bushels. Wheat futures settled { cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.64\ a bushel; corn was { cent to 2 cents higher with December at $2.30} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $1.21 a bushel. Petroleum futures fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange following a report that Saudi Arabian crude oil output has reached 8.2 million barrels per day, its highest level in 10 years. Oil traders said realization is growing that global demand has declined and supplies remain adequate despite the Persian Gulf crisis. Light sweet crude oil finished $1 to $2.04 lower with December at $31.96 a barrel; heating oil was 2 cents to 2.96 cents lower with December at 84.46 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.67 cents to 3.39 cents lower with December at 87.54 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures surged on New York's Commodity Exchange in a rebound from Friday's steep decline. The markets regained more than half of what they lost in the previous session. Gold settled $3.10 to $3.20 higher with December at $381.10 a troy ounce; silver was 3.9 cents to 4.2 cents higher with December at $4.227 a troy ounce. Coffee futures retreated for the fifth straight day on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, reflecting expectations of heavy coffee shipments from producer countries to consumer countries during the third quarter. Coffee ended 2.4 cents to 3.05 cents lower with December at 86 cents a pound. Frozen pork belly futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as the market posted its fourth straight daily advance on signs that demand and fresh-belly prices have risen. Livestock futures were narrowly mixed. Live cattle futures settled .30 cent lower to .10 cent higher with December at 77.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .10 cent higher with November at 87.32 cents a pound; live hogs were .43 cent lower to .08 cent higher with December at 52.32 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.8 cents to 1.98 cents higher with February at 66.25 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: State Banker Joins Criticism of Gorbachev's Economic Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, Referring to, to CORRECT second reference to Mozhaisky. Picks up 5th graf, Gorbachev's compromise. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A state bank official on Monday added his voice to the growing criticism of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for the switch to a market economy, warning it could hurt overall reforms. The criticism followed gloomy predictions from two of the Soviet president's economic advisers, who warned that the plan could spark hyperinflation and cut the standard of living. Oleg Mozhaisky, head of the bank's hard-currency department, told a news conference that recent Gorbachev decrees expanding the use of hard currency were misguided. Referring to the use of dollars in the Soviet economy, Mozhaisky said: ``Dollarization wouldn't bring us closer to the goals of perestroika but would worsen the state of the ruble and could make those goals more distant.'' Gorbachev's compromise program for restructuring the economy was adopted Oct. 19 by the Soviet legislature. It is already under sharp attack in many of the 15 republics. Gorbachev's own advisers have expressed doubts that it will succeed. The economic advisers, Nikolai Petrakov and Stanislav Shatalin, said in a letter to a liberal newspaper that Gorbachev's plan will increase the budget deficit and disrupt economic links among the 15 Soviet republics. The Soviet Union has a deficit of 60 billion rubles, or about $96 billion. ``The decrease in the standard of living of the population will be significant before stabilization. ... The inflationary spiral is winding up too quickly, the collapse of the consumer market is growing and the economy is moving further from a state of equilibrium,'' the economists said in the letter, published Sunday in Komsomolskaya Pravda. The letter, signed by 11 other economists, accused the Soviet leadership of ``indecisiveness and inconsistency'' in economic reform. The statement was a rare public airing of differences between Gorbachev and his aides. Shatalin, a member of Gorbachev's Presidential Council, an advisory body, had written a plan to switch to a market system in 500 days. Gorbachev first supported it, then backed off. Immediately after the Gorbachev plan was adopted, Shatalin said he supported it generally. Since then, he had refrained from public comment. The criticism was particularly striking coming from Petrakov, Gorbachev's usually loyal personal economic adviser. Mozhaisky told reporters he had not read the letter. He expressed general support for Gorbachev's economic reforms, but took issue with two decrees: one creating an auction among Soviet businesses for the foreign currency they hold, and the other setting up a network of stores selling goods in hard currency, or currency that can be converted on the world market. In their criticism, the economists appeared to side more with Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin than Gorbachev. Yeltsin has described Gorbachev's plan as a ``catastrophe'' that will drive up prices and the budget deficit and decrease the ruble's purchasing power. Russia, the country's largest republic, voted to go its own way and implement Shatalin's 500-day plan on Nov. 1. The Gorbachev plan merged that blueprint with a more cautious plan drafted by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. In their letter, the 13 economists also criticized Russian officials. They said the Russian parliament's decision to raise purchase prices and to consider raising pensions will mean that within six months, ``the entire population of the republic, including pensioners, will live worse as a result of inflation or introduction of rationing.'' The 500-day plan, the economists noted, had envisioned delaying increases in pensions and prices until the slide of the ruble's value was arrested. The economists also said: -The government's plan to raise retail prices by decree and compensate low-income groups ``is a path to hyperinflation.'' -The Soviet legislature's one-month delay in adopting a reform program leaves less time by the end of this fiscal year for reforming the banking system, controlling the budget and undertaking tax reform. Meanwhile, they said: ``The population is losing faith in both the reform and in authorities.'' -That representatives of republics had agreed to a unified economic program but because it was bypassed, they are going their own way and ``a unified all-union market is under threat.'' -That the government's plan to cut the budget deficit by 25 billion to 30 billion rubles in 1991 is ``absolutely unrealistic.''

DOC.HEAD: New Technology Links Computers With Incoming Calls
DOC.TEXT: IBM, Northern Telecom Inc. and Nynex Corp. on Monday announced a product that links incoming phone calls at a company or organization with computerized information on the caller. The system will make it easier, for example, for customer service representatives at a mail-order house to handle inquiries and for public-safety officials at a college to locate a caller in an emergency, the companies said. Previously, such systems only were available to companies owning expensive in-house phone switching systems. The new system is aimed at companies and organizations that do not have their own private phone system. It operates through the electronic central-office switch of the local phone company. The systems match the number of an incoming phone call with a computer file. The file then pops up on a screen, using the same telephone network technology as residential ``caller ID'' systems that flash the number of an incoming call on a small screen near the telephone. For instance, a customer's file would appear on a screen at a mail order catalog company where that customers has an account, before the customer service representative even picks up the phone. Syracuse University will become the first phone user to participate in a demonstration of the new system, which is called CompuCall by Northern Telecom, a Canadian-based maker of phone company switching gear. With the system, the college's in-house emergency phone number will be linked to computerized files on the location of every phone on campus and nearby emergency exits. The information for the particular phone will show up on a computer screen as the call is answered. Like the caller ID system, the new phone technology could raise concerns about callers' privacy. Caller ID systems have been criticized because they provide a caller's phone number, which can be used without permission for marketing or other purposes. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., Northern Telecom's principal North American rival in central phone switches, does not offer a similar system, said Joe Bellace, a Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst. However, he called the system a ``future product'' that should not have significant earnings impact for the three participating companies for some time. Northern Telecom said the system only works with International Business Machines Corp. minicomputers, but eventually should be expanded to other makes. IBM earlier this year announced a system called CallPath that links its minicomputers with incoming phone calls over private phone systems made by several companies.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls to New Lows, Gold Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and grafs 11-12 to remove reference to new low against the French franc.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply Monday, reaching a new post-war low against the German mark and a new low against the Swiss franc, as traders continued to take a pessimistic view of the U.S. economy. Gold prices rose in response to the dollar's decline. Analysts said there were no news developments to affect the dollar Monday; the U.S. currency slid on the continued expectation that the Federal Reserve would be forced to move interest rates in this country lower to shore up the flagging economy. Market watchers said they expected the dollar's decline to continue. ``There's no reason why the trend should not continue,'' said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with Bank of New York Co. As long as the economy weakens, traders are expected to shun the dollar. Like all currencies, it is supported by higher interest rates, and the prospect of lower rates means the dollar cannot compete against currencies of nations with higher rates. The dollar fell to a new post-war closing low against the German mark. The U.S. currency closed at 1.4850 German marks, down from 1.4945 on Friday, its previous low. In earlier European trading, the dollar skidded to 1.4923 marks, down from 1.5015 on Friday. The dollar also reached a new closing low against the Swiss franc, ending at 1.2505 francs in New York, down from late Friday's 1.2605. The previous low was 1.2558 francs on Aug. 23. In Europe, the dollar also fell to 1.2505 francs, down from 1.2705 on Friday. The dollar also dipped below 5 French francs. In New York, the dollar closed at 4.9810 francs, down from 5.0180 on Friday. In Europe, the dollar dipped to 4.9875 French francs, down from 5.0420. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included 1,116.00 Italian lire, down from 1,123.75; and 1.15875 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16475. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.35 Japanese yen from 129.10 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 127.05 yen, and in New York, the dollar fell to 126.55 yen from 127.78 yen on Friday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9675 from $1.9515 late Friday. The pound also rose in New York, where it closed at $1.9740, up from Friday's $1.9590. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6765 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6938; 1,116.25 Italian lire, down from 1,129.00; and 1.1586 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1653. Gold rose $3.10 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $379.50 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $378.65, up $2.40. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $377.25 a troy ounce, from $376.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $376.30 an ounce from $375.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.13 an ounce to close at $376.93. Silver rose 4.3 cents on the Commodity Exchange to close at $4.203 a troy ounce. In earlier London trading, silver was unchanged at a bid of $4.18.

DOC.HEAD: Intel's New Chips Should Make Desktop Video Computers Cheaper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, `One problem ...,' to CORRECT ``minute'' to ``second.'' Picks up 11th graf, `To skirt ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY30
DOC.TEXT: The market for so-called multimedia computing got a boost Monday as Intel Corp. announced new chips that should cut the cost of adding video technology to personal computers. Intel says its chips should allow computer makers to offer machines that edit and store moving images - much like they do text - for about $1,000 more than a regular computer. While similar technology exists, it costs at least $2,000 above the price of a personal computer, Intel said. Intel said its technology should spur the growth of multimedia, or the marriage of television and computing. Multimedia, which has yet to take off, allows the data, text and interactive capabilities of computers to be mixed with video, stereo sound, still photographs and animation. Multimedia already is used fornd zeros of computer language. Intel's chips, for example, compress video data by a factor of at least 100 to 1. The images then can be stored on a computer's internal hard disk or, for greater capacity, on a compact disk similar to those used in home audio systems. Intel says its system is the only one designed for ordinary IBM personal computers and compatible models. Competing systems require specialized, more costly computers, said Intel spokeswoman Karen Andring. Intel said its technology also is superior to systems using video disk players to incorporate video into computer programs. Since these systems do not convert the video into digital form, it cannot be manipulated on the computer screen. In addition, Intel says, its system is cheaper. With Intel's system, a computer user could connect a VCR to a desktop machine and insert sections of a television program or movie into a computer program. The system allows special video effects such as fading, zooming and panning. Intel's technology originally was developed at the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J. Intel bought the technology from General Electric Co. in 1988, and since has been developing it in conjunction with IBM. The technology, which Intel calls DVI, for digital video interactive, originally took up seven computer boards and cost about $22,000. In February, Intel made the same system available on two computer boards for $2,000. At a demonstration Monday in New York, Intel announced it had shrunk much of the technology to fit onto two fingernail-sized computer chips for under $100. Further enhancements should make the chips even more powerful and cheaper, Intel said. However, the chips only provide the heart of the system, so other components are needed to actually incorporate mulitimedia into computers, boosting the price to the expected $1,000 level. Among computer and software makers exploring Intel's technology or already offering it are American Telephone & Telegraph Co., Compaq Computer Corp., Microsoft Corp., Lotus Development Corp., Olivetti of Italy and Toshiba, Aiwa and Matsushita of Japan, Intel said. In addition, PictureTel Corp., a maker of video phones, is collaborating with Intel in research that could slash the price of video phones and make the technology common on personal computers, said Norman Gaut, PictureTel's chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Ministers Call It Quits for the Night
DOC.TEXT: European Community agriculture and trade ministers late Monday suspended talks on a proposal to cut farm subsidies until Tuesday morning to give time for high-level consultations between EC governments. Officials said several EC heads of state, including French President Francois Mitterrand and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, were talkin by phone in attempts to arrange a final farm plan. An EC official who asked not to be named said negotiators were treating the Tuesday meeting as an ``unofficial deadline'' for an agreement. The ministers are working under the threat that failure to reach agreement soon could torpedo talks to liberalize world trade. The issue of farm subsidies is one of the key obstacles to the broader trade negotiations. The United States and other agricultural exporters contend the EC unfairly subsidizes farmers, enabling them to sell food more cheaply abroad. Officials said Italian trade minister Renato Ruggiero told the ministers during Monday's meeting that it was ``crucial'' they agree on cutting subsidies for farmers. If not, the United States would use the EC's failure to do so as a reason to abandon the Uruguay Round talks, a four-year effort of more than 100 nations to liberalize world trade, the officials quoted Ruggiero as saying. Those talks are due to end in December. British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer said, ``If we don't find a solution now, we will look ridiculous.'' The ministers were at odds over a proposal to trim farm subsidies on major crops by 30 percent over a period of years. France and Germany have been insisting on guarantees that the trims would not seriously hurt their farmers. In preparation for Monday's meeting, the European Commission, the community's executive body, devised a list of guarantees designed to allay the nations' fears but it was not clear whether it would succeed. ``Logically, there ought to be no reason why we can't come to an agreement,'' said Gummer. But another community official said, ``I don't see any change. I don't see any movement.'' The ministers were repeating the same position they have held for a month, the official said. France, the community's largest exporter of farm products, still appeared to have doubts. Ministers from the 12 EC nations failed in six tries last month to reach an accord. Ruggiero opened Monday's session saying the offer of a 30 percent cut in subsidies ``is not minimal, but of great value.''

DOC.HEAD: Boosts Ad Rates by 6.5 Percent for 1991
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped word `percent' in lead
DOC.TEXT: Time Magazine announced a 6.5 percent rate boost Monday for a full-page, four-color advertisement in 1991 national editions. `The weekly, 2nd graf pvs

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Brokerage Opens U.S. Office
DOC.TEXT: Probursa, Mexico's third largest stock brokerage, opened a U.S. office Monday with plans to use it to help find funding for Mexican companies. Probursa said its decision to open the New York office was prompted by the increasing privatization of many sectors of the Mexican economy, particularly banking, as well as by the surge in Mexican manufacturing and the possibility that a U.S.-Mexican free trade pact will be reached. ``As Wall Street is feeling the effects of the sluggish United States economy, leading investors are looking elsewhere to place their investment dollars,'' said Jose Madariaga, Probursa's chairman. ``Increasingly, they are turning to the Mexican market, which is no longer depending only on oil exports,'' said Madariaga, who also is chairman of the Mexican stock exchange. The New York office is Probursa's first outside Mexico, where it operates 25 retail brokerage outlets.

DOC.HEAD: Sun Unveils New Workstations
DOC.TEXT: Sun Microsystems Inc. on Monday introduced four new workstations that it called faster and more sophisticated machines which form the high end of the company's desktop line. The new SPARCstation 2 computers are almost twice as fast as the SPARCstation 1 models introduced last year, Sun said. They range from a $14,995 monochrome-display workstation to a $49,985 color-screen version offering three-dimensional modeling and animation. Workstations are high-powered personal computers aimed primarily at scientists, engineers and others who need great computing capacity or high-quality graphics. ``The addition of the SPARCstation 2 line with its great graphics simply makes this environment better for technical professionals who have real performance needs,'' said Scott McNealy, president and chief executive officer of the Mountain View-based company. Like its predecessor, the SPARCstation 2 uses the popular Unix operating system and Open Look graphical interface and packages the electronics in a small ``pizza box'' enclosure. But while the earlier models offered from 8 to 48 megabytes of memory, the new ones offer 16 to 96 megabytes. A megabyte is roughly a million characters of information. The new line also includes a low-cost file server, a computer that acts as the hub of a network of desktop machines. The new products are being offered in addition to the $4,995 SPARCstation SLC and $7,995 IPC desktops introduced last year.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysia Airlines Orders 10 Boeing Jets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS fifth graf to CORRECT engine maker to GE-SNECMA consortium; PICK UP 6th graf pvs, Boeing now ...
DOC.TEXT: Malaysia Airlines has ordered 10 Boeing 737-400 jetliners and taken options on 10 others, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Monday. Value of the 10 firm orders is about $330 million. The new twinjets will help Malaysia meet anticipated growth both within the country and throughout Asia, airline managing director Tan Sri Abdul Aziz said. The new planes will replace some smaller 737-200s and interim 737-400s that are leased. The new jets will carry 146 passengers each and have a range of about 2,160 miles. They will be powered by CFM56-3C engines, built by a consortium of General Electric and SNECMA of France. Boeing now has received 264 orders for 737-400s and 2,852 orders for all 737 models.

DOC.HEAD: Unions Pledge $2 Million to Striking Newspaper Unions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to remove reference to circulation apparently dipping; picks up 2nd graf, `The tabloid ...' INSERTS one graf after 13th, `However, News...,' to ADD rival paper's estimate of circulation figures. Picks up 14th graf, `Since the...' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Local and national labor leaders pledged $2 million Monday to help the unions striking the Daily News, while management fought to get the newspaper to readers. The tabloid has continued to publish since the strike began nearly two weeks ago with editors joined by reporters and editors from other newspapers, union members who have crossed the picket line and new hires. But with editorial and production problems apparently licked the job of getting the paper to would-be readers remained. Eight unions struck on Oct. 25, followed the next day by the Newspaper Guild, which represents reporters, photographers and other workers. About 2,000 people are on strike, although some have returned in various Guild departments. The unions went on strike over what they termed unfair labor practices. They had been involved in negotiations since January over contracts that expired in March. The printers stayed on the job to preserve lifetime job guarantees negotiated when automation was introduced. Nine other unions representing groups from Teamsters to teachers agreed Monday to co-sign a $2 million loan to assist the strikers. ``We were very delighted to hear this morning that they were going to help us reach a strike fund of $2 million,'' said George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, a coalition of 10 unions at the News. ``We need it to go out on radio and TV and fight the enemy,'' he said. News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson has declined to provide printing and circulation figures since Friday. Figures provided by the News have been widely disputed. However, Robinson did say the News has had ``tremendous success getting the paper out.'' Hawkers are giving away free papers, including 50,000 on Sunday. More are to be placed in regional malls, but she would not disclose where. ``We're moving toward our normal routine circulation,'' she said. The News' circulation is 1.09 million on weekdays and 1.4 million on Sundays. It is the third largest metropolitan daily in the country. However, News management sources speaking on the condition of anonymity said the paper printed 600,000 copies of its Sunday editions. A source at a rival newspaper, also speaking anonymously, said its circulation people estimated the News distributed 257,000 copies Sunday, including home delivery. That would be down from 300,000 distributed on the first Sunday of the strike, the source said. Since the strike began, most of the sports department, the library staff, the features department and the photography staff have returned. A News official said that about 150 Guild members in the 350-member editorial department have returned, including seven on Monday. At least two others who went back to work rejoined the strike on Monday. Violence filled the first few nights near the Brooklyn printing plant and there have been arsons and misdemeanor charges laid to the unions for damage done to newsstands. McDonald and other union leaders have denounced violence and said they would call upon their members to refrain from it. ``There's no violence there,'' McDonald said Monday. ``I've talked to a lot of newsdealers about not carrying the Daily News. But that's all I did. Those aren't threats.''
